PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.
To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned humbly request that the Senate honours the obligations of the Commonwealth of Australia to protect its territory that has received World Heritage status according to the World Heritage Convention of which Australia is a signatory.

Significant ares of marine and mangrove ecosystems of Australia's World Heritage Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are directly threatened with destruction by the adjacent construction of Australia's largest tourist resort and marina complex at Oyster Point near Cardwell North Queensland (opposite Hinchinbrook Island).

We implore the Senate to use its powers immediately to permanently halt the construction of the marina and access channel in the World Heritage "Buffer Zone" as recommended by the Valentine Report made to his Department in October 1994.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned urges the Government to press for a total ban internationally on the production, stockpiling, trade and use of anti-personnel devices;
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate urge the Government to provide financial aid for the de-mining of countries such as Cambodia.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

The Federal Minister for Immigration, Senator Bolkus reverse a decision refusing entry to Australia for Dana Nance, the Romanian adopted daughter of South Australian parents, Graham and Jennifer Nance and, that the Minister use his powers under Section 35(1) of the Migration Act 1958 in the public interest to personally intervene and allow Dana Nance to become an Australian citizen.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: PRAWN BOAT LEVY BILL 1994
Second reading speech by the Parliamentary Secretary representing the Minister for Resources.
I move that this bill now be read a second time.
The purpose of this bill is to provide the legislative framework for collecting a prawn boat levy from boats that catch prawns for the export market.

In this bill, as in the Prawn Export Charge Bill, the government has taken account of the `user pays' principle by targeting only that sector of the prawn fishing industry that catches prawns for export markets. Boats that would normally take prawns only for the domestic market are exempt from the levy.
The levy will be payable by the owner of any boat that is licensed to be used to take prawns and is a registered establishment under the Export Control Act 1982.
The rate of levy is to be set by regulation, being initially between $50 and $500 per boat per annum, depending on the length of the boat.
There are four categories of boat length levies.

PARA.TAB: (a)A boat less than 10M will attract $50;
(b)A boat 10 but less than 15m will attract $100;
(c)A boat 15 but less than 18m will attract $200; and
(d)A boat over 18M will attract $500.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation provides for a maximum levy rate 50 per cent higher than each of the rates set out above. Pro rata rates of levy will be prescribed in the first year of operation of the act if the act comes into effect part way through a financial year.
It is expected that the boat levy will raise some $300,000 during the first full year of operation.
It is important to note that levy rates for boat length can only be raised following an APPA annual general meeting at which approval is given by members agreeing to new rates of levy.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum.
PRAWN EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1994
I move that this bill now be read a second time.

The purpose of this bill is to provide the legislative framework for collecting a charge on the export of sea caught prawns, parts of sea caught prawns and the sea-caught prawn component of a product.

This bill proposes that all sea-caught prawns, parts of sea caught prawns and the sea caught prawn component of a product, which are exported from Australia be subject to a charge for the funding of the export promotion program.

The charge will be paid by the exporter and will be initially set at 2 cents per kilogram. Only by Industry's recommendation can the rate of the charge be raised by regulation to a maximum of 10 cents per kilogram.
This levy is expected to raise some $200 000 for promotion in the first full year of operation.
It is important to note that levy rates for the export charge can only be raised following an APPA Annual General Meeting at which approval is given by members agreeing to new rates of charge.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum.
PRAWN EXPORT PROMOTION BILL 1994
Second reading speech by the Parliamentary secretary representing the Minister for resources.
I move that this bill now be read a second time.

The purposes of this bill is to provide the administrative framework for collecting, managing and disbursing the prawn promotion funds. This is one of three bills which, collectively, provide funding for the export promotion of Australian sea-caught prawns.

The prawn sector is an important part of the Australian fishing industry, providing significant input to a number of regional economies. In 1992-93 prawn exports totalled $260 million which is nearly 20 per cent of the total Australian fishing industry GVP.

Some 10,000 tonnes of sea-caught prawns are exported annually. Over the past few years, market share and earnings have been reduced through direct competition in overseas markets, mainly from aquaculture prawns being produced in Asian countries. Prices have fluctuated dramatically over the last six years and this has affected all sectors of the industry.

All major Australian prawn fisheries are being fished to full capacity and are being carefully managed by state and Commonwealth authorities to ensure sustainability for the industry. Increased catches to counteract falling prices are just not possible.

Faced with these pressures, the prawn fishing industry recognised the benefits of developing a structured and coordinated approach to market development. Through the Australian Prawn Promotion Association (APPA), the industry is working to increase the export value of Australian sea-caught prawns, especially those sold in the Japanese market.

The industry developed a promotional strategy to contrast Australian sea-caught prawns with the Asian farmed product. The strategy aims to make the public aware of the excellent quality of Australian sea-caught prawns, taken from clean, unpolluted seas. It will also stress specific attributes such as size, flavour and health status.
This is a great example of an industry working together to best promote its product in a very competitive market.
The promotion plan will be complemented with action in other important areas such as value adding, product quality, freight cost minimisation and reliability of supply.

Following development of the proposal over several years, the vast majority of the Australian prawn industry has called for a compulsory levy on its members to promote its products in export markets, particularly in Japan.
APPA had tried introducing voluntary levies but these did not work due to a large number of free riders.

Government support in collecting levy is not unique to the prawn industry. Within the primary industries and energy portfolio, some 30 compulsory levies or charges are collected by the government to fund promotion and other activities to assist primary industries.
Compulsory levies will allow for greater accountability over the use of funds and ensure that those gaining the greatest benefit from the promotion will make the largest contribution.

Given the very strong industry support for the promotion scheme and its funding through a levy, the government was pleased to agree to industry's request to introduce legislation for compulsory levy. The prawn boat levy and the prawn export charge are the two mechanisms by which contributions will be collected.

To support APPA in the responsible management of public funds, the Commonwealth's Fisheries Research and Development Corporation (FRDC) will oversight the management and disbursement of the funds collected.

APPA will bear the responsibility for determining the promotional activities and the day to day running of the scheme. APPA will also provide FRDC with strategic, annual operational plans and annual reports about prawn promotion. These will form a segment of any FRDC reporting requirement to the minister.

The government is pleased to allow APPA to be the main player in running the promotion program. The government views this as an important industry initiative and considers it will prove an important example to other sectors of the fishing industry wanting to promote their products.

The prawn export promotion bill will provide the administrative framework for collecting, managing and disbursing the prawn promotion funds. The collection arrangements closely mirror those that appear in the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (PILCC) Act 1991.
This new bill adapts the essential features of the PILCC Act 1991 for the collection of both the prawn export charge and the prawn boat levy.

One of the provisions in this bill will give the secretary of the department the power to conclude an agency agreement with APPA, making it the collecting organisation for the boat levy and the export charge, thus reducing administrative costs on the scheme.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum.
ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK (ADDITIONAL SUBSCRIPTION) BILL 1994

The purpose of this Bill is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up its allocated subscription to the fourth general capital increase of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). This means Australia would subscribe to 102,370 shares, of which only 2,047 shares will be paid-in at a cost of $US24.69 million.

Honourable senators will be aware that the bank, which was established in 1966, is a major multilateral development finance institution engaged in promoting social and economic advancement in the Asia-Pacific region. Major borrowers include the People's Republic of China, Indonesia and India.
It has 55 member countries from within and outside the region.
The bank's capital is of two kinds: paid-in and callable. The capital increase involves actual payment by members of the paid-in component, and a potential liability for the callable component.

The callable component of the bank's capital serves as collateral against which the bank borrows funds for onlending. The bank's loans have been financed largely by funds borrowed from international financial markets. A call on the callable capital of the bank has never been made. The bank's prudent financial policies and healthy level of reserves make it unlikely that such a call will ever be made in the future.

Under the bank's articles of agreement the maximum amount of funds the bank can lend can not exceed the total amount of its unimpaired subscribed capital, reserves and surplus. In March 1994 the bank reached its lending limit and stopped making new loan commitments.
In May 1994, the ADB Board of Governors approved a resolution authorising a general capital increase which doubles the share allocation from 1,720,497 shares to 3,440,994 shares.
This will allow the bank to expand its borrowings and so finance the bank's operations to beyond the year 2000 and allow the bank to pursue its development objectives in the region.
Under the general capital increase, Australia is entitled to subscribe to an additional 102,370 shares.
Only 2 per cent of these shares need to be paid-in.
As a result of the low paid-in component, the annual cost of the subscription accounts for a very small part of Australia's aid budget.
In supporting the bank, Australia recognises the significant contribution it has made to developing countries in Asia.

In pursuing its original prime objective of economic growth and poverty alleviation the bank has also emphasised private sector development, public sector efficiency, human resource development and natural resource management.

More recently, at the urging of Australia and other donor countries, the bank is paying greater attention to environmental and social problems. In fact, the agreement of several donor countries to adopt the resolution for an additional share allocation was conditional upon the adoption of a policy statement to guide the bank's operations in the 1990's.

This statement emphasises initiatives to strengthen the planning process in the bank, incorporating cross-cutting concerns such as poverty, population, women in development, social sector investment and the environment and addressing new policy issues such as good governance, disclosure of information and the establishment of an inspection function to review potential non-compliance of bank policies.
Most of these initiatives have either been implemented or are in the process of being implemented.

The bank has now established a 50/50 mix between traditional projects which emphasised economic growth and those projects which are aimed at poverty reduction, human resource development, women in development and environmental protection.
The main way in which the bank assists its developing country members is by providing loans for economic and social infrastructure development.
Between 1966 and 1993, the bank provided its member countries with loans totalling $US32.8 billion from its ordinary capital resources.
The bank's lending is primarily to the public sector. However, some direct and indirect funding of the private sector has also been undertaken.
The bank's lending activities have focussed on projects in the agriculture, energy, finance, transport and communications and the social infrastructure sectors.
In addition to its financing activities, the bank plays an important role in providing advice on economic policies, sector restructuring and institutional development in developing member countries.

Policy reform measures relating to macroeconomic policies, sector programs and projects are usually associated with the bank's lending activities and are aimed at improving economic growth prospects, ameliorating poverty and addressing social inequities.
The economic policies promoted by the bank are outward-looking and consistent with the development of open international trade and financial markets.
Through its lending and technical assistance activities, the bank supports the strengthening of institutions which are essential for economic and social advancement.
Australia's participation in the bank allows us to pursue our economic, political and humanitarian interests in collaboration with other donor and developing countries.

The bank's activities have complemented Australia's bilateral aid program in a number of countries, most particularly in Cambodia, Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, the South Pacific island countries and Vietnam.
Participation in the Asian Development Bank has also allowed us to widen the focus of our aid at a relatively low administrative cost.
Australian membership of the bank entitles Australian suppliers of goods and services to bid for work generated under bank-financed activities.
In the past five years, loan disbursements by the bank have averaged $US2.6 billion per year.
This provides a sizeable commercial opportunity for Australian firms.

The most significant benefit to Australia from the bank's activities, however, is not direct procurement from bank projects but the wider export opportunities for Australian businesses deriving from economic growth promoted by the bank in the Asia-Pacific region.
Australian exports to the developing member countries of the bank increased from $12.7 billion in 1988/89 to $23 billion in 1992/93.
As a proportion of total Australian exports, exports to those countries rose from 29 per cent to 38 per cent during this five year period.
There is enormous potential for further exports as economic growth in the region continues.
Australia is a founding member of the ADB and a strong supporter of it.
At the same time, Australia has not been uncritical of the bank where criticism has been justified and it has been pressing the bank to improve its efficiency and effectiveness.
In response to concerns expressed by Australia and other countries about the quality of bank loans, in 1993 the bank established a taskforce to provide recommendations for improving project quality.
Following the report of the taskforce in early 1994, the bank has taken measures to improve the quality of projects.

As recommended by the taskforce, the bank is currently reviewing its organisational structure to make it more relevant to its strategic objectives and to improve the quality of its projects through improved coordination of its project and program work, greater attention to project implementation vis-a-vis project approvals, strengthening of project executing agencies in the borrowing countries, and improved accountability for the quality of projects within the ADB.

I believe that the economic and political significance of the Asia-Pacific region to Australia and the important developmental role which the Asian Development Bank is playing in the region amply justify Australia's continuing support of the bank by taking up the 102,370 shares of the bank's general capital increase.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and present the associated explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 has come on this morning somewhat before its time. I understand that if we had followed the normal procedures of this place we would have been dealing with this bill at around half past 10 or a quarter to 11. One of the difficulties with this bill, as I have mentioned before, is that it has come before this parliament in a great rush. There has not been a proper opportunity for many members of the public to have regard to its implications.

PARA.TAB: When I was dealing with this matter yesterday the debate was interrupted at a quarter to one. I was indicating that we need to take a stand in the interests of both the public and the individuals who may have a well founded fear of persecution if they return to China. I had indicated certain things about making China a safe third country. I had also indicated that we have to do this despite some ignorance in the community.

This ignorance, unfortunately, is a well-meaning ignorance. It is based, again unfortunately, on some highly coloured misinformation and indeed comes from an ill-founded fear, as distinct from the well-founded fear of some refugees, that is engendered about a wave of yellow peril. This clearly is occurring in the community, and it causes me a great deal of concern. I have heard it, and other honourable senators would have heard it. It is most important that the government or anybody else not do or say anything that might inflame that ill-founded fear.

Let me refer to the points of the bills in the very short time I have left. Evidence to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee public hearing on the bill pointed to a major flaw in the scheme of subdivision AI of division 3 of part 2 of the Migration Act. That division provides for the making of regulations which prescribe a certain country as a safe third country for a prescribed class of persons. The subdivision further precludes any person affected by such a regulation from lodging an application for a protection visa. The major flaw is that that scheme does not provide adequate protection for an individual who may have a well-founded fear of persecution in relation to the so-called safe third country. This was emphasised by Mr Matthew Zagor of Amnesty International Australia when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Amnesty is unaware of the safe third country definition being applied to the very country where the alleged violations which are the grounds for a claim are occurring . . . This is a misuse of our legislation and it refuses to recognise legitimate concerns about the human rights situation in the People's Republic of China. The use of the safe third country legislation will exclude an entire group of people from making claims on any grounds. In other words, if you are a Vietnamese refugee who has settled in China, no matter what may have happened to you in China, you will be sent back . . . The government is deciding and implementing that decision in law that no Vietnamese are facing persecution of any kind whatsoever in the People's Republic of China.

We have to listen to these people who are concerned about human rights, which we all are of course. This flaw became very evident in the case of statutory rule No. 3 in the corresponding bill which names the People's Republic of China as a safe third country for Vietnamese nationals being settled. No witness before the committee was willing to deny the possibility that an individual Vietnamese national may well face persecution from the PRC authorities perhaps for his or her religious beliefs or political opinions. Again, no witness denied that the PRC has an appalling human rights record.

PARA.TAB: The bill also would deny proper refugee process to certain prescribed persons who are Chinese nationals and may never have previously left China but who may have a well-founded fear of persecution for convention reasons. This refers of course to the close relatives of the Vietnamese nationals. The only remedy provided in subdivision AI is for the minister to exercise his discretion in the public interest. I have dealt with the question of what `in the public interest' means.
Again, this was referred to in the evidence of Jean-Pierre Fonteyne, senior lecturer of the graduate international law program at ANU. Dr Fonteyne said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ministerial discretion is—we are told—not enforceable, not compellable, but more importantly in any case it is specified in the proposed legislation as one that is to be exercised in the `public interest'. Of whom? Of Australia. Not in the interest of the individual.

PARA.TAB: It is doubtful on the evidence that the PRC ought to be regarded as a safe third country. This concept properly does not apply when claims of persecutions are made in relation to the country of origin. In the case of former Vietnamese nationals settled in the PRC that have lodged claims in Australia for refugee status, their claims of persecution have been against PRC authorities, not the Vietnamese authorities. They are coming from China, not Vietnam. Let me say this: a number of these people have already been granted refugee status. They have already been granted protection visas. Surely, you are not saying that these people have had some power slip through the net. There must have been the procedures that have been adopted. They must have been found to have had a well-founded fear of persecution, not from Vietnam but from the country that they came from; that is, the PRC.

The bill is retrospective in effect. It will invalidate the applications of several persons from the PRC which have already been lodged and are being processed. The bill also provides for the retrospective application of any regulations made in regard to other safe third countries. The bill allows for applications lodged as long as six months before the passing of a regulation to be invalidated. All that is needed is for the minister to gazette a notice that he intends to make such a regulation. This will allow the minister effectively to freeze refugee applications from certain groups while an agreement to return them to a safe third country without processing of their refugee claim is sought.

It is discriminatory against Vietnamese nationals. The bill deals with fundamental matters of human rights. There has been insufficient time to canvass its full effects and full implications, as noted by Mr Kevin O'Connor, who is the acting Human Rights Commissioner. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what we are dealing with here is a fundamental human rights issue. It is one that obviously involves quite complex international law . . . It would help if there were increased efforts made at consultation—particularly by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department—in the conduct of these processes.

PARA.TAB: This morning we have had put on our desk a copy of the Alert Digest of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The appalling situation that we are faced with is that this measure has been attempted to be pushed through without proper investigation of its implications. I have not had an opportunity of looking at this but, in respect of retrospective application, the Alert Digest—

TALK.START.PARA: —It remains critical of the government.

—Yes, it does remain critical of the government. You have obviously read it, Senator Spindler, but I have not had a chance. I cannot do two things at once, and I can do only very poorly one thing at once. The Alert Digest reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee draws Senator's attention to the provision, as it may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, in breach of principle 1(a)(i) of the committee's terms of reference.

I read 1(a)(i) yesterday. The committee has expressed concerns about the non-reviewable decision, as this bill repeats the features of the earlier bill which were of concern. The committee draws attention to the provision, as it may be considered to make rights, liberties or obligations unduly dependent on non-reviewable decisions in breach of principle 1(a)(iii) of the committee's terms of reference. For the reasons that I have outlined, I am not supporting the second reading stage of this bill, and I oppose this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is a very important piece of legislation and will be welcomed by the community of Australia, particularly in my state of Western Australia. There is enormous concern in the community about the arrival of unauthorised individuals, people who do not go through the proper processes before they seek to come to this country. That concern reached its height over the Christmas-New Year period when the eighth and ninth boat arrived in a matter of two months.
—Mainly in the west.

—Particularly in the west, because that is where most of the people are held. People are concerned, but I echo the comments Senator Harradine just made that there are some in our society who are taking that concern to extremes and expressing extreme views about the arrival of people. I read in the generally distributed newspapers throughout this country suggestions from people that, instead of allowing these people to land and giving them the right to make application for refugee status in Australia, we should be sending out the navy boats and blowing these boats out of the water at the cost of the human lives that are on board. That is certainly not a position Australia should be following, nor do I believe that Australia should be apprehending these boat people as soon as they enter territorial waters and turning them around, as some other western developed countries have done.

PARA.TAB: Australia is a lucky and relatively wealthy country, and we can afford to give succour to some who are less fortunate than others. In giving that succour we have to control it. We are very proud of our record of settling some 13,000 people who will be settled here under the refugee and humanitarian category during this financial year. On a per capita basis, that is as much as any other refugee settlement country is doing. We do not need the additional pressures of individuals or groups of individuals, from wherever they come in the world, making the decision that they themselves will settle in Australia without going through our proper processes. Indeed, part of the concerns raised in the community is that these people who arrive unauthorised by boat in Australia are seen to be jumping the queue.

This piece of legislation is already misunderstood in the community. Part of the reason why it is misunderstood is that some of the people who have already spoken in this place do not seem to understand the impact of the bill. It has been said that we are making a general comment about human rights in China. Indeed, the bill is doing absolutely nothing of the sort. It is not making a general comment about human rights in China. It is dealing with a specific group of people who have received and enjoyed the sanctuary of the People's Republic of China for many years at great cost to the Chinese taxpayers and who have unilaterally decided that they no longer need that protection and are wanting to resettle in Australia. The bill relates only to the specific group of people in respect of whom all objective evidence supports the claim that they have enjoyed protection previously in China. It makes no judgment whatsoever about China's general human rights record. The issues are quite separate; they are not contradictory.

Further argument has been put in this chamber and outside that the Sino-Vietnamese people are fleeing China and therefore China is not a safe third country. That is a nonsense. You could draw analogies to prove how nonsensical the argument is. For example, take a person who has fled from my former homeland of Ireland, has settled in New Zealand, then fled to Australia and is now saying that they have been persecuted in New Zealand and making a claim against New Zealand. It is a nonsense argument. Analogies can be drawn to prove just how nonsensical the argument is.

The whole point of the safe third country agreement that Australia has entered into with China in relation to this specific group of people is based on the objective evidence that supports the argument that the people have received previous protection. In this case, the evidence of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees is overwhelming and it was overwhelming during Mr Pierre-Michel Fontaine's presentation to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. What Mr Fontaine is putting forward is accepted in other areas of the international community.

In November last year parliament passed a bill relating to the Vietnamese people who had fled Galang Island in Indonesia, came to Australia and attempted to claim refugee status here. They had previously applied for refugee status and had been refused and they were refused during review—they were not going to be allowed to apply for refugee status in Australia. Consequently, when the legislation was passed some of the people who had arrived here were sent back to Galang Island, it being a safe third country.

On 9 January this year, I went to Galang Island to find out what the situation was for myself in relation to those people. I was overjoyed to find that of the 102 people that Australia had sent back to Galang Island some 20 of the individuals concerned had taken the big decision for themselves to voluntarily return to Vietnam to start building their lives back in their home country and to stop languishing in a detention centre in Indonesia. But the news was even better than that. There were 60 others who had made application to be interviewed by the Vietnamese authorities with a view to their voluntary return to Vietnam. So out of the 102 people we had sent back, 80 people had made the decision to go back to Vietnam.

I think our decision to return those people to Galang Island certainly sent a strong message to the community in detention on Galang Island. So much so that the authorities over there are overwhelmed with applications for people to be interviewed to be assessed for voluntary return to Vietnam. The passage of this legislation in the parliament today will send a further message to peoples in our near region to show that Australia is not a soft touch for anybody who unilaterally determines to settle in Australia.

I also want to make a couple of comments about refugees. Senator Abetz referred to refugees who were detained in Port Hedland. Unfortunately, his comment shows his ignorance of the situation more than anything else. I can assure the Senate and the community of Australia that at this moment there are no refugees detained at Port Hedland. There are a number of people who have made application for refugee status in this country and have failed and they have failed on review and have now chosen to remain in detention while they pursue court cases against those earlier decisions.

There are some people in Port Hedland who are awaiting determination of applications for asylum in Australia. There are also some people there who at this moment have made application for refugee status in Australia. I think a view pervades in some sections of society that if individuals make application for refugee status they are automatically refugees. Of course that is not the case. It is not the case with boat people and it is certainly not the case in the general community.

The statistics relating to refugee applications throughout the whole of the system in Australia last year prove that point. There were some 8,293 applications for refugee status finalised at the primary stage. Part of that finalisation was the withdrawal, for one reason or another, of applications by 1,036 applicants. Of the remaining 7,257, 858 people, about 12 per cent, were granted refugee status and 6,399, or 88 per cent, were refused. Of the 2,268 review stage applications finalised in 1993-94, 586 were resolved before a decision was taken. Of the remaining 1,682, 242 applicants were granted refugee status and 1,440 applicants were refused refugee status. I think the figures are overwhelming and prove the point that refugee status is not automatic merely because a person makes an application.

Comment was also made that the minister and the department were ineffective in dealing with this problem, which had been flagged was on our horizon and was going to increase and become an even larger problem. The problem was not just in the making in 1994. We also had experiences back in 1991 and 1992 with people coming from the People's Republic of China by boat to Australia. The government at that time did react and did act. The Secretary to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs went to China to discuss the problem with Chinese authorities. They were effective discussions because during 1993 the first boat of unauthorised arrivals to land in Australia from China did not arrive until the back end of 1993.

There were some rumours circulating in Australia in the middle of last year that 20,000 people from the Beihai region of China would seek to come to Australia by boat. Fortunately, the rumours could not be believed because of their source. The rumours so far have proved to be unfounded. That is not to say that we did not have some problems. Between 13 November 1994 and 18 January this year, some nine boats arrived from the People's Republic of China, carrying 760 people in total. That is a very large number by any stretch of the imagination, but it is a long way from the 20,000 that were rumoured to be coming early last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am anxious, of course, to get passage of this bill today. There are many other things I could say with regard to the content of the bill and about the public debate that has taken place around this problem, but I will not labour the Senate.

PARA.TAB: In concluding my contribution, I compliment the opposition on the decision taken in its party room in regard to another bill. I am very pleased to see that the opposition is reacting to the community concerns that have been expressed, and expressed very forcibly, about their rejection last year of the bill which would have blocked unauthorised or illegal arrivals in this country seeking compensation against the taxpayers of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 needs to be looked at in context. It fits in with a group of bills which have been brought forward to deal with the problem of refugees, or people claiming to be refugees, coming to our shores from South-East Asia, mainly China. This particular bill reacts to the recent arrival of a group of people from the south of China, from an area called Beihai.

PARA.TAB: I was on the Senate standing committee dealing with legal and constitutional affairs which investigated this bill and took evidence on it. The evidence the committee heard was that these people had fled that region and come to Australia seeking refugee status because their housing had been destroyed by local authorities. This problem has been around for a long time. It has been around since 1978.

It is no credit to the government that we have had to deal with this matter in a piecemeal fashion. In fact, you have a series of bills which have been put forward over a period and which have dealt with these problems on an ad hoc basis. I endorse Senator Abetz's remarks that a long-term solution is what we should be looking at. We should not just look at a problem when it arises and then bring in another bill to fix it. That has really been the form to date of this government in relation to dealing with this problem. Nonetheless, the coalition has indicated its support for this bill, and I would put to the Senate that I do support it with some trepidation.

I do have two concerns in relation to this bill, and I will deal with them shortly. Suffice it to say that when this problem arose Australia participated with other countries in the region. We have the comprehensive plan of action, which was brought about with participation from the United Nations, that dealt with this problem of the boat people, as they are commonly known. In this instance, the bill designates China as a safe third country.

This notion of a safe third country came about as a result of that comprehensive plan of action. What it sought to do was to stop forum shopping; that is, if a person flees from, say, Vietnam and goes to another country and applies for refugee status there and is refused, that person cannot then go on to Australia and have a second bite at the apple. That is really what it is all about because this safe third country principle stops forum shopping.

There was some evidence given in relation to whether or not China should be a safe third country. Mr Fontaine, who is the regional representative for Australia, New Zealand and the South Pacific for the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, stated that the UNHCR's official position has been to support the Australian government's negotiations with China and the way it deals with the problem of refugees and asylum seekers.

Mr Fontaine stated that his staff went periodically to missions in China to monitor the implementation of projects which are financed by the United Nations there. There was not any evidence given by Mr Fontaine which would indicate that China should not be a safe third country. However, there are some misgivings, of course, about China's human rights record. I do not view this as an endorsement of some of the actions of the Chinese government in that country.

The more pressing points really are to do with the minister's discretion. What this bill says is that, if you are a Vietnamese national and you flee from Vietnam to China, you cannot then just come to Australia and expect to be accepted automatically as a refugee. You have had your chance in China. China is a safe third country, and there is evidence to suggest that Vietnamese nationals have been looked after in China. There certainly was not any evidence before the Senate committee to indicate to the contrary.

As soon as the person arrives in China, the presumption is against them achieving the status of a refugee. However, there is a discretion with the minister to overturn that in the public interest, where it can be shown. I believe that discretion is important because it allows for there to be exceptions to the rule. Not every person—say, a Vietnamese national who comes in a group of people from China—will necessarily have the same circumstances; there will be some genuine refugees in that group of people. They must be looked after, and Australia has a very good record for looking after refugees. But, really, we must sort out the genuine refugees from those who really do not fit the bill, and this discretion allows the minister to make an exception to the rule.

The problem I have with this, however, is that the discretion is a non-compellable discretion; that is, you cannot force the minister to exercise his discretion. The second problem is that the person arriving in the country does not really have the means to access that discretion. It is not clear in the bill. The Senate committee raised this point in its report, as certainly did the Scrutiny of Bills Committee: it is no use offering some avenue of action, some remedy to someone but not telling them about it; what you have here is the propensity for a refugee to arrive in Australia and not know that there is this avenue of action available to him or her. I call upon the minister to clarify the exercise of this discretion as to how it can be accessed by someone arriving on our shores. I think that is an important aspect.

The other aspect which was of some concern was the retrospective effect of the bill—and, again, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee did raise this point. Firstly, the legislation is backdated to 30 December, when the minister issued a press release on this matter. Here we have what is popularly known as `legislation by press release'; that is, the minister issues a press release and you subsequently have legislation introduced which is backdated to the date of the press release.

As a principle I oppose that. However, in this case the legislation was introduced hard on the heels of the press release. So, if one were to look upon it on a scale of offending the principle, it would be at the low end of the scale. Nonetheless, I make the point now—and I intend to make it every time it arises in the future: legislation by press release is not a desirable principle. But, in this case, it is at the low end on the scale of offending. I think really that is not so much the issue as the other aspect of retrospectivity, where the minister in the future can gazette a country as a third safe country but the regulation does not have to be made for another six months. That regulation has to be made within a period of six months of the gazettal.

The nub of this problem is this: you have full force and effect at the date of the gazettal but no review by parliament. That is, you have a lacuna, a vacuum, if you like, for up to six months before the regulation is made. So the minister says, `That's a safe third country'—say, Indonesia is a safe third country—it is gazetted, but the regulation does not come in for a period of up to six months after that. That means for that period there is no review by the parliament.

It could be that a minister makes a controversial decision and says that a country with a bad human rights record is a safe third country. Clearly, the people of Australia would reject that—and so, hopefully, would this chamber. But, of course, the review of that regulation would not take place for up to six months after the gazettal of the determination of a safe third country. That is a point I would make.

I really did not see the need for that to happen, and I do not see how pressing the need is for that to be in the legislation. I believe that it robs the Senate of the opportunity to review that regulation.

It is terribly important, when regulations are made, that they be reviewed by the parliament. Regulations govern, more so than the legislation pursuant to which they are made, the lives of Australians in a very direct manner. Government—without debate, without having legislation aired in public and without having the scrutiny of the press or this chamber—can bring in some rather sweeping measures by regulation. That is why we have the disallowance aspect of regulations, whereby this Senate can disallow a regulation and give it the scrutiny it deserves.

I wanted to place those concerns on record. I really do have some mixed feelings about this bill. I think those two aspects need to be looked at; they cause me concern. I will be watching closely the implementation of this bill, because there are aspects of it which could go off the rails.

Nonetheless, we have a very difficult problem before us; we have to balance Australia's interests with the interests of those people who seek to gain asylum in this country. We have to balance human rights with pragmatism, and that is always the most difficult of tasks. It is as difficult as trying to estimate how many angels can dance on the head of a pin. That is the problem we have. That is the task this chamber has; that is the task we as legislators have before us, and we cannot shirk it.

I think this bill is addressing a problem which should have been addressed years ago. It has been around since 1978. I believe that it would have been much more desirable to have approached this whole issue of refugees and boat people with one compendious piece of legislation, not piecemeal with the different bills that we have had. We have the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) to come. I must say that I have greater concerns with that bill than this bill. Nonetheless, the coalition supports this bill and, despite the concerns that I have about it, I join in that support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Ellison, I have some concerns about the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. But we in the coalition have taken the view that, for the good administration of Australia's migration laws, there is a need to send a clear signal to stop people coming willy-nilly to these shores and gaining access to Australia.

PARA.TAB: The important point to make is that every person who comes to Australia places an administrative burden on the Commonwealth. When people do not have a right to stay in this country, they place an unfair and undue administrative burden on the Commonwealth. They also hold up applications from people who do have a right to come to this nation. There is a major issue here of principle, and I think we have to look at the matter—not just now, but in the future—to closely monitor what happens.

I declare a personal interest in this. My family ultimately ended up in this country as a result of the civil war in China. For all intents and purposes, we were refugees at that time. My family has not necessarily received the best treatment in the past from the authorities in what is now the People's Republic of China. But that is the past. I do not intend to go into it, and I do not think it is terribly helpful for today's debate to dwell on it, nor do I think it is terribly helpful for the future to dwell on issues like that. But they are issues of principle that must be borne in mind. In light of those experiences, I am always concerned to ensure that people who come to these shores and have a proper ground to claim to be refugees are dealt with fairly.

I know that there are lot of people in the People's Republic of China who may well feel that they have a good case. We have to judge that for ourselves. This country's migration laws must be written by Australians for the benefit of Australia. That does not mean, in any way, that we in this country should turn our backs on the pleas and cases of genuine refugees because that is part of Australia's humanitarian commitment to the rest of the world.

I know many people who have come to Australia on boats who have been admitted to this country as refugees and who are now very proud Australian citizens. Senator Short knows, as I do, many people in Brisbane who have made massive contributions to this country. One gentleman, whom I shall not name, is now one of the biggest builders in Brisbane. He came to this country as a boat person and was given refugee status. He worked incredibly hard at two jobs to make enough money to go into business for himself. He became a registered builder and is now a very successful builder employing a lot of other Australians.

I think we should always remember too, when we deal with refugee issues, the contribution that those people have to make. Many of them are incredibly motivated. They know that they have nowhere else to go and that this is the country to which they are making a commitment. That commitment is sometimes superb.

I share Senator Ellison's concern about the ability of refugee claimants to access ministerial discretion. I think that is something that needs to be closely looked at. Anything the government or the department can do to make clear how that would work would be gratefully appreciated. Since the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) is in the chamber, I ask him to bear that in mind because it was one of the concerns expressed at the committees hearings.

We are not opposing this bill. I am not opposing this bill. I support the coalition's position 100 per cent, but I think it is important that we bear in mind that there are a number of views about this in the Australian community. I represent the view of a large number of people who are of ethnic Chinese or Vietnamese origin who are concerned to see the fair and proper treatment of refugees. We are giving the government the benefit of the doubt. We are trusting it on this issue, but I am sure it will be closely monitored. I know Senator McKiernan has strong views in the other direction and I respect his views. I bring to the attention of the chamber that there is a plurality of views on the whole issue and it is a hallmark of a mature, democratic society that all of those views are taken into consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the spirit of Senator O'Chee's contribution, I will make a couple of points about the position I come from. It is not just people from Asia who actually come by boat in refugee circumstances. I do not have to go back all that far in my family history to recognise that my grandparents came here as refugees from Greece through the Middle East with British passports. Some 80 years ago Australia was very keen to establish itself as a country which accepted refugees and would accommodate them when they arrived. I too, Senator O'Chee, come to this particular debate knowing that I would not have been here if Australia's doors were not open and the refugee processes were not available to my grandparents 70 or 80 years ago.

PARA.TAB: I also come to this debate knowing that this is a particular problem facing all western democracies. It is not an easy one. It is not an easy one not only because of the humanitarian problem facing the world but also because of the processes necessary to be able to distinguish between those who warrant and necessitate assistance and those who do not. I think all sides of the chamber start from the same starting point that we need to have internationally accepted criteria on which to make assessments of who is and who is not a refugee. You also need to have processes to ensure that those criteria operate fairly as well as processes to ensure the quick return of those who do not necessitate support.

We have come a long way in this country in terms of those criteria. Yesterday I mentioned a letter from the RCOA and said I would incorporate it in Hansard. I did not do so yesterday but I seek leave to do so today.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Refugee Council of Australia
22nd November, 1994
The Editor
Sydney Morning Herald
Dear Sir,
"Don't be duped by ridiculous media portrayals" said a Pooh-like Downer to his colleagues in Moir's cartoon (Herald 22 November).
Such advice is even more apt for readers of the adjacent article by Padraic McGuiness: "Boat People and the Law".
Readers would be forgiven for thinking that he has followed recent developments in this sensitive area. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The picture he paints is a distorted and anachronistic situation, far removed from current reality. Driven by bias and misinformation, he ignores both the complexity of the situation and the major developments that have taken place in the last two years.

It is true to say that there were major problems with the Department of Immigration's handling of refugee status determination two years ago but not so today. To call them "Policeman Plods" and accuse them of "insensitivity to the issues" is ignoring the major and hard won advances that have taken place.
Determination procedures have been made fairer and more rigorous and major advances have been made in the area of access to welfare and medical assistance.

To accuse the advocates of using "propaganda" and "blackmail" is equally offensive and similarly removed from reality. Refugee advocates use the legal process that exists to ensure that the law is upheld and the rights of their clients are preserved. Two years ago this brought them into regular conflict with the government, but here too things have changed because there is widespread recognition amongst advocates that things are changing for the better.

If Paddy wishes to preach, let him at least get his facts straight. No one wins from his biased piece. Not the bureaucrats who are striving to make things better, not the advocates whose pressure have helped to make these changes happen, not the asylum seekers whose lives depend on the efficiency of the system and certainly, not the public who are being "duped by this ridiculous media portrayal".
Yours Sincerely,
Margaret Piper Executive Director.

TALK.START.PARA: —That letter acknowledges that developments in this country have moved a long way over the last couple of years in terms of the legislation, the processes and the cooperation between people and the department and the support groups that represent people seeking asylum status.

PARA.TAB: It is a difficult problem for all countries, and which countries spend billions of dollars on. The OECD countries spend tens of billions of dollars on processing and trying to work out who is and who is not a refugee. Australia has met its part of the overall international responsibility. Sometimes people complain about us spending too much on the processes, but an unavoidable aspect of having a migration program and a defensible refugee humanitarian program is having a process that identifies those who should and those who should not get assistance.

We work internationally by meeting our obligations here. In this respect we have had advice on this legislation that it fits very squarely within our international obligations. We also work internationally with other countries—not just in our region but throughout the world—to set up mechanisms and regional processes to handle problems like this through the comprehensive plan of action, through regional consultations on illegal movements and through our very close cooperation with the UNHCR in Geneva and elsewhere to take refugees.

When people address this area they should acknowledge—and it is not something only one side of parliament should be proud of; it is something the whole parliament should be proud of—that Australia has a very strong record in taking numbers of refugees into this country. We take more refugees per capita than any other country in the world and we also give assistance. The letter from Margaret Piper acknowledges that assistance has been enhanced:

SPEECH.PARA: Determination procedures have been made fairer and more rigorous and major advances have been made in the area of access to welfare and medical services.

So we should not decry our record or the fact that we approach this area in a non-racially discriminate way. I know there have been some suggestions of that. Angela Chan, someone I know very well from the New South Wales Ethnic Communities Council, said that this legislation had a hint of back to White Australia. Comments like that do not help the debate or public awareness of the situation. It is a comment that is sensationalist and born out of ignorance. You cannot say this legislation invokes white Australia at a time when we have a non-discriminatory immigration policy, when Vietnam is our fourth major source of migrants, when the government only a few weeks ago set up an office in the southern part of Vietnam to enhance people's access to the migration process here, and when we take into Australia at least 1,000 bona fide refugees of Vietnamese ethnicity and background who are in camps in the region. The government has announced that if we can take more, up to 1,300, we will be able to do so in this financial year.

PARA.TAB: A comment that we are returning to white Australia is ignorant and self-defeating and does no credit to the person who made it. I have said that to her direct and we have agreed to disagree on this. The public should be aware of the fact that the processes and intakes here all prove that the suggestion that we are returning to a White Australia policy is fallacious and ignoran

We need to be aware of comments like this. We also need to recognise in that context the great record Australia has had in this area. As I said earlier, we all need an internationally acceptable benchmark. Governments here have continually applied that benchmark for the last 50 years or so under the refugee convention.

We also need to acknowledge that international jurisprudence moves on. Senator Ellison said, for instance, that this has been a problem since 1978. The solution we are tackling the problem with now was not around in 1978. This concept has only been around for the last couple of years. To that extent, only two years ago when I went to Europe I had an opportunity to scrutinise the safe third country concept and to discuss it with the UNHCR and others in both Geneva and elsewhere. It can be said that Australia has moved as quickly as is practically and desirably possible to introduce this concept into our legislation.

Some comments have been made about the fact that we are introducing this legislation today with haste. This legislation does nothing more than extend legislation passed last year to another group of people and give retrospective effect to it. The process has now been through this parliament twice. The legislation in substance has been here before. For that reason, we think the Senate is well-equipped to make an assessment of it.

It allows for speed, which is necessary in these circumstances. Speed is something that the other side of the parliament has demanded of the process. It only allows for speed while giving flexibility, though acknowledging discretion. Speed is important, but we also need a safety valve. In terms of that safety valve, people who will be coming under this category will be interviewed and will have statements taken. Interpreters will be used. Those statements will go to the central office of the immigration department for further scrutiny and an objective, detached assessment of them. Any statement that in any way hints of refugee grounds will then be raised for consideration. That aspect of it is an important part of this issue. We are not in the business of sending anyone back to a situation of danger or persecution.

What we are talking about has been acknowledged by both sides of the parliament. Those who normally invoke the UNHCR have chosen not to this time. We recognise that these people have been on the move for 16 years. An amount of $1 billion has been spent on their support in the southern part of China. Not only have our officers been going to the southern part of China; we have also received advice from the UNHCR about the conditions there. It is for that reason—I am sure that Senator Short would adopt this position—that we have been able to scrutinise closely what we are doing and accept that it is in the spirit of acceptable international obligations to do so.

I am sure that the opposition has not come to this position of supporting the government with open arms gleefully. It has thought it through very strongly, as we have. We acknowledge that it has gone through the process as laboriously as we have. It has come to the only conclusion that is available to Australia.

As I have said, a lot of money has been spent, and we do have that advice. Some people have said that we have had a lot of notice about these people coming in and that we have known for a year or so. Let us go back to see how we would have known for a year or so. The only statement that one could pin that allegation to is a comment I made at the regional consultations on the illegal movements of people about April a year or so ago, where I warned that, unless we handle the problem properly, we will be triggering off mass movements of people. There was no warning or evidence of anybody moving from China. But it is fair to say that, unless we have processes for handling illegal movements of people, the trigger effect would operate very strongly. In fairness, if people go back to the debate, they will see what has now been termed the government being on notice for 12 months or so.

I appreciate the cooperation that we have had so far this morning. I hope that it continues. It is important to get this legislation through both this chamber and the House of Representatives today. Otherwise we will be in limbo and it will be extremely difficult to proceed in a difficult situation. I say once again that I appreciate the cooperation received so far.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have moved to the committee stage, I draw the attention of the Senate to the report that was on everybody's table this morning—a report from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. That report contains some of the answers that the minister provided to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee following the initial expressions of concern by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

PARA.TAB: The areas that the committee draws the Senate's attention to are the ones that have been canvassed by Senator Harradine, Senator Chamarette and me during the second reading debate. The first one is the retrospective application of this particular legislation. The committee states:

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, the retrospective application of the proposed bill takes away the present rights of this class of asylum seekers under the current law of Australia.
The committee continues:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The committee draws Senators' attention to the provision, as it may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, in breach of principle 1(a)(i) of the committee's terms of reference.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that that is a message from a Senate committee on which both the coalition and the government are represented that should be taken notice of by the Senate. There are two other areas to which the bill draws attention, and I will come to them immediately. When this Alert Digest appeared on our desks this morning, showing that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, while noting the minister's responses, was still critical of a very substantial part of the bill, I approached Senator Short, the spokesman for the coalition, and suggested to him that, in view of these weighty criticisms of the bill by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, the committee stage of this bill should be deferred. But Senator Short advised me that he was not disposed to do that. This should be on the record.

PARA.TAB: The scrutiny of bills committee has six members, and only one of those six members belongs to the Australian Democrats. The other members of the committee, who are respected senators of this chamber, include Senator Troeth, the chairman; Senator Michael Forshaw, the deputy chairman; Senator Mal Colston, whose work on the committee is well known; Senator Barney Cooney, the Chairman of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee; and Senator Chris Ellison, the Chairman of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee. As I said, they are senators of considerable achievement and very good standing in this chamber. They belong to the two parties that are now rushing this bill through the chamber before we can discuss and evaluate this report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. That exposes the utter shabbiness of this process, and I refer to both the substance of the bill and the procedure that was used.

The chamber has been engaged in the final stage of this bill only to find on this very day the minister saying this morning that we should pass this bill forthwith because it needs to be taken to the House of Representatives today. Yet today we have received the Alert Digest asking senators to be aware of the weighty problems that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has found with this bill.

Let me continue with the other areas to which the bill has drawn attention. It draws attention to the minister's non-compellable discretion. We are told that is the safeguard for individual refugees that may have a case before we send a whole boat load—holus bolus—back to China. That is supposed to be the safeguard. But, as the committee points out quite correctly, this is a non-reviewable decision. First of all, it is a non-compellable task for the minister. He need not do it; he need not even consider it. But, if the minister chooses to consider it—somehow I do not know how we would know whether he should consider it, by osmosis I suppose—then his decision is not reviewable. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee says in the Alert Digest:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the committee thanked the Minister for this response—
The minister explained that it was an adequate safeguard—

but continued to draw Senators' attention to the provision, as it may be considered to make rights, liberties or obligations unduly dependent on non-reviewable decisions, in breach of principle 1(a)(iii) of the Committee's terms of reference.

The third item that the scrutiny of bills committee draws to the Senate's attention is insufficient parliamentary scrutiny. It draws attention to the fact that the bill provides the minister with the power to draw up legislation in the future which will have a retrospective effect. There is a lapse of six months for the minister to make certain regulation by issuing a notice in the Gazette in respect of a country that is now not a safe third country but declaring it as such. Senator Ellison has drawn attention to the fact that we are giving the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) the power to fix this nation with retrospective legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Scrutiny of Bills Committee is one of the most critical committees of this chamber. It is one of the committees charged with a duty to watch over legislation and to ensure that legislation does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. That is its first term of reference. Its third term of reference, which is relevant here, reports on whether legislation makes such rights, liberties or obligations unduly dependent upon non-reviewable decisions. That is very important in view of this current issue of the minister's non-compellable discretion. Finally, its fifth term of reference relates to whether legislation insufficiently subjects the exercise of legislative power to parliamentary scrutiny.

One major issue which needs to be on the record is that the government, aided and abetted by the coalition, has today ignored the concerns which remain after the minister has provided an explanation to the committee. The government is prepared to ignore them and to push the bill through.

I wish to briefly advert to two other items and then ask the minister a question. As we detailed during the second reading debate, it is nonsensical to say that China can be a third safe country for refugees who are actually fleeing China. China is their country of habitual residence. One could almost say, after the number of years they have spent there, that it is their country of origin, although they originally fled from Vietnam, not China. The other aspect that relates to declaring China a third safe country is obviously China's appalling human rights record. Tiananmen Square is only one example of that. But we have the Australian government and the coalition—under its new leader, Mr John Howard—declaring China a safe third country.

The other point that needs to be made again is that we are dealing with refugees from Vietnam and China and this legislation is very specifically directed against these people. A number of witnesses before the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee have pointed out that this is clear discrimination against people from these countries, against Asian people. It is somewhat surprising—and it needs to be pointed out—that this discrimination is supported by the Liberal Party under the leadership of Mr John Howard, who only a few days ago offered an apology to those communities about earlier remarks which indicated a wish to discriminate against them.

I know that all these statements will not stop the juggernaut and that this bill, with the help of the coalition, will be passed today and belted through the lower house. But these things need to be put on the record. This is a day of shame for Australia when our parliament passes legislation of this type. The parliament and the nation will rue the day this bill is passed by the nation's parliament.

I would like the minister to address the question of the process that will be made available for that glorious safeguard that is being offered, which I would say is little more than a token gesture. Would the minister please outline what the procedure is for an asylum seeker who steps ashore from a boat or a plane, or swims ashore, and appears on Australian soil and is given a brief identification interview? How does that person know that the one hope he or she has got is the minister exercising a discretion? What legal assistance would be offered that person so that he or she can access that avenue of redress? What is the process? Who decides that that particular case should be brought to the minister's notice? I would appreciate some indication from the minister as to how this safeguard, which is not worth its name at the moment, could be made effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, as the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) is aware, want a specific answer to this point that Senator Spindler has raised. I foreshadowed that in my speech in the second reading debate yesterday and I have told him on other occasions. I look forward to that answer with interest. But I do want to take issue with a couple of points that Senator Spindler has made in attacking me and the coalition for not supporting him in wishing to defer consideration at the committee stage because of the just receipt of the extract from the Alert Digest No. 2 1995. It was tabled yesterday, not this morning. It has been with you since then.

PARA.TAB: But much more significantly, and I must say I am surprised at how ill-informed Senator Spindler appears to be in terms of the processes and the information available in this parliament, everything that is contained in the Alert Digest of yesterday, including the minister's response, has been available to Senator Spindler and to all of us in the Senate since 16 October 1994 when all of it was contained in the 17th report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. So you have had all this information for almost three months. The fact that you have not apparently been able to catch up with it I think speaks volumes, if I may say so, of your lack of attention to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document that senators found this morning in the chamber is Alert Digest No. 2 of 1995 and it is dated 8 February 1995, which is yesterday's date. I was well aware, as Senator Short must have known, of what has been published by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee on an earlier date. The point I am making is that this document is on the desk of every senator in this chamber today, and it is important that senators in this chamber are informed of the minister's explanation and the fact that the committee, in a statement dated yesterday, 8 February, does not accept the minister's explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important for this chamber to have regard to the views—I acknowledge they are reasserted views—which are contained in the Alert Digest No. 2 of 1995 that we have all received today. This Alert Digest deals specifically with the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) that is before us. By reasserting quite firmly what it asserted in the 17th report of 16 November 1994, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee surely is asking us doubly to consider what we are bound to consider, I believe, as a Senate; that is, whether this legislation trespasses unduly on personal rights and liberty.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to delay the Senate in canvassing those matters. I know and Senator Spindler knows that, no matter what we say, this bill is going to go through this chamber today and it is going to be rammed through the House of Representatives, a bit like most of these pieces of legislation.
Unfortunately, some members particularly—I hesitate to say it, but I dare say some senators—see the words `Migration Legislation

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment Bill' and do not think about the issue of refugees. They do not think this is a matter which is dealing with persons who may have a well-founded fear of persecution on their return. The bland title—this also goes for the title of the next bill—of Migration Legislation Amendment Bill puts some people to sleep, yet within this particular bill lies a provision which may indeed condemn an individual to persecution for life on return to the PRC.

PARA.TAB: Going to the specific point that was made by Senator Spindler and reinforced by Senator Short about the non-reviewable nature of the minister's discretion and about the minister's discretion itself, I think in this chamber we ought to know what procedures have been or will be put in place to ensure that the claims to refugee status of those who might slip through the net—I think that was the term being constantly raised in the committee—are brought to the attention of the minister.

I draw the attention of the minister to what the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee said about this. I made dissent to that committee's report, as did Senator Spindler, but we, and everybody else on the committee, were concerned about the issue we are just raising. I refer to page 13 of the committee report, which states:

In relation to the PRC as an STC the existence of an effective safeguard to ensure that individuals with genuine claims for refugee status have a facility to ensure that those claims are determined in accordance with law is of great concern to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Without any further ado—I am sure Senator Short and Senator Spindler would like this also—I really would like clarification of this matter to see what procedures are set in train or are to be set in train.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will go to that question, but I will also comment on the little discussion between Senator Short and Senator Spindler. I know Senator Spindler very well and I know him to be a quite intelligent person. For him not to realise that the document before him this morning is identical to the one he got last October stretches—
—Did you introduce the bill last October, Minister?

—Look, Senator Spindler, what I am saying and what Senator Short is saying is that this bill basically invokes legislation that was passed in October. The substance of that legislation was assessed by the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee in October. It is assessed here now. It does not suit your character or reputation in this place if you are playing politics on this matter, but let me suggest to you that that is precisely what you are doing. You know full well what you are doing. You have been through this before and I really think it does not do you any credit to be taking this particular line this morning.Let us just take the point that Senator Short made. We have lived with this legislation for a number of months now. Senator Spindler knows that. I do not need to draw the point, Senator Spindler, but I am sure you know what I am saying to you.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the process, let me also say, as I said in respect to the bill as a whole, that we do not come to this legislation lightly, nor do we come to it without taking enormous care to ensure that what we are doing takes into account our international obligations and protects us from sending anyone back who, in fact, would be in danger. To that extent, the process is important. I think the three senators who spoke mentioned the importance of it.

Let me also say that the process has been discussed in the committee hearings and officials were asked about what process is in place.
