I think the senators involved in this discussion do have some foreknowledge of the sorts of processes that we are talking about. The process that we are talking about is the establishment. In fact, there are careful mechanisms in place to ensure that any deserving case will be brought to my attention. As I said, this issue was explained during the committee hearing. The mechanisms are designed to ensure that any persons raising serious protection claims are not refouled as required by our international obligations under article 33 of the convention.

In essence, the process will be that all unauthorised arrivals are interviewed. They will be interviewed carefully by officers of my department and they will be asked for information about who they are, where they come from and why they have come to Australia. That is a broad definition of the three areas of questioning. It should also be acknowledged that interpreters will be used as necessary and, of course, they probably will be necessary in most circumstances. If such an arrivee is covered by the safe third country provisions, of course, they cannot apply for a visa unless the minister's non-compellable discretion is exercised.

The information that is provided at these interviews will be carefully assessed. It will be examined by senior officers of the department in Canberra, and it should be recognised that by doing so we are actually having people removed from the interview process making the assessment. An important aspect of that is to ensure objectivity. If there are reasons presented that make my intervention desirable, the case will be brought to my attention and I will consider it.

I believe it is an important safeguard, Senator Spindler. It does allow us to look at those hard cases, and it does also balance, I think, the competing necessities in this area. It is a necessity to have a quick process, but a necessity to have a process that does throw up any serious issues of persecution under the convention. That mechanism is one that is, I think, the best available to government. It ensures that issues will be brought up, but it also ensures what is necessary and what everyone has demanded of the process. Everyone has demanded of the process that we have a quick process, particularly when you are talking about a safe third country provision such as this one. I think the government has allowed the only safeguard that is available to any administration in such an area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Minister, I was distracted. I could not hear whether you said that the arrivee will actually be informed of that possibility by the officer that is interviewing him or her.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the arrivees will be interviewed. They will be interviewed, as I said, in those three broad areas of who they are, why they came here and where they came from. If there are issues of serious refugee relevance in the context of that interview, then those issues will be assessed, not just at the level of interviewer but also by senior officers in the department in Canberra and then by me when the issues are brought to my attention.
—With respect, that was not my question, Minister. My question was whether every person who is being interviewed will be informed of that avenue of redress.
—I think, in answering your question the most recent time, I said no. I then went on to explain how the interview would take place.

—I believe that is not a satisfactory safeguard; if the person to whom the safeguard is offered does not even know about it, clearly, they cannot access it. I think the safeguard has been exposed for the sham I believed it to be all along.

PARA.TAB: On the matter of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee dealing with this issue, the bill was introduced on 31 January 1995. Clearly, the committee could not have addressed the bill in October as Senator Short claimed, or November as the minister mentioned. One of the three issues, the non-reviewable discretion of the minister's, was canvassed by the committee in relation to migration bill No. 4. So that was an issue on the table, but clearly it was not dealt with by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was. Read page 7 of yesterday's report; it tells you that it was.

—I wonder how Senator Short can explain the fact that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee can discuss a bill in October, when the bill has not been drafted until the post-Christmas period and has not been introduced into parliament until 31 January. As I said, one of the three issues was canvassed by the committee in relation to migration bill No. 4: the non-reviewable discretion of the minister's.

PARA.TAB: Then there are the other two items. The second issue, the retrospective operation of this very bill, which is drafted specifically in relation to the provisions of this bill, by definition, could not have been dealt with earlier—and I cannot even understand why that is a point of argument. Nor is the third and final one, the insufficient parliamentary scrutiny heading, which queries the provisions which give the minister a licence to introduce retrospective legislation, in line with the comments made by Senator Ellison. That, by definition, also refers specifically to the provisions of this bill. Therefore, it cannot have been dealt with any earlier than after 31 January 1995.

I do not have the date on which the committee first met to discuss it, but we do know that the committee, after having examined the minister's responses, has provided this final statement which was tabled yesterday at 4 o'clock in the afternoon and is dated 8 February 1995. Two of the three issues at least cannot, by definition, have been canvassed any earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister's mechanisms, as outlined, appear not to be sufficient to prevent refoulment—and this is a matter of very great concern. It was a matter of concern to those who took the trouble to give written evidence to the committee.

PARA.TAB: Of course, one of the difficulties which members of a committee face is finding sufficient time both to go through the written material and to listen to the personal presentations. We did have personal presentations given to us on Friday of last week. But I have had the opportunity to go through the written material, and there are some questions I would like to ask about this particular matter.

Amnesty International—which is interested in preserving and upholding human rights, as we all are—indicated in appendix 2 of its submission that it sees four principles of specific practical measures which are necessary for the effective implementation of the international standards. They include the following:

SPEECH.PARA: 1 The fundamental principle of non-refoulement demands that national asylum procedures are adequate to effectively identify all those in need of protection.
2 All asylum seekers, in whatever manner they arrive within the jurisdiction of a state, must be referred to the body responsible for deciding on claims for asylum.
3The body responsible for deciding on claims for asylum must be an independent and specialised authority whose sole and exclusive responsibility is examining and making decisions on asylum claims.

4 The decision makers of that independent body must have expertise in the international refugee law and international human rights law. Their status and tenure should afford the strongest possible guarantees of their competence, impartiality and independence.

My view is that this legislation offends against each one of those principles which were outlined by Amnesty. I ask the minister to address his mind to the provision relating to the STC—the safe third country—China being a safe third country.

PARA.TAB: Minister, leaving aside the group determination for refusing protection visas that you have proposed under this legislation—incidentally, there is no group determination for accepting a person's protection visa—are you certain that this measure that is currently before us will not deny to a person who has a well-founded fear of persecution if returned to China, a person who has never left China—in other words, a person who was not a refugee because of the border war in 1978—a right to seek a protection visa and to lawful proceedings which operate to protect persons from being forcibly sent back to China as a result of their well-founded fear of persecution?

TALK.START.PARA: —My very clear advice is yes, I can give that assurance.

—Minister, I draw to your attention the provisions of the regulation of 27 January which this bill seeks to make retrospective. Regulation 2.12A, which mentions the safe third country and prescribed connection, states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)For the purposes of paragraphs 91D(1)(a) and (b) of the Act:
(a)PRC is a safe third country in relation to a person who is,

PARA.TAB: or has been, a Vietnamese refugee settled in PRC, or a person
who is a close relative of, or is dependent on, a person who is,
or has been, a Vietnamese refugee settled in the PRC—

SPEECH.PARA: Leaving aside the dependent children, there may be, for example, a close relative—and what is defined as `a close relative'—of one of those persons who has arrived in Australia with the particular group who has never left China but who has a very grave concern that, if she is returned to China, she might well face persecution for a convention related matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I can say to Senator Harradine is that, in terms of your first question, the answer still stands because the evidence before the committee and from the UNHCR and the Hong Kong authorities has made it clear that the people you are concerned about have been receiving protection in China. That is precisely why we are moving down the road with this legislation to adopt the safe third country concept. The clear evidence is that they are not in fear of persecution. That evidence is from bodies like the UNHCR and the Hong Kong administration.

—The minister has misunderstood. I will try to make it clear by way of an example. At this time I am not talking about people who were made refugees as a result of the border war and were given `protection' in China. I am talking about an adult who may be a close relative of one of those persons and who has never left China. It may well be that the close relative concerned may be the spouse of one of the people you are talking about. That spouse may have a well founded fear of persecution on convention related grounds. Does this measure cover that person or does it not? If it does not, what is meant by `close relative'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, if you look at the evidence from the UNHCR, the very clear advice is that relatives are also not being subject to persecution in China. The advice still stands. We are not talking about people who have been subject to persecution. Whether we are talking about the subject group or the relatives, the advice has been very clear that they do not suffer persecution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is now saying that they do not suffer persecution. How do you know?

—If I was sitting here making that assessment, you could make that criticism, but the very clear advice from the UNHCR and the Hong Kong authorities is that you should not be concerned about these people because they receive protection.
—Even the UNHCR advice does not go to the person I was just speaking about.
—I said it does.

—History will show that you are wrong. I have read and listened to everything on this, and it was clear by yesterday's debate that you had not. Nor, presumably, had your officials, if they advised you the way they did yesterday. I will leave that point. There is no point in you arguing that black is white and me arguing that white is white. The proof of the pudding will be in the eating, unfortunately. This could be the reason this matter might go to the courts, because you cannot prescribe China as a safe third country and prescribe also that a person who has never left China, who has always been in China, is a person to whom that safe third country policy applies. It is ludicrous.

PARA.TAB: Could I go to the next point. In respect of the prescription of the People's Republic of China as a safe third country, you were required under section 91D of the Migration Act to address certain questions: the compliance by the PRC with relevant international law concerning the protection of Vietnamese refugees settled in the PRC, the meeting by the PRC of relevant human rights standards for the Vietnamese refugees settled in the PRC, and the willingness of the PRC to allow Vietnam refugees settled in the PRC who have subsequently travelled illegally to Australia to return to the PRC and to remain there.
I go to the point of human rights. I refer you to what you said in your tabling statement of, I think, 2 February:

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of human rights accorded to the Vietnamese refugees in China, Australia is satisfied the refugees are treated essentially as Chinese nationals, and that their living standards are in the main similar to those of local Chinese nationals. We understand that they have the same rights and obligations as Chinese nationals, which includes the obligations under the household registration system, and that they enjoy the same civil rights as Chinese nationals, with the exception of the right to participate in elections.
I should be grateful, Minister, if you would advise the committee what you think about that latter exception.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you look at the situation there, we are talking about non-citizens. It is not just China where non-citizens do not get a vote. They do not get a vote here, either. The difference between Australia and many other countries is that in Australia you can become a citizen after two years. That is part of our inclusive approach. But many other countries in the Western world do not allow citizenship for quite a number of years, if at all, to people. So I think it needs to be looked at in that international context.

—I do not want to break Senator Harradine's line of questioning but I want to come back to a point that Senator Harradine raised. I do not know whether he has moved off it now. I am somewhat concerned about the responses that Senator Harradine got from the minister to his earlier question. Could I just get the following clear, minister, following what you said to Senator Harradine. If a Chinese born wife of a Sino-Vietnamese comes here and—whether you believe it or not—believes she has been persecuted or has a fear of persecution, are you saying that there is no way in which that person can make an application for refugee status?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The line of argument that Senator Harradine was putting is a bit different to Senator Short's argument. I can say to Senator Short in respect of the sorts of people he is talking about that if they are PRC, obviously they can. The process for Sino-Vietnamese in China who are covered by the proposal would be the process I mentioned earlier. They would be interviewed. If in the course of that interview questions of refugee protection are raised, it goes through the process of ultimately coming to me.

PARA.TAB: There is still the capacity for exercising ministerial discretion for these people. The main object of this legislation is to cover these people in the way that I have just explained. If at the end of the interview questions of concern are raised, obviously they will be raised up the system to the minister for the exercise of his or her discretion. So they are not cut out of the system altogether.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was my understanding of it. That is why I was confused at the responses the minister gave to Senator Harradine. I got the impression that he said carte blanche to Senator Harradine that these people would not be subject to persecution and, therefore, the whole thing is irrelevant. What the minister has now said to me is somewhat inconsistent with what he said to Senator Harradine. I do not know whether I am confused. I think Senator Harradine probably is. Am I talking about something different from Senator Harradine?

—The minister may have clarified it. But he is now saying to Senator Short that PRC citizens will have access to all the other laws relating to refugee status in Australia and will not be covered by this bill. That is what I understand the minister is saying to Senator Short. The minister said that it is a question of PRC citizenship or nationality. He is saying to Senator Short that this bill does not apply to a PRC national. Under those circumstances, that has clarified it. I do not see how it would not. The minister says that it would not, so who am I to argue with that?
—It has always been my understanding that this bill has nothing to do with PRC nationals. This bill deals only with PRC non-nationals who happen to be Sino-Vietnamese. Is that correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. Senator Short should go back through the Hansard and see what Senator Harradine asked earlier. As I said to Senator Short, it was a different aspect of the question. Senator Harradine did not ask me whether they would have the right to apply for status or whether any claims would be treated here. He went to another aspect of the question. Senator Short's understanding is quite clear. It has been the core part of the legislation right from the start.

—I also express concern—similar to the concern of Senator Spindler and Senator Harradine, although not to the same extent—about whether this mechanism in terms of the Sino-Vietnamese will work and how it will work. As I understand what he has said, the minister would rely on the responses to the question of essentially why people had come here to find information that may lead him to think that they could have a genuine claim for his looking at using his non-compellable discretion.

PARA.TAB: What I am concerned about is that so much depends on the nature of that part of the interview. It would be very easy, I would imagine, unless the instructions given to the interviewing officers are very clear, to fudge that, if you like, or conduct that part of the interview in a way which, as Senator Harradine and I think Senator Spindler were saying earlier, did not really give them a clue that there was scope for coming into the non-compellable discretion net.

What I was looking for earlier on, and what I raised in my speech during the second reading debate, was an assurance from you that the nature of the interview—in particular, the `why have you come' part of the interview—is conducted in a way that gives us confidence that if a person is a genuine potential refugee applicant that does come to light.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give that assurance, Senator. The advice I have been given is that the interview of these people will be conducted in the same way as you would conduct an interview of someone who has the right to seek asylum status here. You would go through that same sort of expansive discussion and interview with them—that same process. In that context, I think the assurance you seek can be given.
—Just to clarify this once and for all, will one of the questions be, `Are you a Chinese national?'
—Sure, I think that would have to be one of the questions.
—If the answer to that were, `Yes, I am a Chinese national. I am the wife of this Vietnamese national and I have a well founded fear of persecution on return to my country', what would you do then?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in those circumstances that is where the non-compellable power would come into play.
—But what does the non-compellable power or discretion have to do with it at all if the person is a Chinese national? The bill does not apply to Chinese nation als.

—I think we then go back to the point that Senator Harradine and I started on earlier: a dependant who may be a Chinese national is covered by the regulations. I think that is the point Senator Harradine was trying to make earlier. As I said, Senator Short, in those circumstances that is where verification would have to take place and also the non-compellable discretion can be invoked.

—If there are two people on the boat, both of whom are Chinese nationals, one of whom is a Chinese national on his or her own and the other a Chinese national who happens to be married to a Sino-Vietnamese, are you saying that if both get off the boat and say, `I have a fear of persecution; I seek asylum,' the treatment of those two Chinese nationals will be different?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that has very clearly been the case from the start with respect to this. The regulations and the agreement cover Sino-Vietnamese and close dependent relatives, so the situation is very much that.

—Quite frankly, I do not understand that because I thought this whole thing in the safe third country agreement and the memorandum of understanding quite specifically did not relate to Chinese nationals. It is said specifically that it applies to only Sino-Vietnamese. The fact that a Chinese national might be married to a Sino-Vietnamese does not in any way change the fact that that person is a Chinese national.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Sure, but the agreement and the legislation goes to those who are being protected in the People's Republic of China. Those who are being protected are Sino-Vietnamese and their families. That was very clear from the advice that came to the committee last week in respect of this. So, on that basis, the class of people whom we are talking about are those who have received protection. That is why we cover Sino-Vietnamese and families—and dependants, for instance, in families.

PARA.TAB: But, if someone is totally separate from one of those families, the legislation does not go that far because the advice that we have does not go to the protection that has been offered to them. They are a different class altogether. I think you can understand the distinction. You may raise it in terms of a bit of a curiosity in the legislation. But I think the reality is that you cannot take it much further than that core group, nor should you take it less than a core group, because if, for instance, you had a whole boatload of people who were married to PRC nationals the whole purpose of the legislation would be undermined. So in that context we have that non-compellable discretion. If questions of refugee concerns are raised, that process is there to accommodate that particular sort of situation—probably in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to return to the structure of the initial interview that would be conducted. The minister said that it would be similar in both cases. It would be similar for a person who is a protected person in the PRC of Sino-Vietnamese extraction, as in the case of a Chinese national. That is good. I welcome that statement by the minister. I ask the minister whether there is a checklist of questions or a form on which the information that is elicited in that interview is recorded.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a checklist of questions to be asked. In anticipation of your next question, yes, we will make that available.
—I thank the minister for that offer.

—Would the minister mind pointing out where in the Migration Act or the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994 he is given any power to declare any foreign country a safe country of origin? Could he please point to that in the legisla tion?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are concerned about here is safe third country, not safe country of origin. If you are seeking safe country of origin, you will not find it but, if you are seeking safe third country, that is in the legislation. Do you want me to find the particular section covering—

—I understand what you are talking about, but Senator Short and I were talking about the instance of a Chinese national who has never left the country. How can you say that is a safe third country for such a person? I am dealing with the answer that arose from questions by Senator Short, which he put so well. If two Chinese nationals came—one who is not related to one of the Sino-Vietnamese and the other who is related to one of the Sino-Vietnamese, and they are both Chinese nationals—you are saying that one will be dealt with in a discriminatory fashion as opposed to the other due to our laws.

PARA.TAB: All I am asking you is this: if they are Chinese nationals and not refugees—therefore, China cannot be regarded as a safe third country for them but as a country of origin—where in the legislation, particularly the Migration Legislation Amendment Act (No. 4) 1994, do you have the power to do what you are proposing to do under the regulation which this bill seeks to make retrospective?

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Harradine in that sense. I would have thought that by definition it is not possible for China to be a safe third country for a Chinese national.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The operative clause is 91D(1). That gives the power to prescribe a third country in relation to a non-citizen or a class of persons. That does give you the power to do it specifically in legislation. I know the point you are making, Senator Short, but the law defines things in different ways. It has defined this situation under 91D(1) in the way that I have just stated.

PARA.TAB: The reason why two people might be treated differently under the law is the reason why we have this legislation. One of those persons gets protection and support, and the other does not. The first gets protection and support because they are part of a Sino-Vietnamese family. That is why we covered that net. Senator Short understands—I am sure the others do too—that that has been the core basis on which this legislation has proceeded. These people have received protection and support in the PRC. When I talk about `these people', I am not just referring to those who have fled from Vietnam. I am also referring to those who may have married in the PRC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that quite extraordinary. I would therefore want doubly to seek a reassurance from you that, in terms of the use of your non-compellable discretion, as far as a Chinese national who happens to be married to a Sino-Vietnamese is concerned, you would exercise that non-compellable discretion extremely liberally; otherwise you are creating a major discrimination between two otherwise similarly placed people in the sense that they are people of the same nationality. That is a matter of very grave concern. Therefore, you ought to give this parliament an assurance that you will exercise your non-compellable discretion in relation to Chinese nationals who might be caught up in this in such a way that there is in practical terms no distinction between the two.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give an assurance that the process of non-compellable discretion will be used in these circumstances if the person raises a question of concern. If they do not, then you do not have that process triggered off. But, if that person does in any sense at all raise a question that could come under the definition of `refugee', then obviously that is the sort of circumstance where that non-compellable discretion will be used. I can give you an assurance that far, Senator Short.

—I am not going to delay the chamber, but I am totally unsatisfied with the legislation. It is bizarre, to be quite frank. It seeks to make retrospective the regulation that prescribes China as a safe third country in respect of persons whose complaints are not against their country of origin but against the PRC, the country they came from most recently. In respect of these interviews, will there be—as I believe there ought to be—present during the primary interview persons independent of the department; namely, persons who are able to assist the primary interviewer and the asylum seeker in fulfilling their obligations and rights?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer in respect to these people is the same as in respect to anyone else who is interviewed by immigration officers: no, there will not be.

—The difference, of course, is that others have access to a full range of normal refugee processes. Due process is and ought to be available to them; whereas that same due process and the extent of that process is not, by definition, under this legislation, available to these people. I would have thought that, to safeguard the departmental officers as well as to honour our international obligations, it would have been advisable to have a person independent of the department present to assist in the interviews. It is not going to cost a great deal of money, because the number of potential persons will be so few.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the bill stand as printed.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
That the bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the passage of this bill further, but I do want to place some statements on the public record at this opportunity. In my speech at the second reading stage I made quite clear what the Greens's position was in relation to this legislation. I have been detained at another place while the committee process has been going on and I did have some questions which I wanted to ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), simply to place on the record the grave concerns that have arisen about this legislation. I know that Senator Harradine and Senator Spindler have engaged in very worthwhile discussion and I will certainly be reading the Hansard record to acquaint myself with those concerns and with the minister's responses.

PARA.TAB: There is no point, I believe, in the Greens asking for any more information. The reason for that is that the opposition and the government have agreed to the passage of this bill. It is being pushed through. I believe that history will vindicate those who have expressed the strongest objections to this. I therefore indicate that, while it may not receive a division at this point, the bill is clearly going through on the same basis that other migration legislation bills, with one exception, have gone through; that is, with the two major parties, the government and the Liberal-National coalition, supporting it. The very grave concerns that I believe are held right across the community for those who understand the implications of this bill on the human lives are reflected by those who have voted against it, amongst whom are the Greens.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That regulations 16 and 18 of the Austudy Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No. 409 and made under the Student Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very simple issue before the Senate. The government is seeking to change the criteria by which a student is able to obtain the independent rate of Austudy. Up until now, when a student has married and left home they have been treated as independent. That seems a fairly logical sort of assessment—logical for the young married couple and logical for the parents as well. Up until now, the assets and income of the parents have not been taken into account in assessing the eligibility of that married student. Now, for some reason, the government wants to change the rules to provide that if the student is still under the age of 22, even though the student is married, the student will no longer be treated as independent. The consequence of that would be that, in assessing the rate of Austudy applicable to the student, the assets and income of the parents of that student could be taken into account.

PARA.TAB: Not surprisingly, we oppose this quite extraordinary decision of the government. It is a decision that has upset a lot of students and student organisations around the country. I understand the government is seeking to develop some exotic argument that it is obliged to do this under the Sex Discrimination Act. Obviously, that is not so at all. It has no obligation. There is no obligation in the Sex Discrimination Act that obliges the government to change the definition of `independent' under the Austudy rule so that a student who is married and under the age of 22 is no longer to be treated as independent.

I suppose it is a convenient argument—perhaps it is the only argument that the government has got to mount. But it is certainly not so that in any way the Sex Discrimination Act applies to this decision. It might be relevant to other decisions that the government has to struggle with in relation to de facto couples and, if that is so, the government can have that struggle. But it is not relevant to this matter that is before the Senate today.

We, therefore, have moved the disallowance of this. We say, obviously, that a student who is married should continue to be treated as independent, whether they are under the age of 22 or over the age of 22. Their Austudy allowances should be treated that way as well. So it is a simple issue. It is an issue of commonsense in many ways. It is an issue of fairness to the students concerned. We are confident that the step we have taken to seek the disallowance of this motion is sensible and sound.

I guess the only other argument the government might have is that it is seeking to save a very small sum of revenue, but I do not know that that is an argument that the government has really put. What we are talking about is a very small sum of revenue. It will be interesting to hear the minister, but it will be hard to see on the figures we have been given how that could in any way be a convincing justification for what the government is seeking to do.

Therefore, I trust that the Senate will seize the opportunity to bring this government to task again. I hope that in future when the government looks to discriminate against certain students, certain classes of students, it will take into account the fact that it will not easily get such discrimination through this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats welcome this move by Senator Hill. We believe that it expresses what should be so in this area: that, in fact, the government's attempt to bring about a very unfair interpretation is a move which is inexcusable and cannot be supported. We welcome the move for disallowance by Senator Hill, and we will be supporting it.

PARA.TAB: In fact, I find no capacity whatsoever to disagree with any of the words that Senator Hill has just used. He has presented the argument clearly. There is, I believe, no capacity to disagree with anything that he said. I would be amazed to hear any attempt that the government makes to bring any rationale to this debate in support of its attempts to bring an unfair regime to apply to young married students.

If the excuse that the government has indicated it will be using is, in fact, confirmed—that there is a belief that the Sex Discrimination Act has something to do with this and that there is an exemption which has expired—then I suggest that the simplest measure the government could adopt at this moment, without going any further in the argument, would be to continue that exemption, which apparently has been applied for 10 years. If the government's other legislation is clumsily unable to deliver a fair situation to all students, then perhaps the best way out is to continue the exemption, which has applied for some years now, and then seek another way which is fair to resolve the matter.

Those of us who look for consistency in the law of the land and in the way society organises itself would recognise that society has established a number of measures of independence. In Australia the age of majority has moved from the traditional 21 years of age, which it was for an immeasurable time, down to 18. So there is at least some consistency with the ability to vote, to accrue debts, to enter contracts, to engage in military service, to enter into marriage and to make other decisions which are generally recognised as independent adult decisions.

But this government, until recently, chose for the purposes of Austudy to define `independence' as being 25 years of age. The Australian Democrats insisted that that was entirely unjust. With the assistance of student representative groups we have been able to persuade the government to at least reconsider that. Gradually, year by year, the age of independence with regard to Austudy calculations has been moved down from 25 years of age to what is presently 22 and should be 21. Of course, for consistency we would prefer eventually that it be lowered to 18 years of age. But we understand that the government cannot see, what I consider to be, the pure fairness of that. The exception has been that, if young people are married, they have defined their independence in another way—and I think in a quite correct way.

When I was a student the age of majority was 21; at that time it was also the age at which one could start to consume alcohol. Of course I obeyed that law, but I probably contravened another aspect of society: I think my mother bought by socks and underpants until I was about 30. That did not mean I was not independent; it just meant that that was the sort of parent I had. I never really liked any of those socks and underpants, and I do not know that I ever wore any of them. But that is the sort of thing that happens in families.

Here, one should adopt a degree of maturity and understand that, if you are independent, that does not mean to say you have to tick every little box, dissociate yourself completely from parental influence and be not at all dependent on parental advice. Even though I have neither of my parents with me on this planet now, I still think even at the age I am now that there are moments when I would very much like to seek my parents' advice on a number of matters—not the least of which are those things which happen in here. I do not agree with the idea that you should completely dissociate yourself from your parents before you can be declared independent. Just because the government decides that you are encumbered with, obligated to or dependent upon your parents does not make it so. We have to look at the real world.

When people are married, society accepts that they have established their independence. For the government to contradict this—what I think is—a perfectly legitimate definition of `independence' is sheer nonsense; it is bureaucracy gone to its worst extreme. I could continue, but I think the sense of the matter was expressed succinctly by Senator Hill. The Democrats endorse, welcome and support Senator Hill's motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal Sen B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the motion for disallowance, moved by Senator Hill, is about the Sex Discrimination Act, despite his attempts to denigrate that argument. In 1983, the Sex Discrimination Bill was carried through both houses—and I might point out that it was carried through with the support of Senator Hill and, I would assume, probably with the support of the Australian Democrats. In his debate on that bill, Senator Hill said:

SPEECH.PARA: So rather than argue, as some have, that this Bill introduced a new type of legislation, I see it as a logical progression towards the goal of ensuring for all Australian women the right not to be discriminated against in certain specified areas critical to their well-being, on grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy.

I think those sentiments are very worth while, and I am very pleased to see them set out. What I would like to emphasise is that it does include the basis of `marital status'. Certainly, Senator Hill is attempting to disallow at the moment a discrimination that exists in the Austudy regulations; that is, they discriminate between those who are married and those who are not married.

PARA.TAB: This breach of the Sex Discrimination Act has existed for 10 years. We have been seeking exemptions, and those have been provided. I suppose it reaches a stage where you can no longer make excuses and you have to change those regulations to comply with the Sex Discrimination Act. The Austudy regulations are discriminatory because, without those amending regulations that the opposition is attempting to disallow, they state that you receive independent status merely by becoming married; so someone who was in identical circumstances in terms of financial support, but unmarried, would not receive independent status. This, in my view, is discriminatory, and I am pleased that the regulations introduced this year have stopped that continuing discrimination.

It is very easy to say, `Well, traditionally those who are married have been treated as being independent.' That is certainly the case. I suppose the reasons for that are largely based on inheritance; you became eligible to receive an inheritance upon either reaching the age of 21 or becoming married.

The fact is that most students, even though they may be married, are not financially independent. They do not have the capacity to financially support themselves, and this is not going to be automatically altered by the fact that they are married. Clearly, there should be one rule for students seeking financial support from the government, whether they are married or single. These regulations have that effect.

In supporting these original regulations, I am not unsympathetic of those students who presently receive Austudy on the basis of independence brought about by their marriage who may be adversely affected. Figures indicate that approximately 0.5 per cent of the present Austudy population could potentially be affected by this change but, because of recent changes to the basis of independent status, this number will probably be reduced.

In the last few years, the age of independence has been reduced from 25, as it was when I went through university, to 22. As of 1 January next year, it is anticipated that that will be reduced to 21. That means that, no matter what your marital status is, you will receive Austudy as of the age of 21. In my view, that provides the maximum amount of financial support for those who require it and who would probably not be receiving it from their parents but, at the same time, it does not discriminate between those who are married and those who are single.

I urge the Senate not to support this disallowance motion. The effect of disallowing Austudy regulations 16 and 18 would be that they are almost certainly in breach of the Sexual Discrimination Act and would lead to students taking the matter up with the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. This would lead to a large expense for the Commonwealth in defending a position which is in breach of nearly all the views expressed by senators who supported the original Sexual Discrimination Act. I urge you to not support this disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one of the most bizarre explanations I have heard in recent times. We are not dealing with the issue of sexual discrimination; we are dealing with the definition of independence. If the government's current position is that those people who are married get a poorer deal, then that is where the discrimination is occurring. It is not a matter of males or females being made worse off because they are married. It is a matter of the government proposing something that will discriminate against people because they are married. That is the change and that is what we are arguing against.

PARA.TAB: What the government is trying to do with this amendment is take married people, under the age of 22, off the independent rate of Austudy. We support the coalition's motion of disallowance because it seeks to preserve the status quo and will retain the independent rate of Austudy for married people under the age of 22. The government's proposal was preposterous. Was the government honestly proposing to make adults over the age of 18 who are married seen under the eyes of Austudy laws as dependents and, therefore, means tested using their parents income and assets?

This is a joke. I do not know a more obvious definition of independence than marriage and moving out of the parental home. If we were to extend the argument, is Senator Neal suggesting that if a young person is married and happens to be killed in an accident, then any goods owned by that person must go to the parents? For heaven's sake, that is ridiculous. There a lot of areas where the status of people change when they get married and leave home. Therefore, there is a recognition that that changes their financial circumstances.

Why did the government pick the age of 22? Because at the age of 22 students naturally qualified for the independent Austudy rate, married or not. The government was trying to catch out students, who may get married for the $120 per week Austudy rate, before they would normally qualify for the independent rate. Instead of trying to catch people out who may be marrying for an extra government allowance, this should be taken as a message to the government to help those people who are desperate enough to study and have an income.

The government needs to lower the Austudy age so any adults over the age of 18 can claim the independent rate if they are independent from their parents. The government should also think seriously about bringing Austudy into line with the dole and adding a rent assistance component so Austudy does not remain way below the poverty line. These are more helpful and constructive suggestions than the government's method of doing things.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much would that cost, Senator?

—Senator Schacht interjected and said, `How much is that going to cost, Senator?' Perhaps Senator Schacht would be prepared to consider the fact that, if you are underfunding your education sector, sometimes you are going to have to play off one sector against the other. This does not mean fairness for anybody. You have to look at your public sector and understand why people are not becoming university students, why they are not lining up to get into university, why there are fewer people wanting to get into university and why there are fewer people with good qualifications. It is because you make it so darned difficult, because you give them large debts to pay off at the end and because, if they are married, it is almost impossible. You are trying to sneak through, without warning or public consultation, unfair and irrational changes which would cause great harm to young married students. We wholeheartedly support the coalition's motion to disallow the Austudy Regulations (Amendment).

—I support the motion to disallow regulations 16 and 18 of the Austudy Regulations (Amendment). I do not often agree with our dark Green senators opposite, but on this occasion I must fully agree with the remarks Senator Margetts has just made. I am pleased to hear that the Greens and the Democrats are supporting us. Given the minor amount of money the government is saving here, one wonders what on earth this government is doing. The discrimination act was brought down in 1984 and it has taken this government 11 years to discover this problem. Why has it taken 11 years? Senator Hill has already put the arguments that the urgency for disallowing this pair of regulations is because they are patronising and extremely unfair. The effect is clear: it is to remove marriage as a ground for access by students to the independent rate of Austudy and Abstudy.

PARA.TAB: The regulations are dated 6 December and will, therefore, adversely affect students about to commence their studies in late February. Young married students under the age of 22 will be severely disadvantaged if the regulations proposed by this ALP government are allowed to stand. This is yet another example of arrogant Labor Party government—not only arrogant but also inefficient, if it takes it 12 years to wake up to the fact that there is a problem. The government is breaking another longstanding promise to the Australian people, just as it has done in many other areas. If you look at the history of why governments go out of power, it is usually because of incompetence and because they keep upsetting a whole range of interest groups. The government is certainly doing this now with the students.

I have spoken to senior students recently. The minister is going to find when he gets to the next election that the sort of support he had in previous elections he is not going to get from the students this time, not after what he has done to them over the last few years. This is yet another silly example of an inefficient government, desperate for money, trying to squeeze out of the students a little extra money, totally alienating them just like it has alienated people in the timber industry, just like it has alienated the environmental lobby and just like it has alienated people who live under flight paths. Given all those interest groups the government has upset, the government will find that it will have a negative at the next election. It has just lost another 2,000 votes, the votes of married students under 22 years who are in line for a serve of this Labor government's arrogance.

Austudy is a Commonwealth funded financial assistance program. Students must satisfy an income and assets test. Broadly, for those who are not aware of the arrangements, there are three different scales. There is a standard rate for students between the ages of 16 and 22 who receive some financial and material support from their parents, there is an away from home rate for students who from necessity and because of other factors have to live away from their family home to study, and there is the independent rate of Austudy payment. This is the one that is being affected by these regulations. Up to now the independent rate was paid to students believed to be no longer financially dependent or supported by their parents; that is, a student with dependent children, one who has been working full-time or receiving a pension for three of the past four years and, up to now, a married student.

These regulations of the Labor government will remove marriage as a qualification for independence on Austudy and Abstudy rates. Coalition senators and members have received a raft of protest calls to their offices about this absolutely stupid measure. Young married students and their parents want the ALP generated anomaly that is now before us to be scrapped. Young married women and students are upset and confused by these arbitrary changes. They fear—and quite rightly—that they may have to drop all or part of their studies this year.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Simon Crean, and DEET are supporting this ridiculous proposition. One would wonder why. The patronising assumption is that these young married people under 22 years of age remain financially dependent, supported by their parents. Unless the coalition and other parties in the Senate succeed in disallowing this motion, married students under 22 will have their Austudy payments judged not only on their own income and their spouse's income but on their parents' income and assets as well.

How out of touch is government thinking when the government proposes such a ridiculous change to regulations. In many cases, these married students have moved to other states or are following their spouses in terms of work or study. They have cut the apron strings. Who can really argue that they are not truly independent of their parents? This measure is illogical and must be overturned. The coalition will be maintaining the status quo. I am pleased to see that other parties in the Senate have come to the same conclusion.

I have sought to find out some of the reasons for this ALP government's singling out this group of tertiary students in terms of eligibility for the independent Austudy rate. The answer partly lies in the requirements of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. This says that a person cannot be discriminated against on the basis of marital status. Under Austudy, prior to these regulations, married couples got the independent rate while a de facto couple did not.

There is good reason for this, because the definition of `de facto' is so broad that large-scale rorting of the system could have occurred. For example, relationships of convenience developed in student housing so that the students involved could get the more lucrative independent rate. This government was lazy and arrogant in not tackling this problem of definition. It could have decided on a fair and workable definition for genuine student de facto relationships. This would have removed the need to discriminate against any group. But the ALP minister chose to penalise married students who genuinely deserve the independent rate.

There is all this hurt and uncertainty for young married students because the Labor government could not find, with the help of its vast bureaucracy, a simple definition for de facto relationships. There was all this trouble and hurt for 2,000 gravely disadvantaged students who were made to continue their studies.

How much is the government going to save out of this measure? It will save $110,000. What will it lose in the long run in revenue by the fact that students stop studying and do not get higher qualifications, more lucrative jobs and, therefore, do not pay higher taxes? This has to be one of the most stupid and cost ineffective measures ever brought before this parliament. Students condemn its unfairness. We move to disallow these regulations. I urge the Senate to support that move.
