DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 December 1994, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 is an omnibus bill which amends several primary industry acts: firstly, the Rural Adjustment Act 1992. While the opposition agrees with most of the bill, we are extremely concerned about the amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act to allow the government to bypass state governments to undertake regional adjustment.

PARA.TAB: We know that the National Farmers Federation has agreed to regional plans for restructuring an area, but many farmers are worried about the individual property enterprise agreements which are being pushed in the south-west Queensland rural adjustment strategy. There also seems to be a clear indication that in western New South Wales the push for restructuring is coming from the top down but there is pressure on the local community to make it look as if restructuring is being sought by the local community.

We are aware that the amendments now before us will allow the rural adjustment scheme to operate effectively at a regional level rather than through state governments. The amendments provide for written agreements to be entered into with persons other than a state for grants of money or loans relating to rural adjustment. The regional approach will not replace the existing state based programs. It will be in addition to them.

However, we need to know whether these regional restructuring plans will result in the federal government taking over land management which is the prerogative of the states. For this reason, the coalition has already referred this particular legislation to a Senate committee for further investigation.

I think it is important that senators note these particular issues at a time when the primary industries of Australia are feeling extreme effects from not only the drought but also the economic consequences of many of the policies of a federal Labor administration and the compounding effects, particularly of interest rates, that have had their effect right throughout Australia.

The second act which is being amended by this particular piece of legislation is the Livestock Diseases Act 1978. This act is to be repealed to remove the Commonwealth's responsibility for exotic disease eradication activities in the Australian Capital Territory and to remove the Commonwealth's liability for payment of compensation to ACT producers whose property is destroyed or damaged as a result of exotic disease. The ACT will now join with the Commonwealth, the states and the Northern Territory in the Commonwealth-states cost sharing agreement for sharing the costs of exotic animal disease eradication campaigns.

The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Products (Collection of Levy) Act 1994 is also amended. This is to change the starting date for the registration activities of the National Registration Authority for agricultural and veterinary chemicals from 1994 to 1995. In addition, the government claims that experience in collecting this interim levy has highlighted the need for amendments.

These amendments include changing the date of payment of the levy from 1 June to 31 July each year. It is claimed that this will remove the necessity for industry to pay both the interim levy and the main levy during the 1994-95 financial year. The NRA will also be able to approve payments by instalments. The amendments to the late penalty payment provisions will allow for those payments to be set by primary legislation rather than prescribed by regulations in accordance with the concerns previously expressed by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

A further amendment affects the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987. This act is amended so that the Australian Dried Fruits Board or any other product board that is established under the act in future will not have to call a special annual general meeting. Instead, in future the chairperson of the product board must report to the annual general meeting of the product board's eligible industry body. The Dried Fruits Board sought this change. It will also allow a member of the board of the AHC to report to the eligible industry board annually rather than specifying the chairperson. There are now nine such eligible bodies and more indicating a desire to join. It is difficult for one person to attend all their annual meetings. The same types of amendments are made to the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987, which now has 11 member bodies.

Finally, in relation to the Farm Household Support Act 1992 there are now provisions for amendments which will allow the payment of farm household support to farmers who have reached the pension age by deleting the definition of `pension age'. We agree with this. I indicate that, subject to the considerations of the Senate committee which will look at those important aspects relating to rural adjustment, the coalition will be supporting this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator Tambling very clearly put it in outlining the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.3), this bill is a package designed to make changes to various primary industry acts. The change to the Livestock Diseases Act to include the ACT in the exotic disease eradication programs is an obvious change given that, despite the ACT's small size, there are rural holdings still in it. I do not know how much longer that will remain because of the way the city is spreading, but it would be patently anomalous for the ACT government not to share the burden of controlling exotic disease outbreak when its next-door neighbours in New South Wales have that responsibility.

PARA.TAB: One of course would hope that it may never occur but, as we have seen in the recent outbreak of human disease from smallgoods, disease outbreaks do occur. Some years ago in Tasmania there was an outbreak of what appeared at the time to be foot-and-mouth disease. The campaign to isolate the property affected, trace backwards and forwards the stock movements from it, and isolate and destroy the affected animals was a massive campaign. As history now records, it was not foot-and-mouth disease, and Australia remains free of that deadly disease. But the exercise was expensive, and compensation was involved. As I said, it was not foot-and-mouth disease. It was traced to incorrect feeding of smallgoods to pigs—but the potential is there. If a similar situation occurred in the ACT, the ACT government ought to expect to share the cost.

The changes to the agricultural and veterinary chemical products interim levy collection procedures are again a straightforward and necessary amendment to accommodate real world experience. The Australian Horticultural Corporation Act is a similar industry-driven change. The changes to the Rural Adjustment Act, however, in my view and in the view of other coalition senators—I am quite sure Senator Crane will make some further remarks on this later—need further examination. In essence, the proposed amendments would allow written agreement to be entered into by the federal government with persons other than a state agency.

As the Senate would be aware, the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee has just completed a lengthy study of the efficacy and effectiveness of the rural adjustment scheme and came up with some very strong views and conclusions. During our inquiry we took evidence on the issue of regional rural adjustment programs. One in particular that we comment on in the report is that in the south-west mulga lands of Queensland which the committee visited. That program seems to be working very well. It had a grassroots-up application, though. One of the reasons why I think there should be an inquiry is to find out whether this should be applied downwards or upwards as far as the implementation of it is concerned—that is, whether it should come from the federal government down or whether it should come from the grassroots up.

The department, in its evidence to the committee, mooted such changes as the legislation proposed. I think Neil Inall was a great proponent of it, as were others, during the inquiry. As I say, Mr Neil Inall, the Chairman of the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, supported it very much. It is fair to say that the committee was very supportive of the view that a regional approach is a good way to go. However, against that support one needs to examine the mechanisms of such a change. I think the rural and regional affairs committee will examine those issues, and I believe it is appropriate that it does that. Funding arrangements, for example, where regional projects transect state boundaries need to be looked at to find out what happens there.

There is also a political equity question here, in that the government of the day could use this mechanism to direct funds to a region for political purposes. Given the recent history of the sports funding activities and the attitude of the government, it is highly likely that RAS funds could become pork barrels for regional areas.

The state agencies also have to be considered. What impact would these direct arrangements have on the functions and role of the state agencies? I do not think the amendments as they are outlined in this bill really cover those aspects. We are all too frequently aware of examples of sloppy drafting across a wide range of bills. It is not uncommon to have legislation in this place fixing up one unintended consequence or another.

I also wonder whether the funding will come from a regional program or out of RAS. Basically, if it intends to do things regionally, maybe it should come out of the regional development program. I want to know whether it will definitely be grassroots up or whether it will be imposed one way or another. Will it bypass the states and will it be pushed down, as I have already said? Will the RAS funding come out of underspends or will it come out of new money as a regional approach to RAS? Those are some of the questions that have to be answered. Obviously, the benefit of these Friday committees is that we can get those answers and have a much better informed debate here in the chamber.

I would like to think that, by referring the bill to a committee that is intimately interested in the operation of RAS, as the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee and the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee are, we might overcome some of the drafting glitches and unintended consequences that may over time become apparent in this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to contribute to this debate on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994. I am just going to concentrate on the aspect of rural adjustment. It is fair to say that, whether it is right or wrong, the committee report into rural adjustment demonstrated quite clearly that there is enormous confusion out in the farming sector as to how rural adjustment works. There is a lot of concern that it is not adequately meeting the current requirements of rural adjustment in Australia. There is also concern about the different interpretations between the states and a whole range of matters which came before the committee which put together the report.

PARA.TAB: In view of the fact that Senator Panizza is in the chamber, I would like to take this opportunity to thank him sincerely for the work that he did on my behalf when I was not able to be here last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. It was my pleasure.

—Thank you, Senator Panizza. It is a pity we are not on broadcast; it could go out to Merredin or Southern Cross, couldn't it? No doubt you will send them a note. Some of the points I want to raise have been touched on by Senator Brownhill and Senator Tambling. The point that I want to make first and foremost is that it is absolutely essential that the rural adjustment process is understood in country centres and works as intended. The evidence clearly showed that that is not the case. It is important that the government picks up most, if not all—I would suggest all—of the key recommendations of the report.

PARA.TAB: The first recommendation I want to deal with is that we should give it a positive focus rather than a negative focus, which it currently has. It needs to be renamed and called the rural enhancement scheme or the rural promotion scheme. It needs to be called something positive, unlike the rural adjustment scheme, which is negative. When you talk to people about RAS, as it is generally known, there is a negative thought about it before you even start, and that needs to be addressed.

I acknowledge that we have agreed to refer this bill to a Friday committee, and I will not spend a lot of time discussing this now, but it is important that we look very carefully at this so-called regional focus. When it is said quickly and looked at on the first glance, nobody has any problems with a regional focus; but then the problem comes in. I want to relate this to exceptional circumstances, because exceptional circumstances has a local focus. There is a drought or a flood or a fire or whatever the particular aspect is in a particular area concerned.

As we all know, the provisions with regard to exceptional circumstances have a long way to go before they are satisfactory in terms of how they are determined, how they are administered, how the funds are delivered, who is eligible and who is not eligible. Why is a line drawn in a particular place when, from the information that we have brought before us, in many instances a person on the outside of the line is in a situation no different to that of one on the inside of the line? Information has been brought to me in recent weeks that in New South Wales there are a number of cases outside the line that are significantly worse off than some of those that are inside the line. They seem to be significant cases, as they have been reported to me, but I have not had a chance to check them personally.

All these aspects have to be looked at very carefully and very thoroughly. How is it going to be administered? Is it going to be administered direct from the Commonwealth to the person or persons? Is it going to be done through shire councils? Is it going to be done through farm advisers? If people wish to get involved as a group in one of these regional programs, what structure do they have to put in place? The legislation does not spell out any of this type of thing. As Senator Brownhill quite rightly identified, as things operate it could well become open to political abuse. That is one of my main concerns.

The other concern which I must emphasise here again—and I think I have touched on it briefly—is that we must have a system in which there is equity between regions or areas as to how they are treated and how they are assessed. How are we going to deal with a particular region that, for example, might be primarily grazing or wool growing, as against a particular region that is primarily grain growing? We can throw horticulture in there; we can throw in almost anything. Is it going to deal with the fishing industry? What is their position in terms of that and restructuring of it?

None of these questions are answered in what I have seen of the legislation or in the explanatory memorandum, and they all need to be examined thoroughly before this goes anywhere down that path. If it were possible, I would certainly be insisting that we see the regulations or, preferably, that we have amendments put in the act which spell all these things out. I know you cannot write every single word into a piece of legislation, but you need some very thorough guidelines in the legislation so that people know exactly how it stands and how it is going to operate.

I will come back for a moment to the exceptional circumstances arrangements, which, as I said, have a regional focus depending on what the circumstances are. They are administered through the states in conjunction with the existing rural adjustment authorities. My preferred position, when dealing on a regional basis, would be to maintain that particular arrangement through the states with a changed focus and a changed name. Having said that, I would like to see from the department and from the minister what the actual proposals are and what the plans are to deal with some of the matters that I have mentioned.

The other point which I think needs spelling out very clearly is: what will be the criteria in terms of the individuals who make the application? Can a minimum of five operations make the application, or will there be a necessity for a minimum of 20? Does it include small businesses in terms of towns and restructuring? Does it include farming operations or grazing operations that as part of their operation have an adjunct of some other small business operation? Will there be limits on the amount of finance that is available to go into any one scheme?

Where will the funding come from? Senator Brownhill raised a very valid point. Will it come out of existing rural adjustment funds? Will it come out of regional development funding? Will there be new money? From reading the newspaper reports in recent days on the problems the government has with the deficit and the budget process, I doubt whether it will be new money. I think we can just about rule that one out.

But all these questions and points, if this is the focus of the way that the process is going to go, need to be put on the table; they need to be answered. I believe there need to be additional changes to the legislation to make it more clear and we need to have the regulations delivered to us so we know, when we go to finalising this legislation, precisely and exactly what we are voting for and what it is about.

The last question I wish to raise in this debate is purely and simply: what will be the long-term future of the various rural adjustment authorities round the states as we know them now? Is it the intention, for example, to gradually phase them out? Will this regional focus take over some of the roles and functions that they have now? Will there be a capacity, in terms of the regional focus, to go direct to an individual farmer? One can go on and on. It just raises so many questions that are unanswered. We will be going to the Friday committee, and I give notice to the people from the department who are coming to that committee, that we need to have some very specific, precise answers to some of the things that have been raised here. There is, of course, a whole host of other issues that I, Senator Brownhill and, I presume, Senator Woodley will be asking with regard to this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994. This bill makes a number of amendments to programs within the primary industries and energy portfolio, but I will restrict myself today to commenting simply on those sections which deal with the farm household support scheme and the rural adjustment scheme.

PARA.TAB: Amendments in this bill to the Farm Household Support Act will remove the restriction that farm household support payments are not available to those who are of pension age or older. In November last year, the New South Wales Synod of the Uniting Church put out a report which summarised the concerns that came out of a meeting of rural financial counsellors in New South Wales. In that report, the church said that one group of people who have been identified by counsellors as falling through the welfare safety net were some farmers over 65 years of age—presumably mostly males.

The report says that some of these older farmers find themselves in the position whereby their overdraft is at the limit and no extension is available from their creditors. They are ineligible for the age pension or any other social security payment because of the level of their assets—in other words, their farms—and do not qualify for a drought relief payment. On top of all this, up until now, they have also been ineligible for any assistance under the farm household support scheme simply because of their age. Assistance has been restricted to those who are over 16 but have not reached pension age.

The Democrats have never been very strong supporters of the farm household support scheme, primarily because it is operated as a loan system rather than a grant scheme. As such, I was not at all surprised to hear the evidence given by numerous people to the recent RAS inquiry to the effect that the farm household support scheme, in the words of one witness, `has been the greatest failure.' It has been said before in this place, and I will say it again, that the last thing people who have exhausted every source of commercial credit available to them need is another loan hanging over their heads. Given that the chances of being able to sell a farming property these days are pretty slim, that is what farm household support recipients ultimately end up with—a loan accruing interest at commercial rates.

Ever since the introduction of this scheme, the Democrats have argued that payment should be provided as a grant and not as a loan. It should be remembered that these payments go to farm families who have no money whatsoever, who have no capacity to borrow from any financial institution, and that the payments are solely to cover the family's day-to-day living expenses. My colleague, Senator Lees, made some comments in 1992 about the loan aspect of this scheme. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, this amounts to the government making money out of alleviating poverty. To make it clear, we are talking about farmers who need a payment to put food on the table, but they may end up after two years with a debt of some $20,000.

For those people who received farm household support when it was first introduced, the two years will be up next month, at which time they will begin to be charged interest and they will have to start making repayments.

PARA.TAB: These people are among some of Australia's worst off farmers, and they are being penalised for not being able to sell up their properties and get out of farming altogether. Given the situation in rural Australia at the moment, farmers in many parts of Australia would be lucky to give their farms away, let alone to sell them. In spite of this, these people are soon going to have to start repaying a debt to the Commonwealth. It is a debt accumulated while they were basically living in poverty; a debt on which the government will charge a commercial interest rate.

I reiterate that the Democrats believe that, since the object of farm household support payments is solely to cover the day-to-day living expenses of totally destitute farm families, the payments should be made as a grant. The Democrats will not be opposing the extension of eligibility to the scheme to those who have reached the pension age, so it may at least provide short-term relief for some of those farmers identified by the Uniting Church as being in great financial difficulty. In spite of this, we urge the government to undertake a review of this whole scheme as soon as possible.

I turn to the amendments in the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 which refer to the rural adjustment scheme. These amendments will provide greater flexibility to the rural adjustment scheme in its delivery of assistance. In particular, the bill will enable RAS assistance to be provided on a regional basis, in addition to being provided through the usual state adjustment authorities. The Democrats are pleased to see this added flexibility. Although we share the concerns raised by Senator Crane, given that the amendments are framed with goodwill, we are pleased to see this added flexibility being incorporated into the scheme as it is something for which the farm sector has been calling for some time.

I reiterate some of the comments I made last week. As senators will be aware, the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs completed an inquiry into the operation of the rural adjustment scheme and presented its report late last year. Although the terms of reference for that inquiry were reasonably wide and the evidence received pointed to some of the fundamental problems with rural industry and communities, the report of the committee was basically limited to operating within the existing government framework, but gave some attention to the issue of rural debt. The report concentrated on making amendments to the current rural adjustment scheme and did not consider the overall question of what policies are really needed in this area. This means that most of the recommendations contained in the report, while they will improve the rural adjustment scheme if they are implemented, do not get at some of the much deeper problems facing Australia's farmers and rural communities.

I support the committee's recommendations, but to fully comprehend and to begin to rectify the enormous problems in rural Australia today, we need to go beyond the scope of that inquiry to get at the problem raised in many of the submissions. The evidence which was presented certainly went far beyond the scope of the report as it is written.

We need to ask ourselves: how can it be that family farms which have been viable for generation after generation are suddenly so unviable that the current generation is being forced to sell up and leave the land? I think the answer to that question would expose some far greater problems than we have covered in the report of the RAS inquiry. As I said a moment ago, many of the submissions went deeper but I believe the report does not address those submissions adequately. In many ways, I believe the drought has masked these deeper problems. The drought has certainly pushed a great number of farms to crisis point and beyond and the media has played a useful role in showing this to the broader community, pointing out and underlying the desperation that there is in country Australia. But the problems facing Australia's farmers go far deeper than just the drought. I would like to outline for the Senate what I see are some of these deeper problems.

The first of those is the problem, or perhaps more accurately, the epidemic of rural debt. The epidemic has been brought about by high interest rates, by various banking practices, by advice and encouragement to farmers to get big or get out and, regrettably, by insufficient scrutiny and monitoring by farmers of the financial advice given to them. The issue of rural debt was touched on very briefly by the committee in the RAS inquiry but I believe it is an area which needs far greater attention.

There are many other problems and I raised these last week. There are problems such as land degradation, the effect on farmers of being part of the global economic system, the problem of the removal of government resources from rural areas, and the entry into industry of large international agribusiness which is increasing foreign ownership of Australian resources and subsequently bringing about a reduction in the number of Australia's family farming operations. And there is what I believe is a total lack of any—I was going to say government but really it is all of us—real commitment to the maintenance of rural communities and infrastructure. The exodus from the bush continues as it has for the last 20 years and I do not see any policy from any party which really addresses that. There is no policy direction from either the government or the coalition which is committed to the maintenance of population and industry in inland Australia.

The final problem I see is the deliberate walking away from policies of cross-subsidisation. It has become a dirty word but they were policies on which Australia was built and on which many of our rural and remote regions rely. These are some of the deeper problems which are facing rural Australia today and these are the issues that we are going to have to address if we are serious about rectifying the growing gulf between rural and urban Australia.

The problem with the current rural adjustment scheme—and I admit the benefit that it is to some farmers—is that its two foci are designed to make viable farms more viable and to remove all other farmers from rural industry altogether. That is a policy for continuing down the same disastrous track—disastrous from my point of view. While some would see that it may produce a viable rural industry, I would see it as continuing the dramatic exodus from the bush. We need to ask ourselves whether or not we want to see the family farm survive in this country or whether we are happy to stand by and see those farms taken over by investors and foreign owned agribusiness. The Democrats are committed to fighting to protect the family farm as we believe it is an essential part of the fabric that is rural Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their support for all those bills except the one relating to the rural adjustment scheme. I look forward to the speedy passage of those after the committee hearing on Friday. I am advised by Minister Collins that he is quite comfortable with the proposal that the committee look at RAS on Friday and I think people will be reassured by the evidence presented on that occasion. I hope the bill can then come back and proceed as speedily as we originally envisaged.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to earlier today, the bill stands referred to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee for consideration and report on 7 March 1995.
Debate resumed from 7 December 1994, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Bill is being supported by the coalition, so it will not be held up very long in this chamber. What I must say, in the absence of Senator Alston, who has carriage of this bill, is that the coalition welcomes this bill because at last it will bring uniformity into the carriage of dangerous goods throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: There have been some very ridiculous situations where six states have had six sorts of regulations. This bill will bring about uniformity, though the state of Western Australia is not taking it on board as a whole. The Minister for Transport in Western Australia, Eric Charlton MLC, has said that the Western Australian government will mirror legislation in Western Australia, so there will be uniformity right around Australia even though Western Australia will have its own legislation. I welcome that. I have briefed my colleague from New South Wales, Senator Tierney, and made him an instant expert on transport. I now defer to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Panizza for his comments and rise also to indicate the support of the opposition for the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Bill 1994. The purpose, as Senator Panizza has outlined, is to create a uniform system of regulation across Australia in terms of the movement of dangerous goods through various states. In regard to dangerous goods it follows from the National Road Transport Commission Act 1991, where the intention was to create uniform legislation. If this bill is adopted by the parliament, the provisions of the act and the regulations, which constitute the flowing on from the earlier act, will become the primary law in the states and territories in relation to the transport of dangerous goods.

PARA.TAB: The reason why we need this legislation relates to the problem that we currently have with a series of different regulations across the states at a time when often we have large trucks moving material from places like Perth to the eastern seaboard. Under the current system each state requires a series of things to happen but they are not uniform. Not only is this situation incredibly inconvenient for the truck operators but it is also extremely expensive. I would just like to give some examples of that.

A dangerous goods registration and licence for a prime mover is required in Victoria. That is not required in other states. New South Wales state law deems a trailer to be unregistered if the registration label is lost, and there are heavy fines attached to that. That does not apply in other states. The Victorian dangerous goods branch requires additional excess flow valves to be fitted to LPG tankers. Other states do not. An example of the problem when one of these road transports cross Australia relates to a regulation like AS3788. The Victorian authorities have a different standard for the testing of LPG gas tankers from those in South Australia and New South Wales in terms of frequency and the area subject to extra stress. So the person in business has to meet a whole range of standards relating to that particular situation.

We also have problems of non-recognition of other jurisdiction approvals or testing inspections. This is a point of contention and re-testing is often done using different criteria in various states. I have an example of one company and the great inconvenience it was caused by the current situation of different sets of regulations. The transport manager of a Perth firm which carts dangerous bulk goods and liquids awarded a contract for the construction of a 25-triaxial B-double trailer to a Queensland company. When this piece of equipment was finished, it had to be moved. Honourable senators must keep in mind that this was a new trailer; it was not carrying any goods at all at this point. The company required operating permits to move it from Brisbane to Perth to pass through the various states.

Neither the New South Wales government nor the Commonwealth government had in place legislation to deal with this type of vehicle. It was therefore necessary to avoid transit through New South Wales. The vehicle had to be moved via the Innamincka Track. Three sets of operating permits were then required for Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia. Both South Australia and Western Australia required the trailer to be inspected by the dangerous goods inspectors and each inspection cost over $10,000. That example shows the ridiculous nature of the situation that we have had up to this point in time.

The coalition welcomes this bill. This legislation is an essential part of micro-economic reform. One of this country's great costs to a whole range of goods is the transport component: these inspections have cost the economy and increased the price of the good. This legislation is an excellent example of micro-economic reform; it is an excellent example of cooperation between the state and federal levels of government. Federation took place in 1901. I am absolutely amazed that it has taken until 1995 for such legislation to be put in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the Greens do not oppose the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Bill 1994, the things that have been left out or, more accurately, the exemptions, need to be mentioned at this stage. Honourable senators will recall a debate on 11 October last year which was in relation to my motion on the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act. That motion and debate took place because of legitimate community concerns. Some of the most worrying transport of dangerous goods in our country—that is, the transportation of radio-active waste—comes under the least scrutiny. We expressed concerns at that particular time and the government assured us that the highest level of safety would be maintained.

PARA.TAB: It is cruel, perhaps, to remind the government that in fact there were two spillage scares within a month. I quote from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 8 December 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: Thousands of tonnes of radioactive soil, contaminated during the CSIRO uranium experiments in the 1940s and `50s, are being trucked through outer Sydney suburbs and a number of NSW country towns on the way to South Australia.

It had been sent to Lucas Heights, where it was being stored under tarpaulins. The soil was packed in drums sitting on wooden pallets, and so was open to termite attack and rust. I will quote from an article in the Australian on 6 January 1995 by John Kerin. It says:

The federal Minister for Science and Technology, Senator Cook, yesterday faced renewed calls to halt the dumping of radioactive waste in South Australia following the second spillage scare in a month.

The reaction followed an incident in which a truck carrying drums of waste from Sydney's Lucas Heights to Woomera Range head, 600km north of Adelaide, was turned back in Sydney by police following a complaint from a motorist that something was leaking.

It seems ridiculous that whilst there seem to be moves to regulate the transport of dangerous good, we have this amazing anomaly. This is most important at the moment because we have sites like St Marys, where there is an unknown quantity of various toxins within the soil. They are not even sure exactly where they are.

PARA.TAB: There was a debate over radioactive waste from that site, but there are also other toxic contaminants within that soil. According to the information we have, Australian Defence Industries is exempt from state and federal laws. Even though it has nothing to do with defence, defence procurement or anything of that nature, the process that ADI is involved with is property speculation in which some private firms perhaps stand to make a great deal of money at public expense.

Here we have an exemption which may also involve a great deal of soil and other contaminated material moving from St Marys. Some of it might be radioactive, some might be toxic, some might be of an unknown quantity or quality, and we will not know. We will not be able to scrutinise it. It will not have to go through the normal process of the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Bill 1994. Or will it? Perhaps, when we briefly move into the committee stage of this bill, I will be able to ask this question of the minister: exactly what kind of assurances does this bill give us when we have these huge problems involving a lack of scrutiny and involving slackness in relation to transport of radioactive waste and toxic waste simply because it happens to be done by ANSTO or ADI?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the speakers in the debate for their contributions.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that Australian Defence Industries believes it is exempted from the normal laws of environment and safety in relation to transport of radioactive and toxic goods; and this would, to its mind, include the clean-up of the site at St Marys. I ask the minister: is this the case?
—At this stage, the bill is intended only to cover dangerous goods defined by the Australian dangerous goods code which at the moment excludes nuclear material.

—I thank the parliamentary secretary, but I remind him that the site at St Marys is not only a radioactive site. I did mention the removal of radioactive waste, but I also mentioned that there are a number of toxic substances that are perhaps still to be discovered on that site which will require transport over time before this can be carved up as is intended, to be used as a housing site. Would Australian Defence Industries be exempt from the legislation in its efforts at property speculation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Depending on the type of toxic substance that exists at the site, some of those toxic substances would be covered by the Australian dangerous goods code, so Australian Defence Industries would be covered by the legislation. It depends on the nature or the type of toxic substance that is uncovered. I am not familiar with the site that Senator Margetts refers to, nor the likely nature of toxic substances. Depending on the degree of knowledge of the toxic substances at that site, we would have to look at what is toxic from that site and then list it against the dangerous goods code. We could then provide an answer.

—I thank the parliamentary secretary. I would be very grateful for any information that could be provided in relation to when Australian Defence Industries is subject to these laws, when it will be exempted and the reasons why.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just received advice. We will attempt to gain particulars of substances from the site and will give a response about whether or not Australian Defence Industries is covered by the dangerous goods code.

Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
