QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I remind the minister that on 2 February and 6 February he categorically denied that the government had made an arrangement with the Tasmanian Labor Party which saw 50 coupes originally to be protected in Tasmania deleted from the list of 511. The Tasmanian shadow forest minister, Mr Lennon, on 27 January stated that he had negotiated that agreement with the federal government. I ask the minister: in light of his earlier denials, how does he now explain the comments made by Mr Lennon in the Tasmanian parliament yesterday? Mr Lennon said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . it was my intervention—not to Senator Faulkner, but directly to the Prime Minister's office—which saw the number reduced to 72. He—
can say what he likes. Faulkner has been shown for what Faulkner is in this debate.
Isn't this just another grubby deal organised by Mr Keating for his electoral purposes, or have you on two occasions misled the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indicated before in answers to similar questions from Senator Hill that I am not aware that there is any truth to such allegations.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I also remind the Senate of what else Mr Lennon said in the parliament last night. He said, `Faulkner caused the mess in the first place with the process that he set up. Surely to goodness that is well established by now.' I ask: is the minister claiming that Mr Lennon is lying to the Tasmanian parliament or, alternatively, is he saying that he has been so sidelined in this whole process by the Prime Minister's office that the Prime Minister has not even bothered to tell him about the deal? Has he inquired of the Prime Minister's office what was negotiated with the Tasmanian government and, if he hasn't, why hasn't he?

—What I have indicated in relation to the substantive issue raised by Senator Hill in his first question and followed in his supplementary question is that I do not believe there is any substance to the rumours.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer the minister to reports this week of a survey by Monash University and Ernst and Young which shows that manufacturers are still in the early stages of quality control development and which concludes that a lack of understanding of management practices is acting as a major impediment to quality improvement. Given the need for Australian manufacturing to continue its strong output and export growth, can the minister indicate what impact these findings may have on the future performance of the manufacturing sector? Is the minister taking any action to address these concerns?

—This is a timely survey because it shows us what progress the manufacturing sector of the Australian economy is making in responding to changes in the international marketplace and suiting itself up for international competition. The Monash-Ernst and Young survey canvassed 1,000 manufacturing firms across a wide range of manufacturing sectors. It compared results of a similar survey in 1991 with this survey, which was taken in 1993, and came to some conclusions.

PARA.TAB: Some of those conclusions are a little worrying, but others point the direction to the future. It found that Australian manufacturers are in the early stages of picking up quality principles for their businesses.

The idea of quality is not as widespread in the manufacturing psyche as we would like to see. Only 10 per cent of Australian firms are fully certificated in their business for quality principles. That compares to a worldwide average of 20 per cent, and around one-third of companies do not practice quality management techniques, like total quality management, in their human resources, administration or marketing area. They think of quality only in terms of products and product development.

The figures confirm the Australian Manufacturing Council's report Leading the way, which was released last year, which suggests that about 35 per cent of Australian firms are not yet ready for competition in the international marketplace. It is also estimated that about 10 to 20 per cent of Australian manufacturers are actively engaged in export, indicating that a large number of them have not yet turned on to the opportunities of export in the international economy.

That is why I believe there is going to be continuing and sustained growth in Australian manufacturing into the future and why I have a quite buoyant outlook about the future of this sector. We have been increasing manufacturing exports year on year for the last 10 years by about 16 per cent. It has been growing dramatically. But what we see from these figures is that a smaller band than we would like to see of Australian manufacturing companies is responsible for that dramatic growth in exports and for that widening of our export base, but there are many more companies that have not yet got the message.

Therefore, the objective of government policy is to push principles of world best practice to encourage industry benchmarking, to encourage the quality mission, total quality management, and to spread, by way of example of successful Australian exporters, successful Australian innovators and successful Australian companies, that these principles embodied in managerial practice in our manufacturing sector will mean that Australia is on an ever onward ever upward burgeoning path for manufactures of exports and be able to more widely and aggressively compete in the international market.

The other reason for that confidence in our manufacturing sector is that the Ernst and Young survey found that more than 50 per cent of Australian firms have started the process of quality certification. That compares with 35 per cent of overseas firms. In the Working Nation statement brought down by the Prime Minister last year, we have encoded a series of programs and policies which will ensure the spread of best practice, the spread of quality management in Australian manufacturing and the take up of those principles and concepts. I am certain that the government, working closely with this important and strategic industry sector, will be able to broaden the economic base of this country and offer Australians long-term quality jobs. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the June 1994 AQIS recommendation that `importation of cooked chicken meat be permitted from the USA, Thailand and Denmark based on conditions specified in the draft protocol'. In light of the fact that the Australian industry is in a five-year process of expanding the domestic market which will provide flow-on export benefits, in light of the fact that ABARE has estimated an outbreak of imported Newcastle disease would cost the local industry $59 million in the first year, and in light of the fact that we know the products from Thailand, USA and Denmark are heavily subsidised, I ask: has the final decision been made on the importation of cooked chicken meat? Why has the Australian government decided that now is the time to consider exposing the Australian chicken meat industry to the disease risks involved?

—In answer to the last part of Senator Boswell's question, we will do nothing of the sort. In fact, Australia has one of the most enviable regimes of quarantine in the world, as Senator Boswell well knows. We get criticism from others from time to time around the world of just how scrupulously we apply it. It will continue to be applied scrupulously but only on a sound scientific ground.

PARA.TAB: I do want to make one comment about what Senator Boswell said about subsidised chicken. I want to make it clear that that is a separate issue. The quarantine requirements of Australia are based completely on technical/scientific grounds and not, as Senator Boswell knows, on any financial grounds.

I have had a whole series of meetings with representatives of this extremely important Australian industry—and it employs thousands of Australians in permanent jobs. As a matter of fact—I did not know Senator Boswell was going to ask this question today—I had an extensive meeting again this morning with representatives of not just the industry but also unions that represent the workers in its employ. Certainly, as I have said, it is by no means the first time I have met with the industry.

I repeated to them this morning the assurance I have given them previously, and they accepted it. That is, before any final decision is taken I will meet with them again. There is a delegation going to Thailand to actually inspect plants that may supply Australia with the product. I have invited representatives of the Australian Veterinary Association to be included in that delegation and, of course, the industry itself will be involved in that delegation which will inspect at first hand the processes that are going to be used in factories that may export chicken meat to Australia to ensure that the highest standards of processing possible are carried out in those factories. It will not be until the quarantine authorities in Australia, on expert veterinary advice, are satisfied that there is no risk to the Australian chicken industry that that will be allowed.

I add—again, I am sure Senator Boswell knows this—cooking, providing the chicken is cooked correctly, destroys even the most resistant of all known pathogens that infect chicken. Of course, there are concerns about post-processing contamination that also have to be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Salmonella, for example.

—If it is properly cooked, as I have said, those will be destroyed. That is why the most scrupulous examination has to be made in terms of these matters. I stress again: the quarantine decisions that will be taken will be taken on a sound scientific basis; that is, a scientific basis that we can defend internationally—and the chicken industry knows that. I repeat again the assurances I gave representatives of the industry this morning: there will be no decision taken until there is further full consultation with the industry.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the current visit to Australia of the South African Executive Deputy President, Mr F.W. de Klerk, and recent media reports of Mr de Klerk's support for an Indian Ocean trade pact. Is the minister able to advise the Senate on the Australian attitude towards this concept? Is this suggested framework a realistic means of building a better climate for trade and economic cooperation among the littoral states of the Indian Ocean?

—I thank Senator Loosley for his question. I understand that the foreign affairs and trade committee had a meeting with the Executive Deputy President this morning, as I had the pleasant opportunity to do. Amongst the issues discussed was the question of the development of relationships around the Indian Ocean and the significant changes that have taken place—the political transformation in South Africa and the economic transformation in India—the combined effect of those and their implications, particularly from my point of view for trade, but my colleague the foreign minister is interested in their security implications also.

PARA.TAB: We did have an exchange of views about that, having read what Mr de Klerk had said. It was quite clear that we share a view about the value of developing relationships around the Indian Ocean rim, about developing some sort of Indian Ocean identity, but we also agreed on the need to proceed in a very measured process with this. We are not talking about rushing into setting up secretariats, organisations, committee meetings and formal structures. I do not think any littoral state of the Indian Ocean is currently interested in the development of anything as structured as that. It may eventually lead to that, but that is not envisaged at the moment and is not within sight.

There are some important steps being taken. We welcome the fact that Mr de Klerk has said this. Last August the Australian government, on the basis of a joint submission from the foreign minister and me, endorsed the `Looking West' strategy to lift our priority of focus towards the Indian Ocean and we have had welcome cooperative discussions with the Western Australian government with regard to this matter because much of the interest and priority in Australia is focused, of course, in Perth.

From a trade point of view, the interest is focused much more broadly. On Sunday I will be leading a trade mission to India and next month to South Africa. In both of those instances there will be substantial interest from companies based on the east coast as well as the substantial west coast interest. I think those trade missions will build on the successful activities, led by the special trade representative in 1993 and 1994 to those countries, and build the developing interest of the Australian private sector.

Also, the foreign minister and I are promoting further discussions of this broader issue of Indian Ocean relationships. There will be discussions of a less official nature at a conference in Mauritius in March. Australia will be hosting such a conference in Perth in June, fundamentally under the initiative of the Australian government but with the cooperation of the Western Australian government.

This is not in any way to imply that Australia is lessening its focus on APEC. APEC and its region and, in particular, the east Asia-western Pacific region remain the primary focus of Australian trade interest. We do need to have a global approach to trade. Australia is and always has been a global trader. As the opportunities develop in the Indian Ocean, we are committed to continuing to maintain the focus on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Does the minister accept the authority of the IPCC scientific advice with respect to the urgent need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions? Does the minister accept that in the light of this advice the response of the government to greenhouse gas reductions has been inadequate? Specifically, has the $6 million allocated through the minister's department for the `energy card' scheme resulted in the installation of a single solar hot water system? If not, why hasn't it? Is it not a fact that such a scheme would work if it were adequately funded through the redirection of revenue from a carbon tax?

—Of course, we do accept the expertise and the projections of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change that Senator Coulter referred to. In terms of the future, Senator Coulter, if you have a look at the actual report the panel has produced, you will see that when they used the word `eventually'—and this is very important in terms of some of the press reports that I have seen—what they meant was not in the next two or three years; they meant in the next two or three centuries. The reason that I say that is that there was an extremely misleading press statement—and I understand it was an unauthorised press statement—issued after the release of the report which contained a rather startlingly different picture to the content of the report itself. We certainly do accept that.

PARA.TAB: I think the energy card, an initiative of this government, is going to be an extremely important model—we do not know yet how it will work—in encouraging people to use more energy efficient equipment. We have, indeed, provided $6 million in funding for that proposal. It was not delayed because of a funding problem. The delay was entirely outside the hands of the government in that, when all of the negotiations had been completed and it was about to be launched, both of the private organisations involved had significant corporate changes—simultaneously, as it happened. That required a complete re-look at the previous agreements by the lawyers that were then involved. I understand there has been no hitch to that. They are not unhappy with what they have seen and so on.

My advice now is that that scrutiny by the lawyers, as a result of these corporate changes made, has almost been completed and we will be able to issue the energy card in the near future. But I can assure you that I have as much interest as Senator Coulter in seeing how successful that very innovative scheme by the government, that has been strongly supported by the two private industry organisations involved, will actually result in a change in the patterns of energy requirements of consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I remind the minister that article 6 of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty requires states which are party to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty to `pursue negotiations in good faith on effective measures relating to'—amongst other things—`nuclear disarmament'. Is the minister aware of a firming view amongst many NPT parties which are not nuclear weapons states that the nuclear weapons states have not met their article obligations? Is he further aware of a view that the current review and re-negotiation of the NPT should, for this reason, include definite timetables, extension periods and targets to help give real effect to article 6? Is it a fact that the government is, nevertheless, seeking an indefinite extension of the NPT and does not support attempts to introduce any definite time frame for further nuclear disarmament? How does the government justify this position?

—The nuclear non-proliferation treaty has been, unequivocally, the most important reason why the world still only has five declared nuclear weapons states and a handful of others whose status is a little more ambiguous, as distinct from having 25 or 30 nuclear weapons states, which was the anticipated reality just a couple of decades ago when these matters were being first debated. The NPT has been a great force for stability in this respect.
—How many are there now?
—I am not going to be specific about it, but we all know who the likely additional nuclear weapon holders are in the subcontinent, the Middle East and elsewhere—well, not necessarily elsewhere.

PARA.TAB: But the reality of the situation is that Australia does very strongly support indefinite extension of that treaty at the forthcoming review conference. We see that as being a major factor in locking in the significant achievements in disarmament which have occurred since the end of the Cold War and to provide the most propitious environment for continued nuclear reductions.

It does need to be appreciated that, whatever may have been the case about the article 6 obligations prior to the end of the Cold War, there has been an extraordinary degree of movement pursuant to article 6 in those last few years. The United States and Russia, under the START process, have certainly begun the crucially important process of making deep cuts in their nuclear arsenals; and of course we have had a situation where the former Soviet states which inherited nuclear weapons—the Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus—all both have joined the NPT and are working towards eliminating nuclear weapons on their territories. Those cuts are real, they have occurred and they are continuing. We want that state of affairs to occur.

We take the view that indefinite extension provides the best way to advance the goal of universal adherence and, in particular, to convince non-parties—including, again, in particular, those with unsafeguarded nuclear programs in regions of proliferation concern—to rethink their attitude to the NPT and abide by the international norm the treaty has so successfully created. We want a reinforcement of that norm and to create an environment in which there is an assumption of perpetuity about it, so that those states which might be minded to succumb to the temptation of going down the proliferation path will not be doing so with any other belief than that the NPT regime will be permanent.

We see the indefinite extension as also providing the most stable environment for peaceful nuclear cooperation programs, which has always been the other side of the NPT equation. That is essential for major power and research reactor programs, which do require long-term assurances extending over four or five decades from both suppliers and recipients. Senator Margetts, I know you cannot be expected to express any enthusiasm for the peaceful nuclear program; you do not accept it. But you do need to understand that was always part of the NPT trade-off formula.

The NPT has been criticised for legitimising the nuclear haves versus the have-nots. But all it was doing was recognising the reality that, at the time of the negotiation of that treaty, certain states—five of them—had acquired nuclear weapons prior to the establishment of the international consensus against their acquisition.

The final point I would make is that Australia very firmly stands behind the principle of the eventual elimination of nuclear weapons—absolutely and unequivocally. We supported a Japanese resolution to that effect in the United Nations recently. We have continued to urge the nuclear weapons states themselves to squarely embrace that, not just regard it as some kind of fanciful wish list. We do believe it will be very helpful indeed, for the success of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty renewal, for the nuclear weapons states to make a commitment to work towards the eventual elimination of nuclear weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't the minister's indication that the government is siding with the nuclear weapons states in this issue conflict with Australia's arms control policy? You mentioned a peaceful nuclear proliferation program; we are all aware that the NPT as it currently exists ensures the proliferation of nuclear material. Could it not be that you are endeavouring to ensure a future for Australian uranium exports?

—It is unequivocally not the case that Australia's position on this is one of `siding' with the nuclear weapons states, as you put it. There are many more countries around the world than the nuclear weapons states which see the advantages of indefinite extension of the NPT in exactly the same terms as we do—as creating a better environment for ensuring non-proliferation in those areas which do not have nuclear weapons at the moment, as well as creating a better environment for the nuclear weapons states themselves to negotiate further deep cuts, hopefully leading towards eventual elimination.

PARA.TAB: As to the peaceful program being a cover somehow for an intended nuclear future for Australia, I repeat that the truth of the matter is that peaceful nuclear cooperation was the price paid for support for the NPT. The developing countries and the non-nuclear countries all wanted assurances that they would be able to develop nuclear power and so on peacefully. They demanded that as the price of agreeing to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty itself. It is a crucial part of the equation, and that is the basis on which we are supporting that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to the fact that the government proposes to slash $280 million from the children's services budget.
—That is a lie.
—This represents over a quarter of its entire budget. Can the minister clarify where these cuts will occur?
—Order! There is a point of order.
—Are you going to get Senator Cook to withdraw that?
—Senator Cook, would you withdraw what you said?
—I withdraw.

—On a point of order: it is perfectly appropriate to demand that someone not call someone on the other side of the parliament or elsewhere a `liar'; that is perfectly the case. That was not the context in which that particular statement was made in this instance. Senator Cook was referring to a purported statement of fact as being a lie, not that anyone on that side was, in fact, a liar, because the document in question is not suggested to have originated from that side.
—Is Senator Evans canvassing your ruling? You have already ruled.
—I have already ruled. I think that sort of language is unseemly in this place, and that is why I asked Senator Cook to withdraw. I call Senator Troeth.
—Could I start my question again, Mr President?
—Yes.

—I refer to the fact that the government proposes to slash $280 million from the children's services budget. This represents over a quarter of its entire budget. Can the minister clarify where these cuts will occur? Will it be child care? Will it be assistance to sole parents? Will it be means testing the child-care rebate? Will it be operational subsidy to child-care centres or their capital grants? Isn't this just another example of the turmoil and confusion caused by your government to Australian parents who, day by day, are losing the capacity to plan their budgets and their personal lives?

—On a point of order: would Senator Troeth table the document from which she is quoting and which is the source of this outrageous allegation that she is making as if it were truth? Will she table it?
—There is no point of order.
—I have already spoken in this place about questions that are canvassing and trawling across possible things that may or may not be in the budget. About those matters, I have nothing to say.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I was very pleased the other evening while watching television to see a very moving advertisement featuring people who had recently taken out Australian citizenship. I assume that the advertisement is part of a new stage of the citizenship promotion campaign. Can you inform the Senate of the objectives of that campaign, and what results have so far been achieved?
—I thank Senator Chris Evans for raising this question. He is spot on that the government has—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you want to know about citizenship? The issue that Senator Evans raises was a major focus for Australia Day this year. It is part of an ongoing campaign that the government has been running for some time. The new ads that you did see, Senator Evans, are part of the second phase of that campaign.

PARA.TAB: The campaign has been running successfully. In fact, more than 11,000 people became Australian citizens on Australia Day. As a consequence of the promotions on that day, the number of queries the department received the next day was double the daily average. The promotion has been going for some time and there was a big focus on Australia Day. We are now embarking upon a new phase in the campaign, involving new television ads—the ones that you noticed—as well as ads in other aspects of the media.

The second part of the campaign builds on the first part by interviewing those who took up citizenship in the first part of the campaign. The ads that have been developed as part of the second phase pick up some of the concerns that those people raised, in fact some of the aspirations that those people decided they would meet by taking out Australian citizenship.

In terms of the new phase of the campaign which started a few days ago, I should say that on the first working day after the new ads were shown the telephone inquiry line received 1,300 calls and more than half of the people who called asked for application kits to be sent to them immediately. It is not just a TV campaign; it will be run in ethnic and suburban newspapers as well. The campaign will be officially launched this weekend in Melbourne at Station Pier, a place where the first postwar migrants from Britain and Europe disembarked some half a century ago.

Senator Evans, your question also gives me the opportunity to focus on the success of the overall campaign so far. Though we are only halfway through it, I can say that the response from the community continues to be extremely encouraging. When Prime Minister Keating and I announced last November that we aimed to encourage a substantial proportion of the 1.1 million or so eligible permanent residents to take up citizenship we anticipated running a campaign, but we did not anticipate the success of the campaign.

Since the telephone hotline has been part of the overall campaign, it has taken nearly 42,200 calls and a total of 25,800 people have actually lodged formal applications with my department. More than 80 per cent of those new applicants have stated that they were prompted by the advertisements to take this important step. Senator Evans, you were right to focus on the new phase of the campaign which started a few days ago. The government believes that the money we are spending in this area is well spent and the community response I think reflects that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I refer the minister to his answer yesterday to Senator Zakharov's dorothy dix question concerning the Russian space project. Is the minister aware that the Australian Space Council's agenda document, dated 12 December last year, confirms that there will be very little Australian involvement in the Russian launch of the mobile start missile—a converted ICBM—on Australian soil? Is it the case that in October last year the Australian Space Office was warned that relations between the United States and Australia would be `sorely tested' if the issue of missile technology transfers was raised in the absence of definite proposals? Will the minister give an assurance that Australia will not breach its conditions under the existing missile technology control regime agreement should it proceed with the proposed Russian launch?

—It is quite clear that Senator Chapman is at least six years out of date. He still thinks the Iron Curtain exists and that behind it is the Soviet Union. Nevertheless, to answer the last part of the question relating to Australia maintaining its commitment to various international treaties that affect international missile testing arrangements, control measures and so on, of course Australia will maintain all its obligations. We have been up-front for a number of years in seeking to be part of and in support of those obligations. Anything the Space Office does will be in accordance with those international obligations. That has always been made clear from the very beginning.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the remarks about the potential of certain Russian companies interested in developing a space launch capacity in Australia, I announced yesterday that those two Russian companies will have representatives in Australia in the near future—I think next week—to have discussions with the Australian Space Office regarding the feasibility of such proposals. None of those discussions contravene any of our obligations under international treaties.

Whatever those discussions lead to, one of the criteria of those discussions will be the fullest possible participation of Australian industry. Initially it may mean that there may not be a high level of Australian participation even if the first launch of it did take place in Australia. But we would not agree to a first launch if we knew that there were not going to be successive launches with high levels of developed Australian industry participation. That is the whole theme of the Australian Space Office, the Space Council, and its five-year program adopted by a range of people who are involved in both space science and space industry. That has been the unanimous view of the Space Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I call the minister's attention to an answer given during question time last week by his colleague the Minister for Defence on the subject of arms sales to Indonesia. I ask the Minister: how does he justify his own approval in-principle to the export of arms, regardless of the quantity, to a country with a human rights record as poor as Indonesia's? Is it the case that officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade advised against the decision to sell rifles to the Indonesian military and that Australia is now at odds with the United States, which has deliberately restricted arms sales to Indonesia precisely because of its poor human rights record? Finally, can the Minister guarantee that human rights concerns will be the prime consideration in future arms sales to Indonesia, especially as Indonesia has now indicated in a media release dated 23 January 1995 that it would consider future arms purchases from Australia?

—Since misunderstandings seem to continue on this subject, let me remind the Senate of the facts of the matter as set out in Senator Ray's statement in this place last week. The government of Indonesia has never requested a substantial purchase of rifles from Australia, be it to the value of $100 million, $10 million or $1 million. ADI, the only producer of military rifles in Australia, has no intention of marketing the Steyr rifle in Indonesia on any kind of significant scale, again be it to the value of $100 million, $10 million or $1 million—the figures that we have variously seen thrown around. The approval in-principle granted by the government was related to the export of a very small number of rifles, probably of the order of 20 or so, for the purpose of trials and evaluation. Australian firms require this approval in-principle for even such a small number of rifles, and even then proposals for the actual sales, concrete sales, if that is in fact going to follow, are further examined on a case-by-case basis before a specific licence is granted—all as a result of our rigorous export controls.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the case that human rights considerations, including the possibility of the weapons in question being misused in a civilian human rights invading situation, are taken into account. They are taken into account at this stage and they are taken into account at every other stage of the process, but particularly when it gets to the concrete sale. So, in terms of the assurance that Senator Bourne seeks, I can say that human rights concerns would certainly figure in any consideration of possible proposed defence exports to Indonesia, whether of rifles or of anything else.

The administrative process by which this is done, if I can just add something to what Senator Ray said last week, is as follows: controls in the export of defence and related goods provide for all applications where there are or might be foreign or strategic policy interests to be referred to the standing interdepartmental committee. In this process every application is considered on a case-by-case basis and in reviewing cases within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which has an input into this process, applications are routinely referred to the human rights section and to other relevant sections and departmental recommendations, of course, consequently do take account of human rights considerations. Beyond that I do not think there is anything more I can say. It is about time this particular matter was put once and for all politely to rest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Enviropnment, Sport and Recreation. Is the minister aware of calls by the Australian swimming coaches and swimmers for a boycott of international meets in which the Chinese swimmers compete or an outright ban on Chinese participation as a result of a series of positive drug tests on Chinese swimmers, many of whom actually beat Australians out of medals at the recent world championships? Is the minister also aware that Dr Ken Fitch, the chairman of the Australian Sports Commission's medical panel and a member of the IOC medical commission, described as `a total joke' the penalty handed out to an Australian weight-lifter found guilty of using a banned drug? In view of your repeated undertakings to the Senate that you are committed to rubbing out drug use in sport, will the government now support the recommendation of the Senate's drugs in sport inquiry to establish an independent tribunal to impose penalties so that Australia's leadership role in encouraging international compliance with strict enforcement of drug free sport is not compromised by the embarrassment of the weight-lifting fiasco?

—I am aware of many of the events that Senator Campbell raises in his question. Eleven Chinese athletes tested positive to the use of the banned anabolic steroid dihydrotestosterone following tests taken at the recent Asian Games in Hiroshima. I am informed that the testing was conducted under the control of the Olympic Council of Asia. The council announced in December 1994 that seven of the 11 Chinese athletes testing positive were swimmers. One was a track and field athlete, one was a cyclist and two were canoeists. The Chinese Swimming Federation banned those seven swimmers for two years. This sanction is consistent with the IOC recommended sanctions. The remaining athletes were banned for periods consistent with their respective international federation sanctions.

PARA.TAB: The Chinese Olympic Committee announced that it will hold an investigation into the matter. I am awaiting news of that investigation. I understand that the tests leading to the positive results were initiated by the international swimming federation, FINA. I remind Senator Campbell that I wrote to FINA last year strongly expressing our concerns about the lack of effective international anti-doping programs and, in particular, the need for worldwide, out of competition testing to be conducted. What has occurred with the Chinese swimmers in no way compromises our anti-doping agreement with China. In fact, it reinforces the need for agreements like that. It is really important to place emphasis on out-of-competition testing.

Australia's reputation in this regard is second to none internationally. I can certainly say to Senator Campbell that the Australian Sports Commission was very concerned about some aspects of a hearing and investigation conducted by the Australian Weightlifting Federation into a positive test returned by a weight-lifter.

This investigation reported in September 1994 and formally put the AWF on notice that specific actions needed to be taken in respect of drugs in sports matters. These were to obtain prior agreement from the ASC in respect of making appointments to hearing committees; inform the weight-lifter that the consequence under the AWF policy of second offence is a life ban; investigate the supply of banned drugs to weight-lifters and take appropriate disciplinary action against any persons found to have contributed to doping infractions; amend the Australian Weightlifting Federation's doping policy to ensure that inadvertent usage will not negate appropriate sanctions; institute an aggressive education information program in conjunction with ASDA to ensure that athletes are not ignorant of the AWF policy or the consequences of taking banned drugs; and develop a procedure for investigating medical problems and therapeutic treatment utilising a medical advisory panel.

As Senator Campbell knows, the ASC is going to review the AWF's progress in these matters. The AWF has demonstrated a commitment to fighting drugs in sport. It has imposed maximum penalties on athletes returning positive tests for anabolic steroids.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for saying that. It actually shows that he understands the issues. The main point of the question was whether he will now back the drugs in sport inquiry's recommendation to have an independent tribunal so that sports do not judge their own sportsmen and their drug use. It was a very crucial part of that inquiry's recommendation. I want the minister to say whether he will rule it out or reconsider it in light of the importance of Australia's international credibility, which I have no doubt about.

—I am happy to look again at that recommendation that was made by the committee. I am also willing to ask ASDA, the Australian Sports Drug Agency, and the Australian Sports Commission also to look again at that recommendation.

PARA.TAB: I can assure you, Senator, that we do continually evaluate the effectiveness of our anti-doping program. There is no doubt that we need to continue to do that, but it is acknowledged in the international community that the sports drug policy in Australia is not just among the best in the world but is the best in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the minister aware of media reports about the detection of an exotic pest known as the changa mole cricket?
—We heard about it on the radio this morning.

—I am concerned about the people in primary industry in this country. The reports have compared its destructive ability with the cane toad and claim the destruction it wreaks on lawns is the plant kingdom's equivalent of flesh-eating disease. Can the minister assure the primary producers that reports of this insect's destructive ability on commercial crops have been wildly exaggerated, like some of the claims you lot over there make?
—Are you fully across your brief?
—Senator Kemp, you would not know a changa mole cricket if you fell over one.
—What does it look like?

—There is actually a very good photograph of it in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald. At one end it has a short, fat body, like me, and at the other end it has a big, ugly boofhead containing a tiny brain, like Senator Ian Macdonald. But it is a serious matter which has alarmed primary producers.

PARA.TAB: The facts are, however—Senator Tierney might like to listen to this—that AQIS was informed by the CSIRO Division of Entomology on 2 February that specimens of insects causing serious damage to a golf course in Newcastle were identified as the changa mole cricket. It is a serious pest of turf, pasture, rice crop, sugarcane and vegetable seedlings.

After visiting the site of the infestation and comparing specimens of the pest with those already in the New South Wales Department of Agriculture at Rydalmere, it was concluded that the insect had probably been in Australia since 1982. The reason for the concern—and we have had a lot of concern in my office this morning—is it was reported as an outbreak of a new exotic pest in Australia. We think the reason for this mistake is that previous specimens collected from Williamtown in 1982 and Maitland in 1989 were misidentified at the time by New South Wales authorities as a native Australian cricket.

In cooperation with CSIRO, the Turf-grass Research Institute and the New South Wales Department of Agriculture, AQIS is now conducting surveys to establish the likely spread and the population levels of the pest before determining whether an eradication program would be feasible. Other states have now been informed of the nature and extent of the outbreak and all possible action will be taken to develop an appropriate control strategy.
The pest has now been in Australia for 13 years. While it is a serious problem, particularly for turf growers and for golf courses, Gareth—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a threat to golf courses, too.

—Yes, Gareth is more of a threat to a golf course than this cricket, probably. It does not appear to have affected any other commercial crops and comparisons with cane toads and flesh-eating diseases are obviously ridiculous. Primary industry at the moment does not have anything to fear about this pest.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Minister, do you agree that, with an aging population and the continued deinstitutionalisation of people with disabilities, it is critical that funding for the home and community care program is maintained at current levels at the very least? Will you give an unequivocal assurance that your government will not cut funding for HACC in the 1995-96 budget, as it has done in real terms for three out of the last four budgets? If you cannot or will not give that assurance, are you saying that the most vulnerable in our community will have to suffer more and more because of your government's mismanagement?
—Just like Senator Troeth's question, this trawls across speculation about the budget. Again, I have nothing to say.

—I am asking the minister to give a guarantee to the many people with disabilities and older Australians who have now suffered as a result of her government's failure to keep HACC funding up to a certain level that, with all these cuts that the government is proposing, they will not be the ones who suffer. I am asking the minister to give that guarantee now.
—That was a good try from the senator. She seems to be under clear instructions from Mr Robb. As I said, I have nothing to say on this matter.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I take objection to the minister saying that I am under instructions from Mr Robb. She knows very well that I have taken a keen interest in this area for many years. I will not have that said to me across the chamber.
—There is no point of order. You have time later to make a personal explanation if you want to.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I invite you to reconsider that ruling either now or later. The imputation that a senator conducts his or her duties under instruction from someone outside this place should be ruled disorderly. I invite you to reconsider your ruling.
—You know as well as I do, Senator Vanstone, that if people are aggrieved they have recourse to an explanation after question time.
—Mr President, they have recourse to you to keep order in this place as well. That is what you are for.

—Mr President, on the point of order: everyone knows that the Republic Advertising Agency has written a letter to Andrew Robb of the Liberal Party asking parliamentarians on the coalition side to scare recipients of our health and welfare schemes.
—Order! That is not a point of order.
—This letter is exactly in line with that. The letter states: `Surely the object to budget time is to make—
—Order! Senator Cook, there is no point of order, and you know it.
—Mr President—
—Order! You have made your statement. I think that is enough.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Minister, I understand that this morning you launched the Australian Information Industry Association's publication Agenda for Growth. It is an important publication which sets out the strategic direction for the industry. Given the significance of the information industry to Australia's economic performance, can the minister outline the nature of the industry's agenda and its assessment of the capabilities and the opportunities for Australia for the foreseeable future?
—Earlier today the Australian Information Industry Association launched its publication Agenda for Growth, which is a strategy booklet it has prepared.
—Does it mention Andrew Robb?

—It has nothing to do with Andrew Robb, Senator Bolkus—this is a successful industry. Agenda for Growth sets out how the association intends to go about building, with the help of the government, the information industry sector in Australia. Of course, as senators would know, this is a key sector which is critical to Australia's growth and prosperity. After all, Australia has the second largest information technology and telecommunications market share in the Asia-Pacific after Japan.

PARA.TAB: Australia has an information technology and telecommunications market twice the size that of Korea, and it is seven times larger than the markets in Singapore, Hong Kong and Malaysia. It must be remembered that market growth in this industry sector is very strong in the whole of the region. Our proximity to those markets provides Australia with a real competitive advantage.

What I find most pleasing in this report is the strong focus the industry itself has chosen to put on exports. That is because it is a successful exporting industry pledged to doing better. This industry sector earned in exports for Australia over the last year $2.6 billion. The industry has set a target to reach $10 billion in export and foreign earnings by the year 2000.

It might be said that $10 billion is the combined size of the coal and iron ore exports of Australia. If the industry succeeds, it would be a great result for this country. A decade ago information industry exports were under four per cent of the coal and iron ore exports. This is a rapidly growing, high technology industry right at the cutting edge.

One of the main drivers for this enormous growth is the government's partnerships for development program, which encourages international information and technology and telecommunication firms to expand and invest in Australia. The program also encourages Australian firms to enter into productive export oriented alliances with international companies. When the Bureau of Industry Economics releases its scorecard on the partnerships program later this month, I am sure you will see that there has been a very positive performance by that program. It has stimulated a very positive performance by this industry.

The program's successes have in part contributed to overseas business leaders recognising Australia's capability in building and delivering innovative IT&T products and services. Thanks to these strengths, Australia can now claim competitive advantages in many areas, including software development, professional services and local and wide area networking. For our part, we will be working with this very dynamic industry in the future to achieve its vision.

World leadership in the use of IT&T for our competitive advantage is within our grasp. International recognition of our excellence in IT&T applications and systems is growing strongly. Exports of $10 billion a year by the year 2000 would be a significant presence in this global market. In fact, our future does look very bright here. This is a dynamic industry, succeeding on behalf of this nation in this dynamic market of the world and more broadly around the globe.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. The minister would be aware that from 1 December 1994 it has been necessary to obtain prior approval from the Health Insurance Commission for all PBS authority required items. Can the minister explain why, with the new authority prescribing, some doctors on some days are having great difficulty or at times are unable to obtain authority script approval via the free-call service? This is despite the statement in the national health schedule book that there is a 24-hour, seven-day-a-week service.

—I thank you for your question, Senator. I think senators would know, as you say, that since last year all authority prescriptions issued under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme now need prior approval by the Health Insurance Commission. First of all, it applies to certain products to ensure that they are used appropriately and, secondly, it very clearly applies to new drugs and, when drugs are very expensive, cost-effective drugs.
—It is nice to hear you answer a question for a change.

—Just wait, Senator. You will get your answer in a moment. I am answering Senator Watson's question. The Health Insurance Commission did set in place very considerable resources to provide for the efficient 24-hour telephone approval and/or any authority requests that came by mail. The Health Insurance Commission makes clear that it underestimated the phone applications and overestimated the mail applications, or at least it certainly had concern that there were not sufficient resources to deal with the phone applications.

PARA.TAB: On the advice that I have been given the Health Insurance Commission, being very aware of the difficulty, introduced extra staff and new phone arrangements. So the delay was largely dealt with. If that is still not the case, I will certainly see whether there is anything further to check or provide for you. But the delays were recognised by the Health Insurance Commission. It is important to reassure consumers and doctors that that concern is understood by the Health Insurance Commission. If those circumstances and arrangements are still not sufficient at the moment, I will see whether there is anything further I can provide for you.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Can the minister inform the Senate whether any difficulties are being experienced in relation to the protocol on homeless youth between the Commonwealth and the states and territories?

—I thank Senator Neal for this question. Senators would know that there was a new protocol introduced in about October last year between the Commonwealth, state and territory governments to deal with the problem of how best to manage young homeless allowance applicants. There certainly were cases raised in this place and we know of requests into our offices of concern about the management of the youth homeless allowance.

PARA.TAB: The protocol agreed between the Commonwealth and the states particularly applies to three groups of people—under-15-year-olds, wards and others in protective care, and 15- to 17-year-olds at imminent risk of violence or abuse. From October to December over 660 young people were referred to the states and territories and over 80 per cent of those referred were under 15. Since that time there has been industrial action in both New South Wales and Western Australia that has led to considerable difficulties in implementing this new protocol to deal with the youth homeless allowance and with young people who may be in those sorts of difficulties vis-a-vis relationships with their family.

In New South Wales the work ban has been lifted, but Minister Longley's department has said that it would only respond to cases referred under the protocol `when all other work demands had been met'. This was published in the Public Service Association of New South Wales minutes to members dated 1 December 1994. The Commonwealth is also concerned and is still yet to be convinced that the protocol arrangements in Western Australia are operating effectively. The protocol recognises that the states and territories have primary responsibility for young people at risk. If these arrangements are not working satisfactorily, then most vulnerable young people can be forced into highly unsatisfactory living arrangements.

The Senate will be interested to note that, for example, a 15-year-old boy from Sydney's outer west was referred to the Department of Community Services for assessment. He is unable to live in the parental home due to irreconcilable breakdown caused by a long history of family disharmony. The Department of Community Services in New South Wales placed him in a refuge but was not prepared to provide any other support. The young person needs money for books, a school uniform and other ongoing living matters. The New South Wales government seems to be of the opinion that it does not matter at all and that it is not its responsibility.

The New South Wales government believes that, because it funds refuges through the supported accommodation assistance program in conjunction with the Commonwealth, it does not have to do anything other than to see that this person is into a shelter. That is not the terms of the protocol and the Commonwealth is very concerned that the states, particularly New South Wales and Western Australia, seem not to be interested in implementing their part of this protocol for young people.

The Commonwealth government has contacted both the New South Wales and the Western Australian governments. The Western Australian government replied that it is very concerned and supports the protocol. New South Wales has failed to reply. In this place on occasions we have had passionate concern about the young homeless allowance and the problem it creates for young people. Ongoing concern by the Department of Social Security, but also in response to those sorts of concerns, allowed the governments to come up with a protocol late last year. Two governments are actually ignoring that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time Senator Crowley said that my question was in response to a direction from Mr Andrew Robb of the Liberal Party headquarters. I found that offensive and totally inappropriate. Senator Crowley knows, as does every senator in this chamber, that I have asked questions about aged care and about the home and community care program nearly every sitting week since I came into this parliament. It was not directed or influenced by Mr Robb; it was influenced by the fact that today there was a statement in the newspaper that intimated that the Labor Party was thinking about reducing HACC funding. It has reduced it in real terms for three out of the last four budgets. My concern was that the government will continue to reduce it—maybe by even more, given that leak—and I was moved to ask a question. I have not had any contact or any correspondence with Mr Robb or any direction from any leader of my party. I found what Senator Crowley said inappropriate and offensive. Mr President, will you ask her to withdraw it?
—You have made your personal explanation. I cannot judge the truth or otherwise of any of these accusations.
