SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Chapman this day, relating to space launch capacities in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It has become increasingly clear that the minister either does not understand the key issues or is misleading the parliament and the public about the process which is being entered into with the Russian and Australian space proposal currently under consideration.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Space Council's own agenda paper, presented by the executive director, Mr Malcolm Farrow, dated 12 December 1994, clearly supports the concerns I have raised publicly and in this place and, furthermore, creates a dispute about the answers given by the minister. I quote from a copy of the leaked document, which follows a recent overseas visit undertaken by the executive director to assess the feasibility of establishing a light launch vehicle site and ongoing operation in Australia. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Russian companies, in general, expressed the most interest in launching from Australia. Both STC Complex (the developer of the START rockets, which are converted ICBM's) and Energomash (manufacturers of all Russian first stage rocket engines) proposed joint ventures with Australian industry to establish launch service operations in Australia.

STC Complex has proposed a joint venture project to launch the START family of LLVs from Australia. They have a virtually autonomous launch system which would require very little infrastructure beyond the provision of a suitable site. If the technical and economic aspects proved feasible and attractive a launch service could be up and running in a very short space of time once the decision to go ahead was made. It would require relatively little start up capital.
There would be very little Australian content in the first instance but it could be a good way of gaining early entry into, and experience of, the market, for a relatively small amount of capital.

Additional material provided to me highlights the growing concern within the United States about the possible transfer of sensitive missile technology under the MTCR agreement. It is clear that Australia is heavily reliant upon the United States for the importing of rocket motors, guidance systems and the like.

PARA.TAB: I wonder what concerns the United States Department of Defense may have, given Australia's negotiations on this matter with Russia, a country that the minister himself knows is not a signatory to the MTCR agreement. That is the real issue. That is the concern: Russia's non-compliance with the MTCR agreement. It is nothing to do with reds under the bed, as the minister mockingly tries to suggest and scoffs about. Does the minister question that Russia remains a relatively unstable country and that it is not a signatory to this important agreement and that therefore relationships with it in this area are quite risky? This document further states:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be fool-hardy, however, to believe that the transfer of Category I items—
that is, rocket motors and guidance systems, et cetera—
would be a `lay down misere'. The US Department of Defence position is that presumption to deny means `no transfer to anyone for any reason at anytime!'
The document further states:
. . . US goodwill towards Australia would be sorely tested if the issue of technology transfer is raised in the absence of definite proposals.

What we have seen is Australia wanting to secure sensitive missile technology from the United States under the MTCR agreement while at the same time encouraging the Russians to enter into a joint venture with Australia.

PARA.TAB: The minister really is playing with fire in this instance. If he proceeds with this bizarre proposal without adequate protection, he is likely to get burnt as he has indeed been when he has proceeded with other proposals without adequate consideration. We remember the Australian Institute of Marine Science and his problems with the customs department. This minister is accident prone. I urge the minister to give very careful consideration to this Russian proposal, given the serious implications it could have for Australia's involvement in the MTCR, not to mention Australia's relations with the United States.

The establishment of the MTCR was clearly designed to protect sensitive missile technology. There is considerable concern within the industry groups about the impact this Russian project could have upon future United States-Australia relations. The minister must come clean with what he is proposing and stop hiding behind the shroud of secrecy that he ha until now imposed on this project. He has been caught out by the admissions of his own department. The potential for Australia's participation in the launch of missiles should not be jeopardised. It is an important part of our future and it ought not to be jeopardised by this minister's incompetence.

I want to repeat the main issue to the minister so that it is quite clear. The main issue is that the MTCR agreement precludes Russia and, therefore, any negotiations with Russia prior to it becoming a signatory. Any negotiations with Russia place Australia's relations with its allies at substantial risk. It is a risk that the minister ought not be taking. I urge him to reconsider it. I also seek leave to table the document from which I quoted.
Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is now the third or fourth time in this chamber—it is certainly the third time—in the last two days when Senator Chapman has spoken, asked a question and spoken again. He has made the most extraordinary accusations that somehow Australia is going to be in breach of international treaties which we have signed by having a feasibility study done with two Russian companies that have shown interest in being able to provide a launch facility in Australia for low earth-orbiting satellites.

PARA.TAB: I want to point out to Senator Chapman that the very same Russian companies are in discussions with and, quite openly and quite transparently, have provided assistance to a range of European, Asian and North American companies. We are not the only country to have discussions with the Russians and we are not the only country with which the Russian companies have sought to have discussions.

I do not know where the feasibility study will lead over the next few months. However, it was the advice to me from the Executive Director of the Australian Space Office—with, as I understand it, the support of the Australian Space Council—that this discussion and these negotiations with the Russians should take place and should be funded by the Space Office. I have agreed to that advice.

All the papers you quote do is point out the facts. I do not deny that the Russians and the Americans may have some differences of opinion. But we are a sovereign country. We will make our own decisions on what is in our best national and commercial interest. We will weigh that up in conjunction with information we get and consultations we have with countries such as the United States, Russia and any other country. We made that very clear from the beginning.

You are on what I would call a `beat-up purpose' here. You are trying to drag it out as though Russia is still some part of the old Soviet Union and the Cold War is still going. That is what you are on about. What I am surprised about, Senator Chapman, is that three or four years ago you signed, like I did, the major recommendations, unanimous recommendations as they were, of the Senate committee on transport dealing with space launch facilities in Australia. All I have been doing as a minister is carrying out the thrust and the principles of that report, which I thought you and the Senate would have been very pleased about.

We are looking at every possibility to get a commercially viable space launch activity going in Australia. Certainly, we have to look at all the opportunities, not just those in the United States. They may not choose to provide us with some of their technology. The Russians may choose not to provide us with some of their technology. If that is the case, so be it. We will negotiate our best opportunities for Australia's interest. I can assure you that in doing so we will abide by all the international treaties that we have signed. That is certainly the policy of this government. To suggest that the Space Office itself is going off on its own venture without cognisance of these treaty obligations is absolutely without foundation. I certainly understand all those obligations and they will be met.

However, I think we would be stupid to ignore an opportunity that could occur after these discussions and studies with these two Russian companies. If it transpires at the end of those studies that we would be in transgression of any international treaty, then that would be the end of those opportunities. But to write them off before we even have a chance to discuss them or find out what they are offering or what the opportunities are for Australian industry is absurd. We in no way compromise—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not a signatory to the treaty.
—Yes, and those matters will be taken into account in this study over the next few months. If it turns out that in the end that is a problem, we will make our decision accordingly.

PARA.TAB: What you want us to do, based on Cold War rhetoric, is to say, `The Russians are the Russians' or, `The Soviets are the Soviets. There is something risky about them; ignore them.' In doing so, you may be limiting Australia's opportunity to re-enter and develop a commercial space industry in this country. It would be typical of the opposition to cut off its nose to spite its face. You can do it to yourself, but you are not going to do it to an important Australian industry that has considerable potential and is fully supported by Australian space industry companies who also support these feasibility studies taking place.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services, to a question without notice asked by Senator Troeth this day, relating to funding for children's services.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to be taking note of an answer in which the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) said that she had nothing to say. I think the fact that the minister had nothing to say proves the significance of what I was asking. She maintained that she could neither confirm nor deny the substance of my question. Yet Senator Cook called the substance of my question a lie. I can only presume that he has superior knowledge to that of the minister in charge of the department.

PARA.TAB: Both Senator Cook and Senator Crowley may be interested to know that my information was taken from a report on page 1 of today's Australian which spoke of possible cuts and mentioning an amount of $280 million from children's services. To put the lie to Senator Cook's description of what was stated in my question as being a lie, I direct attention to the words of a spokeswoman of the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, who confirmed that the leaked figures were budget proposals from economic bureaucrats. So I would presume—and I am sure the Senate would presume—that they must be on the government's agenda for budget cuts. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has also refused to comment on these possible budget cuts. This whole attitude by the government simply creates turmoil for families.

At the start of this new year of 1995, Australian families in many cases are preparing for parents to take up new careers or jobs which entail child-care arrangements for their families; and, at the same time, child-care centres are planning their staffing commitments and the way in which they will operate in the new year of 1995. What are they to make of these extremely conflicting reports coming from government sources that there will be a means test on the child-care rebate, there may be a more stringent means test on the home child care-allowance, and so on? No-one knows what is going on.

On Tuesday there was no answer from Senator Crowley on the matter of child-care rebate means testing. Once again, we have a classic policy division and another nasty choice for the Prime Minister. In the logging debate which took place last week, we saw the government having to make a very nasty choice between the demands of the logging and forestry industries and the demands of the environmental industry. The Labor Party cannot please either of them—and, from its present intensive efforts, it still appears to be pleasing neither side.

In exactly the same way, Mr Keating and Senator Crowley appear to be caught between the femocrats in the Prime Minister's office and Dr Lawrence who maintain that child care should be seen as a work related expense—and this view is shared by the Womens Electoral Lobby—and the views of their other supposed allies, such as Martin Ferguson from the ACTU who thinks the child-care allowance should be means tested. Presumably Mr Beazley and Mr Willis, who are keen to adopt programs which will do something about cutting the enormous government deficit, also would be in favour of means testing.

The coalition has claimed from the start that these programs should have been better targeted. The fact that the government of Senator Crowley and Mr Keating made these promises and is now prepared to walk away from them is symptomatic of the way that the government is treating the families of Australia.

In 1994, we have the child-care rebate non-means tested. In 1995, the same question comes up again. We have no comment from the Prime Minister, we have no answer from Senator Crowley, and we have cautious kite flying from Mr Beazley and, I would suspect, later in the day from Mr Willis. So I say to the Senate that Senator Crowley's intimation that she has nothing to say is indeed symptomatic of the attitude of the whole Labor government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me give Senator Troeth the benefit of the doubt for the moment and accept that in that intervention she is not adopting the Robb instruction or the advertising agency's suggestion to argue in accordance with the proposition that `the object till budget time is to make every welfare recipient feel like they're about to lose it. And if they don't lose it this time, they'll lose it next time'—one of the more contemptible instructions or political doctrines that any of us have seen in our political memories. I will work on the assumption that she does not mean that and that, for the present purposes, she is acting not in accordance with that but is acting in accordance with her own fundamental misconception about the budgetary process. I suppose that is not surprising. She has not been in government and has no realistic expectation of getting there, so it is not unreasonable that she should not have devoted any attention to understanding the way the budget process works.

PARA.TAB: She refers to this purported cut as being `on the agenda for budget cuts'. Let me say very clearly to Senator Troeth just this: in any budget process, whoever is in government, a whole plethora of documents is prepared. Everybody has a wish list for spending; everybody has a wish list for cuts. Most of those wish lists are prepared deep inside the bowels of departments without ministers even seeing them before they get into some kind of circulation.

This budget is no different from any other budget in the history of this country in the way that the preliminary skirmishing, manoeuvring and preparation of wish lists proceed. These documents and wish lists—and I am making no concession that the particular document that you are referring to exists; I have no idea what its status might be or whether there is a bit of paper—do not have any authority. The vast bulk of them will not only not be adopted on either the expenditure side of the equation or the revenue side of the equation, but will not even appear on the agenda of the expenditure review committee or the revenue committee of cabinet as the case may be.

A lot of crazy stuff originates from departments on the expenditure wish list side. A lot of crazy stuff, I have to acknowledge, comes on the other side of the equation every year from within the bowels of the finance department. I have been a member of the ERC. I have seen these things; most of them are just nonsense, and their perpetrators do not expect them to see the light of the day. That is the way the budget process works. These things do not have any status whatsoever unless and until they are seriously considered by the formal processes at senior ministerial level and, of course, until they are adopted.

So please let us not have any more of this waving around of bits and pieces that might fall off the bottom and back of trucks, because, I repeat, the overwhelming majority of them do not have any chance of even being seriously considered, let alone adopted. That is what Senator Crowley was effectively saying in the way in which she responded to you. Of course, it is the case that, when any bit of paper is waved around in this context, we do not confirm or deny its status. To do that in the context of a budget preparation would lead you very quickly into a maze.

It does not mean anything to neither confirm nor deny that something is the case. It is simply a matter of the age-old approach that, once you start confirming or denying something, people start drawing their own conclusions about things that you have not adopted that formula in relation to. By and large, we maintain that particular approach; it is without significance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) this day, relating to forest management.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate asked a very straightforward question of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) in relation to certain forestry coupes in Tasmania and what occurred in discussions between Paul Lennon and the federal government. In his answer the minister asserted that basically he knew nothing about it and was not going to comment. It would appear that the only person that does not know about this intervention over the head of Senator Faulkner is the minister himself. Let me remind the Senate what Paul Lennon told the
Tasmanian parliament:
It was my intervention, not to Senator Faulkner but directly to the Prime Minister's office, which saw the number reduced to 72. He—
he is referring to you, Minister—
can say what he likes, Faulkner has been shown for what Faulkner is in this debate.
Paul Lennon, the Labor forestry spokesman in Tasmania, received a letter from industry congratulating him, which said in part:
I understand you played a key role in ensuring that the number of coupes to be set aside by the Commonwealth of Tasmania has been reduced by about 40 per cent.

That is a letter that Paul Lennon quoted in Tasmanian parliament last night when boasting about his activities in reducing the number of coupes. It appears as though the forest industry knows about his success. Paul Lennon undoubtedly does because he is quoting it and very proud of it, yet the minister asserts that he does not know what is going on. The only bright light in the whole debate is that Senator Faulkner has been frozen out and people above and beyond him are now dealing with the problem and, hopefully, resolving it.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that the Labor Party, and especially this minister, is in an absolute mess over the forest issue. We have seen in this place the resignation of Senator Devereux from the parliamentary Labor Party. Senator Faulkner is potentially responsible for the resignation of another five people from the parliamentary Labor Party and for the inter- and intra-factional warfare that is taking place within his own political party. It is amazing that such a non-entity as a junior Labor spokesman for forestry in Tasmania is able to roll Senator Faulkner, the federal minister for environment, by going directly to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). If ever a Prime Minister has given a vote of no confidence in one of his ministers, I would have thought that this is a classic example.

Paul Lennon's involvement, along with that of a whole host of other people, is well known. It is known by industry, it is known by the Labor opposition in Tasmania, it is known by everybody in Tasmania what the difficulty is. Later on in the debate in the Tasmanian parliament last evening, when the government was attacking Mr Lennon and the Labor Party, he tried to deflect some of the attack by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: A problem does not exist here. It exists in Canberra. That is where the problem exists.

He was referring again to the Labor government and to its complete mishandling of this whole issue. It is simply not good enough that the minister for the environment has come in here in question time after question time for the past fortnight and been completely incapable of or unable to answer questions of substance going to the very heart of this very important matter which is affecting the lives of thousands of Australians in regional parts of our great country.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to greenhouse gases.

SPEECH.PARA: The energy card is a document which has $6 million worth of government funding lying behind it. The intention is to address the problem of greenhouse through the installation of solar hot water services. The point of my question was that over 12 months into the scheme not one single solar hot water service has been put on one single house in Australia. The gist of the minister's reply to my question was that the scheme was all ready to go and the two private companies that were providing the backup money, to which the $6 million was seed money, had a change of management at the last minute and backed away from the scheme.

PARA.TAB: Minister Collins began his remarks by pointing to the observation by the IPCC that the consequences of greenhouse gas emissions will not be fully felt for several centuries. That is perfectly true, but I believe that it is rather dangerous for the minister, and through the minister, the government, to put that sort of information on the table in the way in which the minister did because it seems to imply—and I think it was the minister's intention to imply—that therefore we could ignore an attack on greenhouse for another number of decades or perhaps centuries. But, as the IPCC itself points out, while the consequences of greenhouse may be many centuries in arriving, there is such a momentum in this process that we need to address it very quickly to turn it around so that those consequences—decades or centuries in the future—will be less than they would otherwise be. We certainly do not know what those consequences as yet will be. It is for that reason also that we need to be rather cautious about the way we approach this matter and reduce our greenhouse gas emissions as quickly as possible.

The energy card and the delay which has accompanied any spending of that $6 million is not unique. When we negotiated with the government for the ethanol bounty scheme, ethanol to be used in transport fuels, also as a measure to address greenhouse, accompanying that was $4 million which was going into research funding. I learnt just this morning that well over 12 months down the track the government has spent $200,000 out of that $4 million doing studies to find out how to spend the money and that not one dollar of that money has found its way into actual research work which will address the serious problem of greenhouse gas emissions in the transport area, an area from where a large amount of Australia's greenhouse gases come.

So while the government is prepared to move ahead speedily in many other areas, it is tardy in this important greenhouse area. We have seen, for instance, that the government is prepared to move on the national electricity grid, but nowhere at all has it imposed on the state electricity utilities, or the private companies which are superseding them, the requirement that energy efficiency should be one of their criteria. The problem with state electricity utilities for many years has been that they have been charged with the supply of electricity. The simple manoeuvre necessary is to ensure that they no longer be electricity suppliers but the suppliers of end-use energy services at least cost. If that were done, and that is what has happened with some of the American utilities, it would be cheaper for the electricity utilities to supply solar hot water services rather than continue to try—as we have seen recently with ETSA in South Australia, with the electricity supply authority here in Canberra and with the electricity utilities in New South Wales—to sell more and more electricity competitively rather than supply the service of hot water through the least cost mechanism.

The federal government, as it has done in the forestry industry, can exercise control through export and import controls. One thing which the federal government could easily have done is say to the utilities that they cannot import any more heavy generating electricity equipment until such a change is made.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a submission received by the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee relating to its inquiry into rural adjustment, rural debt and rural reconstruction. The committee invited this submission pursuant to privilege resolution 1(13) relating to adverse comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BROWNHILL

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, from 288 citizens, which is not in conformity with the standing orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: RE: THE AVIATION SAFETY AUTHORITY
To my Federal M.H.R. and my Senators.
c.c. The Honourable the Minister for Transport and Communications.
Gentlemen,

PARA.TAB: The government is about to make an appointment which will have an impact on aviation in this country well into next century. The appointment is that of Head of the new Aviation Safety Authority.

I am a pilot member of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, and I want you to be aware that in my opinion Dick Smith is the right man for this job. Dick ran the CAA for two years, and those two years were amongst the safest ever for airline passengers in this country. What's more, the aviation environment steadily improved all the time that Dick was at the helm of the CAA. Above all, the long-standing adversarial attitude between the regulators and the regulated was watered down and the beginnings of a co-operative approach were seen.

Dick's cost-cutting achievement were outstanding—but they left, of course, a legacy of disaffected people. These people are now campaigning strongly to keep Dick Smith out of the job as head of the Aviation Safety Authority—because they realise he won't build a huge empire. But as one of those who will pay for the Aviation Safety Authority, a huge expensive empire is exactly what I don't want.

There is potential political advantage in creating a feather-bedded organisation with a non-demanding leader, because of the extra (unnecessary) jobs that it will create. I am writing this letter to make clear that there is also political disadvantage in doing so because others realize they will have to pay for those extra, unnecessary, jobs.

We're very fortunate to have amongst us a man as public-spirited as Dick Smith. It would be a great pity if we did not take advantage of his willingness to work selflessly on behalf of his fellow-citizens as the first head of the Aviation Safety Authority.
I remain, Sir/Madam, your humble constituent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may be aware that there has been a growing interest in, and demand for, public electronic access to parliamentary materials. At the request of the Presiding Officers, the parliamentary departments have been investigating ways to provide wider community electronic access to parliamentary materials. To this end, the parliamentary departments have been conducting a pilot service offering electronic access for Commonwealth agencies and state and territory parliaments to a range of parliamentary materials which form part of the parliamentary database. These include the Hansard of both houses, Journals of the Senate, Votes and Proceedings, the Notice Paper of both houses, the orders of business and the daily program.

PARA.TAB: An evaluation group was established to oversee the pilot service to Commonwealth agencies and was also asked to make recommendations on a long-term strategy to provide wider community electronic access to parliamentary materials. One of the evaluation group recommendations is likely to be that public access to parliamentary materials be provided through public libraries and community information networks to individuals via the Internet. This is a global network of databases and information sources about which we all know. The evaluation group has proposed that, before a final decision on the use of Internet is made, it should be tried for a period of six months. The trial will involve assistance from the Australian National University provided at no cost to the parliament.

Senators may be aware that a number of parliaments around the world and in Australia either use, or intend to use, the Internet to provide public access to parliamentary information and materials. The parliament of Australia Internet service to be provided by the parliamentary departments will offer the public of Australia electronic access to a wide range of parliamentary materials and will make the work of the Senate and the House more accessible. Mr Speaker and the President have agreed to a proposal from the evaluation group that the trial should commence with the autumn sittings.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AUTHORITY

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak on the documents that Senator Faulkner tabled earlier this afternoon at the end of question time.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Send the whip over to explain. We haven't been notified of it. We don't know what you are doing.
—It was done with Senator Faulkner. I thought he might have passed it on. I am quite happy to move that the standing orders be set aside. I seek leave to explain what I am doing.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner tabled some documents in response to a return to order. He did not table all the documents. He gave an excuse for why the second document was not tabled. I sought leave to move a motion that his answer in tabling be noted. I was told by the President that I would need to seek leave and that it should not be done then but after question time and after the period for taking note of answers was ended. Senator Faulkner was aware of that and wandered around. He did not seem to take much notice. I seek leave to speak about the matter. If leave is not granted, I will take other options.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It may be a misunderstanding, it may not have been communicated to me or it may not have been the case. We certainly will not give leave under the threat that other action will be taken such as a suspension of standing orders. I am trying to contact Senator Faulkner now to see what arrangements have been made. If the fault is at our end, we will apologise. But it is not normal to walk in and seek leave to comment on tabled documents some time after they have been tabled; you know that. It is not normal to grant leave for that.
—I wanted to comment then but everybody said to wait until after the period for taking note of answers.
—You might also indicate how long you will be and then we might sort this out. How long will you be?
—I will be 10 to 15 minutes.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I want to mention is that on 7 February the Senate passed a motion calling upon the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories to table a report entitled Review of Funding Arrangements for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. That has been tabled in accordance with the Senate's return to order.

PARA.TAB: The second document which the Senate sought to have tabled was the independent external review of environmental management charges which, according to page 30 of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park annual report, was due to be completed on 31 December 1994. Senator Faulkner said something about that. I must confess that I did not quite hear him as there were people speaking around me. He indicated, I think, that there was a draft report, that it had not been reviewed by the department but it would be tabled as soon as the department had reviewed it. I am not quite sure why.

Obviously if the document is not here it cannot be tabled, but I point out that the annual report of the authority indicated that it would be completed by 31 December 1994. It states `with a public document outlining the findings and recommendations to be published in the new year'. I am concerned that these arrangements are set out in the annual report and, in many instances, do not seem to have been complied with.

Having said that, I guess I can do nothing more than indicate that I require to see that report as soon as possible. It is a matter that is of great interest to the people of North and Far North Queensland and to all those interested in the Great Barrier Reef, and it should be made available as soon as possible.

The report that has been tabled contains some recommendations that are of major impact to users of the Great Barrier Reef. It indicates that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority needs more money, and I think that has been conceded for a long time. Unfortunately, the government chooses to starve the authority of funds when it is an authority that does a great job and should be properly and adequately funded from existing revenue.

Because the authority does not have funds, there have been these investigations into future funding arrangements. I notice that at page 29 the report indicates that the steering committee identified a number of initiatives the authority could pursue to improve its revenue stream by either extending its current charging regime or introducing new charges. It then indicates that the steering committee is looking at a marine park charge and goes on to explain that it is canvassing charging for resource rents as a source of revenue. To do that, it anticipates that it may obtain an income of some $3 million per annum. It will, I am sure, send shudders through the tourism industry in Far North Queensland if a resource rent is to be charged for activities that involve using the reef.

The report goes on to talk about the current environmental management charge which commercial users of the reef already pay, and for that there is quite a deal of income coming in. The report has indicated that for a $1 increase in the charge it would receive $1.4 million per annum, and the steering committee goes on to say that there would be great concern from commercial users of the Great Barrier Reef if this charge were imposed. From the short time I have had to look at this report, the committee seems to shy away from the charge and then states:

SPEECH.PARA: In view of these concerns, any decision to increase the environmental management charge would need to be a Commonwealth Government decision, not one taken by the Authority.

So this report is again throwing the responsibility onto Senator Faulkner's department to make a decision. Without having referred this to the people who use the reef, I am quite confident that I can say on their behalf that there should not be any increase which would simply be another tax on tourism in Far North Queensland. I imagine the tourist operators and the users of the Great Barrier Reef will fight that all the way.

PARA.TAB: This report then goes on to talk about a new environmental management charge. It suggests that there should be a new charge that is an extension of the environmental charge. That is not for just commercial operators, as is now the case; it is recommended that it be extended to recreational users and shipping. The report identifies that, for the 24,000 private boat registrations using the Great Barrier Reef, at a charge of $10 per annum the extension of this environmental charge would raise $240,000. Of this, 25 per cent apparently would go into administration, leaving $180,000. The report indicates that shipping would gain another $200,000 based on $100 per trip. The report says it is not recommending $10 per annum or $100 per trip for shipping; it is just using those figures to indicate what would be raised from those sorts of amounts.

The report further indicates that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority needs something like $2 million to continue operating. If you are going to get that from the recreational users, that $10 per annum, which would return $180,000 per annum, would have to be increased to something like many hundreds of dollars. That is of great concern to private boat owners and recreational boat owners in the Great Barrier Reef. Whilst I have only just received this report and have not had time to even get a copy of it from the Table Office, I raise this matter at this stage because it is a matter which will be of major concern—

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't read it but you can still talk about it.

—I am referring to the recommendations. This report will be of major concern to recreational boat users. I should say in fairness that the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage has indicated in this report:

SPEECH.PARA: The conclusions and subsequent recommendations in this section of the report on revenue options have not been endorsed by the representative on the steering committee from the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage.

I do not notice any similar reservation by the Commonwealth's representatives. As I say, the conclusions to those recommendations mention that the committee had a dispute as to revenue options. The report goes on to indicate:

The Department of Finance Steering Committee representatives concluded that, as the environmental management charges at a minimum level, there is a particular merit in exploring scope to increase this charge.

Obviously, the Commonwealth representative is saying that not much is being paid now so there is a lot of scope to increase this charge. I view this with some concern, as I am sure the tourist operators, commercial boat operators and particularly recreational boat users in Central, North and Far North Queensland will also have concern.

PARA.TAB: I suspect that my undertaking of 10 to 15 minutes has almost elapsed, so I will not breach that by continuing. Suffice it to say that I will be studying very closely the recommendations of this report. I am anxiously awaiting the Stanley report, which, according to this report, has more specific recommendations. I suspect those recommendations will include a recommendation for an annual charge of something like $50 per annum for private boat users. Perhaps that is the reason why there is some reticence to table that report at this time.

If the government were to charge private boat users $50 per annum on top of the fuel tax of 33c a litre on outboard fuel that they already pay to the federal government and on top of the registration charge that they already pay to the Queensland government, it would just slug private boat owners in the northern waters and would be a great impediment to tourism.

I say to the minister: if you are wanting more money for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—and it needs it—then you should get it out of the fuel tax revenue. Private boat owners pay 33c a litre on the fuel they use. None of that 33c a litre, which is supposed to be for road constructions, is paid back to the boat owners because there are no roads on the Great Barrier Reef. The Commonwealth just gets a skinner. You charge boat owners 33c a litre in fuel tax to fix the roads, but they do not use roads; they use the sea.

If you want some money to properly fund the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which you need to do, then you should get it out of your existing revenue in fuel excise tax, which is $10 million; I think that is the figure you rip off motorists. A lot of that comes from boaties, and they get nothing back for it at all—not a cent. If you want more money for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—and it is needed—then take it out of the fuel tax revenue. Don't go slugging tourist operators; don't go slugging commercial boat operators; and, in particular, don't go slugging private boat owners, recreational boat users, with another tax.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It was a pity that Senator Macdonald did not hear my tabling statement earlier. If he had, I am sure he would not have made that statement. Then again, if he had not have made the statement, we would not have heard such gems; for example, that boat owners do not use roads. It has been most educational for all of us.

PARA.TAB: When I tabled these reports, the report entitled Review of funding arrangements for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which was asked for in part (a) of Senator Macdonald's return to order, had been only recently received. I have not considered the recommendations. I made that very clear. Clearly, I have made no decisions on the matters contained in the report. Let the record be very clear on that matter. You may have indicated—I did not quite catch your reference—that you had a draft copy of such a report. That is quite possible. I do not know whether that was the report that you were referring to.

The point I made—I will repeat it again so we do not raise the level of paranoia in Senator Macdonald—was that the report has been provided to authority staff but the authority board has not yet had a chance to consider whether it adequately meets the terms of reference that were established and, therefore, has not had an opportunity—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you put it to rest now?

—I am just explaining it. If you go outside the chamber and start rabbiting on about it, people will understand that you are disseminating untruths. Just so that you are absolutely clear, I did indicate that I would table it immediately it had been formally received by the authority.

PARA.TAB: Again, so that we can allay any fears you may have had, Senator MacDonald, I also indicated to the Senate that my expectation is that that will occur at the next meeting of the authority on 22 February. If that process takes place—which is my expectation—it will be tabled on the next day of sitting. All that was explained to the Senate when I responded to the order of the Senate that was agreed to on 7 February. I just thought that it might be useful in these circumstances to hose you down a little and to explain the process. It could have been a little easier if you had listened in the first place.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the examination of annual reports 1992-93—reports tabled in the Senate, August to December 1993. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator John Devereux
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Environment,
Recreation and the Arts
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Devereux
Attached is our detailed response to your Committee's report dated March 1994.

As you are aware the Audit Act 1901 is to be replaced by three new Acts, one of which, subject to successful passage through the Parliament, will be the `Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act' which will require all Commonwealth authorities to prepare an Annual Report. The Bill currently provides for the Finance Minister to make Orders on certain matters referred to in the legislation.

My Department is currently developing proposals for two Finance Minister's Orders which deal with the content of annual reports of Commonwealth authorities—one in respect to a `report of operations' which will form the body of the annual report and the other in respect to the audited financial statements. Finance Minister's Orders will be disallowable instruments and will have the force of law.

I have been informed that the proposals for the `report of operations' will take into account the recommendations of your committee and will identify `best practice' from recent published annual reports (both in the public and private sectors) and the Corporations Law. As part of a wide ranging consultative process the draft proposals will be sent to portfolio departments, authorities and relevant Parliamentary Committees for comment. This is expected to take place during December and January. A similar process will also be undertaken for the Finance Minister's Order relating to financial statements.
Yours sincerely
KIM C. BEAZLEY
Senate Standing Committee Environment, Recreation and the Arts—Report on Annual Reports—March 1994—Government Response to Recommendations
Recommendation 1—Evaluating performance
The guidelines should be enhanced to give agencies more guidance on the requirements concerning evaluation of `progress against plans';
Where evaluation is difficult reports should discuss this; and
The guidelines should establish key information relating to evaluating progress over the previous three years to allow comparisons over time.
Response

The Audit Act 1901 is to be replaced by three new Acts, one of which, subject to successful passage through the Parliament, will be the `Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act' which will require all Commonwealth authorities to prepare an Annual Report. The Bill currently provides for the Finance Minister to make Orders on certain matters referred to in the legislation.

The Department of Finance is currently developing proposals for two Finance Minister's Orders which deal with the content of annual reports of Commonwealth authorities—one in respect to a `report of operations' which will form the body of the annual report and the other in respect to the audited financial statements. Finance Minister's Orders will be disallowable instruments and will have the force of law.

The proposals being considered for the Finance Minister's Order for the `report of operations' are that a meaningful evaluation of performance be provided that incorporates an explanation and analysis of performance information, including key financial and non financial statistics and the financial statements. The evaluation is expected to include comments both on the financial year covered by the annual report and material changes in key statistics over a minimum of five years.
Recommendation 2—Reporting financial information
The financial reporting guidelines should be reviewed to make the reports' financial information more accessible to non-experts; and
Reports should draw key figures from the financial statements and integrate them into the main text reporting program activities.
Response

The Financial Statement Guidelines for Public Authorities and Commercial Activities are based on Statements of Accounting Concepts, Australian Accounting Standards and current practice in the private sector—but also take into account the increased accountability expected of public sector bodies. This framework, of necessity, results in a technical document, although the Department of Finance attempts to ensure that financial statements are as user-friendly as possible.

One of the key features of the report of operations as noted in the response to recommendation 1 will be a requirement to provide a meaningful evaluation of performance. This evaluation will include narrative that is based on data included in the financial statements.
Incorporating the details of financial statements into the `report of operations' is considered essential to explain to users in non technical terms the meaning of the financial statements .
Recommendation 4—Letters of transmittal

The practice of printing a letter of transmittal with an inaccurate date as part of a report should be discontinued. Instead the Minister should provide a copy of the letter of transmittal at the time of tabling the report.
AND
Recommendation 5—Letters of transmittal
Accountability information commonly put in letters of transmittal should be retained in a prominent position in the annual report.
Response
The letter of transmittal is a formal accountability document from the person/persons responsible for preparing the annual report. Its purpose is not related to tabling.
Relevant accountability information will be required to be included in the body of the annual report under the proposals being developed for the report of operations.
Recommendation 6—Stating the legal basis of reports
Statutory authority reports should reproduce the section of their Act (if any) which specifies the production and contents of the annual report; and
Where a section of a report on a particular subject is dictated by an Act other than that which dictates the report as a whole, the legal basis for the particular section should be stated.
Response
The Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act, upon passage, will become the legal basis for the preparation of annual reports.

Where specific provisions in the enabling legislation of authorities require the reporting of information not covered by the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act or Finance Minister's Order issued under that Act, the Finance Minister's Orders will require disclosure of the legal basis and the reasons therefor. This will be further facilitated by requiring authorities to include an index of reporting requirements (see response to recommendation 8.).
Recommendation 7—Terms of appointment
Details of appointed members should be reported for statutory authorities in the same way as for non-statutory bodies.
Response
This recommendation will be taken into account in the draft proposals.
Recommendation 8—reporting `nil returns'
Reporting guidelines to be revised to include the requirement to report `nil returns' and this requirement be observed by agencies.
Response

This recommendation will be given consideration in the form of a compliance index to be included in the annual report. This type of index will show where in the report the content relating to each requirement, both in the Finance Minister's Order and in enabling legislation, is located. If for any reason a requirement is not met the reason will need to be shown.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies on the Consideration of the provisions of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 6 February 1995
Senator the Hon. Margaret Reynolds
Chair
Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Reynolds

I refer to your Committee's report titled: Report on the Consideration of the Provisions of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994 which was tabled in the Senate on 29 November 1994.
I support the majority of the recommendations made in the Committee's report. State and Territory Censorship Ministers have been consulted about this response and support it.
My specific comments on each of the recommendations are as follows:
Recommendation 1: The Committee recommends that the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994 be agreed to.
Response: I am pleased to note that the Committee recommends that the Bill be agreed to.

Recommendation 2(i): The Committee also recommends that the Attorney-General cause the classification guidelines and amendments to the National Classification Code and classification guidelines to be tabled in both Houses as soon as practicable after their publication in the Gazette.

Response: I support this recommendation. As noted in the Committee's Report this will also be a requirement under the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994 which is currently before the Parliament. Under that Bill the guidelines and amendments to the Code and guidelines will also be registered on the Register of Legislative Instruments and need to be accompanied by an Explanatory Statement.

Recommendation 2(ii): The Committee also recommends that the Attorney-General cause any intergovernmental agreements in relation to the classification scheme to be tabled in both Houses as soon as practicable after their signing.
Response: I support this recommendation. It is proposed that an intergovernmental agreement be drawn up before the Bill commences.

Recommendation 2(iii): The Committee also recommends that the Attorney-General urge the State and Territory Censorship Ministers to comply with recommendations (i) and (ii) within their respective parliaments.
Response: I support this recommendation and I obtained the agreement of my State and Territory colleagues to the proposal at our meeting on 3 February 1995.

Recommendation 2(iv): The Committee also recommends that regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations should be amended to accord with the criteria for RC (Refused Classification) in the National Classification Code.

Response: I have already agreed, in principle, to amend regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations to accord with the criteria for RC (Refused Classification) in the National Classification Code as recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) in its Report on Censorship Procedure and in the Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. In principle support has also been obtained from my colleague, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator the Hon. Chris Schacht.
It is proposed that steps be taken to amend the Regulations following enactment of the Bill when the final form of the refused classification criteria is confirmed.
Recommendation 2(v): The Committee also recommends that the current Chief Censor [now Director] be the only ex officio member of the restructured Board.

Recommendation 2(vi): The Committee also recommends that there be new positions of Chief Censor and Deputy Chief Censor, to be appointed from the community representatives on the Board by the Attorney-General for a three year term, with one possible extension.

Response: Under the Bill, as is the case with the current Censorship Board and the Film and Literature Board of Review, all members of the Classification Board and Classification Review Board hold statutory appointments.

Under the Bill the statutory positions of Director and Deputy Director will be subject to the same appointment processes as other Board members i.e. the need to ensure that appointees are broadly representative of the Australian community and the requirement to consult about the appointments with State and Territory Ministers (clause 48 of the Bill).

Further, under the Bill they will be subject to the same tenure provisions (a maximum appointment of 5 years with a total period of appointment of no more than 7 years) as other members of the Boards. This is in contrast with the potentially open-ended reappointment arrangements under the existing legislative provisions.

At present the Chief Censor and Deputy Chief Censor also have a senior executive policy and managerial role in relation to the Office of Film and Literature Classification, its personnel and its work. This is in addition to their normal classification functions and responsibilities for managing the work of the Board and for community consultation. These responsibilities will continue under the structure to be established by the Bill.

It follows from this that in the selection of appointees to fill the position of Director and Deputy Director regard would be had not only to their suitability as representatives of the community in performing classification functions and as representing the public face of the Board but also to their managerial experience.

In the Government's view the structure provided in the Bill is the most desirable model. The Office of Film and Literature Classification is a small office (there are only 24 public servants employed in the Office) and it is quite appropriate and cost effective for the Chief Censor to also be the Chief Executive Officer of the Office. I note that this structure is consistent with other statutory bodies which have, in recent years, been given greater autonomy, for example, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Finally, by way of clarification, I note that the Committee in discussing this recommendation in its October 1993 Report on Video and Computer Games and Classification Issues refers to `[t]he situation of the three senior career public servants of the OFLC being the senior members of the Film Censorship Board . . . ' (para 3.62).

I mention that it has not been the general practice in the past to appoint public servants to the statutory positions referred to. Of the incumbents of those positions at the time of the 1993 Report only the Chief Censor was drawn from the public service. Further, the statutory appointees to the Board hold no concurrent public service positions in the OFLC.

Recommendations 2(vii): The Committee also recommends that a community committee be established, representing major interest groups such as parents, teachers, churches, academics, women, youth, aboriginal and ethnic representatives;

PARA.TAB: (a)that the community committee would be asked to consider:

TAB.TAB: any decisions of the Film Censorship Board in relation to the release of a film or video with an MA or R rating about which the Board was not unanimous; and
any decision of the Review Board to vary a Board decision to refuse to release, or release a film or video with a recommended R or MA rating at a lower classification, than recommended by the Board.

PARA.TAB: (b)that the Review Board be required to take the community committee's recommendations into account in its deliberations, and

(c)that the Attorney-General be required to make a determination on any decision of the Review Board to release a film or video at a lower classification than approved by the unanimous decision of the Board, and be required to take into account the community committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:

The Committee's proposal seeks, in effect, to place a `community committee' between the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board in respect of certain decisions relating to restricted material and between the Classification Review Board and the Attorney-General in respect of certain other decisions also involving restricted material.

The first problem with this proposal is that it is directed solely to material in the restricted classification categories whereas some of the most difficult classification decisions are in relation to the borderline of the `G' and `PG' categories.

Secondly, it would be unfortunate if an additional, and potentially cumbersome and costly structure were to put in place merely to safeguard against the possibility that the classification of a contentious film may be unacceptable to some sections of the community. There is ample evidence available to indicate that the Government's intention is that both Boards should be representative of the community and, after extensive consultation with the States and Territories, provisions have been added to the Bill to ensure that occurs.

In terms of censorship matters it has often been stated that every individual has a view, and that those views may be diverse. Accordingly, it is a significant achievement that the majority of the community appears to support the classification process and to rely upon the decisions that result. (eg, in the 1992 joint ABT/OFLC research project 70% of respondents with dependant children used the classification system; in the 1994 Australian Bureau of Statistics survey commissioned by the OFLC it was found that 90% of households with children 12 years and under were involved in their children's choice of films; it was also found that adults living in families with children 12 years or under were more aware of the classification system than adults in other households.)

It is not the Attorney-General's role to comment on particular classification decisions made by independent Boards established for this purpose. However, it is appropriate to observe in the context of this recommendation that the particular decision that concerned the Committee in its October 1993 Report on Video and Computer Games and Classification Issues was made not by the Censorship Board but by the Film and Literature Board of Review as then constituted.

Although raised in a different context, the question of greater community involvement in classification decisions has already been addressed by my Department in some detail in an earlier submission to the Committee on the Bill.
Nevertheless, the issues are similar and they are repeated here in response to this particular recommendation with some supplementary comments from a Ministerial perspective.

The current legislation provides for Censorship Board decisions on the merits and, on appeal, a review on the merits by the Board of Review. Review on questions of law goes to the Federal Court or the High Court. A similar structure is found in the Bill.

A primary decision on the merits with full merits review on appeal is the standard Commonwealth structure for administrative decisions. As the ALRC in its Report on Censorship Procedure noted, where it differs from other reviews of administrative decisions is that it is not a review of an administrator's decision by an independent body but the reconsideration of a decision of one independent body by another.

This difference means that the current decision making process can potentially involve up to 21 individual decision makers (15 on the Censorship Board and 6 on the Board of Review) who can, in appropriate cases, reach the decision by a majority vote. Under the Bill the potential numbers are 20 on the Classification Board and 10 on the Classification Review Board. This gives the opportunity for a very wide diversity of views to be brought to bear in the decision making process.

The proposed community committee would probably add at least a further 10 views to the process if the range of interest groups to be satisfied is taken into account. No doubt the views of this group will be just as divergent as can be the case with the members of the two current Boards and the new Boards. The wide diversity of views that exist within the community are reflected in the results of the on-going public consultation process referred to below.

Quite apart from the undesirability of the Attorney-General having to make classification decisions in the manner proposed in the recommendation, questions relating to whether Board decisions reflect community attitudes, as my Department has previously indicated, are best addressed by ensuring that the Boards:

PARA.TAB: (a)truly represents a cross section of the community; and
(b)remain abreast of community attitudes.

SPEECH.PARA: The representative nature of the Boards is being addressed by the new process of consultation with State and Territory Ministers and the requirement to look at the representative nature of proposed appointments, both of which are now reflected legislatively in the Bill (cl. 48 and 74). You may be assured that this aspect is treated seriously by myself and my State and Territory colleagues. This is reflected in the recent appointments that have been made to the Censorship Board and the Film and Literature Board of Review.

Further, appointments to the current Censorship Board follow public advertisements, interviews and recommendations on the basis of merit. Of recent times there has also been a State and Territory representative on the interviewing panel. This will continue with the new Classification Board.

As to keeping abreast of community attitudes, the ALRC's recommendation for an on-going public consultation program has already commenced. This consultation process takes the form of special screenings of classified, but as yet unreleased, films to groups of people assembled by a market research recruitment agency. An independent market research consultant supervises the completion of a questionnaire and leads a discussion aimed at comparing the issues of concern, the range of intensity of concern about those issues, the recommended age, and appropriate consumer advice with those considered by the Censorship Board when making the classification decision. The results are made available to Board members.

The initial Australian Bureau of Statistics survey on Films, Videos and Computer Games commissioned by the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) has been completed and copies have been provided to the Committee. Further surveys and research flowing from the results of that survey are planned or underway. These include another joint exercise with the OFLC and the ABA.

In the light of the above I do not consider the proposal put forward by the Committee to be justified in the current circumstances. The perceived dissatisfaction with certain classification decisions should be addressed by examining any deficiencies in the current decision making process and taking steps to rectify any problems that are found and not by seeking to impose another potentially unwieldy structure on top of the structure that already exists.
The Committee may be assured, however, that I will be closely monitoring the operation and performance of the two new Boards, in conjunction with my State and Territory colleagues.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL LAVARCH
