The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

EMPHASIS.TAB: Report No. 19 of 1994-95—Efficiency audit—Validation of nursing home funding—Department of Human Services and Health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak on the Auditor-General's report No. 19 of 1994-95, an efficiency audit of the validation of nursing home funding by the Department of Human Services and Health. It is very fitting that we take note of the Auditor-General's report on this matter because it was an earlier efficiency audit into the nursing home payment system which highlighted some of the systematic problems in the validation process which finally prompted the government to apply the necessary resources to attempt to complete validations in a reasonable time.

PARA.TAB: The Australian National Audit Office has again confirmed what we have known for some time. I have spoken about this issue many times in this chamber and I have asked numerous questions in estimates committees. In non-sitting weeks I go to nursing home after nursing home, unlike Senator Crowley who came into this chamber some weeks ago and said, `I visit nursing homes for openings.' I presume that is the only time she ever visits a nursing home. I visit nursing homes more often than just for openings. If you go around and consult with the industry, you find out the problems. The problem that kept occurring over and over again was the problem of validation. I asked numerous questions. We moved a motion in this chamber for an inquiry to be held into validations, which was done, and there has been a report tabled in the Senate on that issue. The Auditor-General has also seen fit to examine it.

There are significant concerns in the report about the department's administration of its validation program. They reflect concerns that have also been expressed by the voluntary and private sectors of the nursing home industry. The fact is that the government has been made aware time and time again that its validation process for nursing home funding is untimely and has caused significant problems to nursing homes throughout Australia; yet it has sat on its hands. The Department of Human Services and Health has been repeatedly criticised for delays in the validation process; yet, even after the department realised there was a need to speed up the validation of 1986-87 data in 1990, it took another four years before the process was completed.

Nursing home records for 1986-87 are being looked at and it is being determined as to whether money which was allocated to be spent on nursing home duties and nursing home services to residents was in fact spent on SAM, or service component services delivered to residents, which attracts a smaller amount of money from the Commonwealth. So if a nursing home has inappropriately said that a nurse was carrying out a nursing duty when she was carrying out a SAM duty, then the Commonwealth claws back the money that has been inappropriately given to the nursing home for that service. Here we have nursing homes having to go back through their 1986-87 records years later.

Another problem that has been associated with the validations is that even if the visits for the financial year 1986-87 were completed by the middle of last year there are some nursing homes that have not had exit interviews and in many more cases the validation has not been completed. I have not had time to have a check because we only got the report at 1 o'clock, but from memory—and I stand to be corrected on this—I was told in estimates hearings by the department that all validations had been completed. It may be that all validations for 1986-87 have been completed in the sense that the nursing homes have been visited, but they have not been completed if the exit interviews have not been done and the nursing homes have not been told whether they owe money or whether they are not in debt to the Commonwealth for money inappropriately allocated to them.

One of the problems also associated with this is that, because the department was so slow in organising the validations, many nursing homes were repeating the same mistake year after year. None of us in this chamber would accept or condone fraud against the Commonwealth, and we know some nursing homes have not carried out their duties and responsibilities in terms of accountability for public money in the way that we would expect. But because the department changed the goal posts, because the guidelines on what constituted a nursing duty versus a SAM type duty were not clear, many nursing homes made genuine errors and, because the validations have not been completed, they repeated those errors.

But who suffers in the end because the department is slow, because money that has been inappropriately allocated to a nursing home has not gone back into the Commonwealth coffers? The real losers, again, are the people in nursing homes. If the department is slow in the validation process and tells a nursing home it owes $40,000 or $50,000 three, four or five years down the track, that money is taken out of that nursing home's allocation for the future. So that means the current people in nursing homes pay the price for an error that the nursing home proprietors may have made many years before. The final crunch is that those residents—the frail, the vulnerable in our community—suffer. So we should not tolerate undue delays in the validation process.

As I said, the delays in the validation process, especially in validating 1986-87 data, have had a significant adverse effect on the finances of many nursing homes. The Auditor-General's report found that the present validation program is untimely with at least 169 inspections of nursing home records of expenditure for 1986-87 being undertaken seven years later. That is totally unacceptable for all the reasons I have said.

The report has found that the backlog of validations is larger now than when the validation program started in its present form in 1990. Currently there are 6,600 validations which have been received but not processed. Not all of those are overdue—and I admit that—but there is a backlog in about 5,000 cases. As I said, this is a most unacceptable situation, especially when compared to private sector best practice.

Another issue that the Auditor-General has outlined is that delays in recoveries are not consistent with good credit management and mean that the real value of money recovered by the Commonwealth has diminished by an estimated $13 million. So what happens if nursing homes owe money to the Commonwealth and that money is not collected? That money could have been used for other purposes, and it has been estimated by ANAO that that constitutes $13 million.

There is debate about this in the report. The department says that the amount lost is only $3 million if you take the CPI as an indicator. Whether you take the CPI or the ANAO as an indicator there is opportunity cost lost because money has not been taken back from nursing homes where there have been genuine errors in accountability between CAM and SAM funding.

What happens? Some bureaucrat or the government might sit there and say, `Well, $13 million here, $13 million there; what does it matter?' That $13 million would at least contribute to the issue that Professor Gregory raised about the decline in capital stock that is occurring in nursing homes and hostels because this government has not addressed the funding requirements of nursing homes and hostels, especially upgrading.

Many nursing homes would look at the $13 million and say, `We could have upgraded to meet the standards we expect to care for our elderly people.' But because the government has been tardy that is the opportunity cost forgone. Who suffers? Again, the frail aged because that money is not being used for them in an appropriate way. It could be redirected back into nursing homes, especially back into capital upgrading which, as I said, Professor Gregory has said is in a parlous state. Also the ANAO office claims there is an estimated $45 million in recoveries which has yet to be identified. Again, this represents a significant cost to the Commonwealth.

The ANAO has recommended that validation inspections be completed within 12 months of the end of the financial year and that the department should adopt a set of procedures which would enable this goal to be accomplished. The department has not accepted this recommendation as being cost-effective or practical. The ANAO has also recommended that all other departmental processes relating to validation should be completed one year later. The department has accepted this recommendation.

The Auditor-General's office has also suggested a program for the department to get up to date. It has suggested a risk management strategy be put in place to get from a situation where there are 6,600 validations to be completed to a situation where validations are completed within two years of the end of the financial year.

These concerns that have been raised in the validation report presented to the Senate by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs and also the Auditor-General's report are not new, as I said before. The nursing home industry has been struggling under the uncertainty and financial difficulties caused by the department's tardiness for too long.

Apart from the obvious difficulties of not knowing whether there will be a negative loading on nursing homes—in other words, you could go along and suddenly find that you are up for $40,000 or $50,000—long delays in the validation process have meant that nursing homes are very uncertain about their future and their future planning. That is not appropriate, as I said. The people who suffer in the end are inevitably the older Australians in nursing homes.

The ANAO concluded that the current process is unnecessarily inefficient and complex for the industry. The ANAO especially commented on the appeals process which needs to be made more realistic and open and it also highlighted the compelling need for validations to be completed within the shortest possible time—as I said, two years.

The Auditor-General's office points out that 190 circulars have been sent out to nursing homes since 1986, and if any of you have received one of those you will know that some of them are quite complicated and detailed. The audit office also pointed out that those circulars are not compiled into a directory or a loose-leaf book so that a new nursing home proprietor who is busily involved with the care of their residents is not trying to struggle through some circulars she or he might have filed some time ago. The department ought to provide them in a way so that people can access that information quickly and efficiently.

As I said earlier, the government has been made aware time and time again that its validation process for nursing home funding is untimely and causes significant problems to nursing homes throughout Australia, but it has consistently failed to solve those problems. This Auditor-General's report is yet another example of this failure. The fact that the backlog of validations is larger now than when the validation program started in its present form confirms this. I hope this report will provoke the government into action which will produce results and stop the uncertainty of funding for nursing homes and make them better places for our frail older Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to participate in this debate because I find that this report of the Australian National Audit Office follows on from work done by the Senate Community Affairs References Committee, contained in a report presented in November last year called Validation of CAM and SAM funding of nursing homes. In its report the Community Affairs Committee expressed concern about validations, and in its evidence before us the department admitted that it was having problems getting its validations up to more current time frames. Page 14 of the committee's report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department has also decided to adopt a risk management approach to outstanding and further validations.

When I quickly read parts of the ANAO report I notice that it also has that recommendation, but it has gone one step further. It has actually outlined many of the issues that need to be taken into consideration when one is running a risk management program. I think this document provides a very important working document for the future on this particular issue. There are 24 recommendations in this report, of which the department has accepted 23.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not accepted them.

—It agrees with them. These recommendations are significant because they outline things such as the mechanisms for undertaking case management, risk management and things like that. It becomes a very important document.

PARA.TAB: The first thing to note is that the Auditor-General states a very clear case for why we need to have validations and states that validations in this industry are necessary. I find that very reassuring because we are spending a significant amount of government money in this area. One of the reasons the audit office says we need to get up to speed rather quickly is that, from its estimate, there is another $45 million in recoveries which have not yet been identified. That is not an insignificant amount of taxpayers' money that should be back in other taxpayer-funded programs.

What I have read of this report I find very interesting. It has suggested a detailed program which would enable performance standards to be met by June 1999 with the aid of a risk management strategy. It has also suggested a list of the possible risk factors to assist the department. It has suggested that the case management approach be adopted, something the department itself had done.

The report has also outlined an appeals mechanism very clearly and very well. One of the issues that kept being raised with the committee when people appeared before it was that they were not necessarily happy with the appeals mechanisms. The ANAO has actually come up with very clear and concise appeals mechanisms. I think these things are very important.

The report also listed what other information might be required to manage the program. It is obtained on an `as required' basis so the program is managed with a lower than desirable level of information. The information system is not, but should be, the by-product of information used to support routine activities.

The ANAO has provided details in this report which it believes are necessary to manage the validation program and has suggested that the system be incorporated into the financial system that provides recurrent funding to nursing homes. For those people who do not have a great deal of time to read ANAO reports, I suggest they read the summary.

The other issue I raise is the final recommendation, which I think has some very significant ramifications for the industry if the industry wants to look at it. It is certainly one way to overcome the problem of having to validate money it has already received. The ANAO recommended that the department examine the possibility of funding arrangements being less conducive to fraud by making the OCRE and CAM payments in arrears, possibly after a phasing-in period. The department will consider this response.

I think this report provides for the industry some fairly clear guidelines as to what the department, if it agrees, will certainly be thinking. It also provides some insight and some information as to how the department can go about looking further at and streamlining the validation process. Nowhere in this document does it say that validation should not occur. I think that is a very important point for people to realise.

I think this report forms a very valuable adjunct to our first report. It will also form a very important part of the work the ombudsman is doing on those cases where people are having problems and are not happy with the appeals mechanism. In here is an appeals mechanism set out.

I think this will be, in the long term, one of the more significant ANAO reports because it does offer a way, a future and some guidelines as to how problems that have been identified, not just by the ANAO but by the department itself, can be overcome.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was introducing my remarks just before lunch when the time ran out. I want to put on record the government's view about this disallowance motion moved by Senator Hill. All senators are aware by now of the advice the Liberal Party is receiving from its chief source of advice, the so-called Republic Advertising company. The Liberal Party is determined to ask—and I quote from the document sent to Andrew Robb:

PARA.TAB: Who are the people receiving welfare who don't need it?
Are there people receiving welfare who don't need it? If so, who and why?

SPEECH.PARA: I will tell you who and why they might be in future. The `who' is those who claim falsely to be in de facto relationships to escape the parental means test on Austudy, and the `why' is because Senator Hill and the Liberal Party want to let them.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal Party wants to pay lip-service to the story that undeserving people are receiving government support. The Liberal Party wants to make that a major thrust of its political platform, but the actions of the opposition here, in particular, give lie to what the Liberal Party would say. What you are arguing for here could create a whole class of such people.

In 1994, a student qualified as independent for Austudy purposes if he or she had been legally married. A de facto relationship was not a ground for independent status. The policy rationale for non-recognition of de facto marriages was that this minimised the scope for students to evade the parental means test by declaiming a de facto relationship.

With the passage of the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act in 1984, which prohibited discrimination on the basis of marital status, these arrangements only continued under an exemption clause or clauses. The last of these expired in mid-1994, but a further six-month extension was obtained to enable the government to implement the change on a whole year basis. The changes to the Austudy regulations made in Statutory Rules 1994 No. 409 from 1 January 1995 state:

SPEECH.PARA: Marriage has been removed as a criterion for independence; the definition of spouse is non-discriminatory; and income tests are the same for both married and de facto students.

The government has introduced new rules governing eligibility for Austudy which are non-discriminatory and fair to all students. The system Senator Hill wants to reinstate discriminated directly against single students and students in de facto relationships. The government's new rules give every Austudy applicant the same standing, regardless of marital status, as required by the laws prohibiting discrimination.

PARA.TAB: The system that the opposition, supported by the Democrats and the Greens, wants to reinstate means single students under 22, unless they have been working full time for three of the previous four years, were still assessed for Austudy on the basis of their parents' income—even if they were not living with their parents and their parents were not providing any financial assistance.

The rules Senator Hill wants to reinstate—as if they represented some golden era that the Liberal Party wants to return to—were inconsistent and discriminatory. I think, under the new leadership of Mr Howard, we want to go back to that dreadful word `incentivation' that occurred in about 1988 and the famous picket fence family that was prominently displayed for a while by Mr Howard, who was the then leader. It appears that we are now returning, in policy terms, to the Howard view of Australia vis-a-vis the 1950s. It has only been a week and a half since he has returned to the leadership formally, and we are already now seeing the impact of the conservative Howard philosophy towards the way Australia is structured and operates. It is a view of the 1950s which fortunately most Australians do not see as relevant to a progressive and open society of tolerance in this decade and into the next century.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you're going to do.

—I'm glad you interjected. I was just waiting for one from the opposition. What we are going to do is win the next election for a start, Senator. The reason we are going to win the next election is because we are looking forward and understanding the changes that are going on in society in this country while you are looking back to a golden era.
—You tell us how you ran CSIRO and all the other things you were involved in. You couldn't run a chook raffle.
—Senator Patterson, you are a very small `l' liberal in the Liberal Party—and I suspect that is now why you are on the back bench rather than the front bench, which is the Liberal Party's loss.
—I don't define myself. You have factions in your party.

—You are on the back bench, Senator. You got sacked from the front bench to the back bench. So when you are talking about people's careers and so on, yours has gone in a pretty major reverse sort of way, to the very back row of the back bench. One of the reasons you ended up back there is because you are a small `l' liberal, which is an unfashionable position to have in the Liberal Party these days, particularly under John Howard. What we are seeing here in this disallowance—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I have been listening to Senator Schacht. He was trying to put up a reasonable argument before, but under the relevant standing order I do not think where Senator Patterson sits in the chamber has got anything to do with this debate. Where she sits in this chamber has got nothing to do with her ability. I believe you should tell him to get back to the relevance of the matter.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—The point of order taken by Senator Panizza has got some merit in it. I would, in ruling on the point of order, ask Senator Schacht to address himself to the motion before the chamber. In asking Senator Schacht to do that, I would ask opposition senators, and all senators, to refrain from interjections which would seek to divert the speaker from the subject matter at hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President, for your assistance in this matter. As I was saying, the rules Senator Hill wants to reinstate—as if they represented that return to the golden era—were inconsistent and discriminatory, even in the way students in de facto relationships were treated. Students living in de facto relationships with high income earners had an unfair advantage over married students because the income of the de facto partner was not taken into account until the relationship had been in place for two years.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, students in a de facto relationship did not automatically qualify for Austudy at the independent rate. Under the regulations we are proposing, the same requirements apply to all students in a fair, equitable and non-discriminatory way. If these changes to the regulations are disallowed, as is now proposed, the regulations that applied in 1994 remain in force. However, no exemption from the provisions of the discrimination act is now in force.

The Sex Discrimination Commissioner is an independent statutory office holder, and the government cannot oblige this officer to provide a further exemption. In the absence of an exemption, the Austudy regulations would be open to challenge by couples in a de facto relationship seeking independent status in the same way as it applies to married couples. A student could bring a complaint on behalf of all students in de facto relationships and compensation could be ordered by the Human Rights Commission. This could have the same effect as changing the Austudy provisions to allow de facto couples to obtain independent status on the same basis as married students.

The opposition's move to disallow the regulations will, therefore, have three effects. The government is likely to be obliged to extend independent status which provides exemption from the Austudy parental means test to students in de facto relationships, at an estimated cost of $170 million each year. An opposition that is talking about $5 billion worth of expenditure cuts is blithely proposing a measure that is contrary to the Sex Discrimination Act and that is going to cost an extra $170 million.

I know that the Democrats and the Greens reckon this is probably a pretty good idea, because they are always in favour of endless expenditure. The remarks made earlier in the debate today by Senator Margetts indicated that particularly. But I am very surprised at the hypocrisy of the opposition announcing that they are looking at $5 billion plus in expenditure cuts and then just allowing another $170 million to be added here—and, of course, not telling where they will make extra cuts to make up for that.

The second effect: that there would be major administrative difficulties in allowing independent status for de facto relationships amongst students because of the ease with which students could falsely represent normal group accommodation living arrangements as de facto relationships, thus circumventing the parental means test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—Senator Bell laughs. You may well laugh, Senator Bell. But you know as well as I do—as do those of us for whom it now is well over 25 years since being university students, as it is with me—that, in a practical sense, students share houses in numbers that most of us now would find uncomfortable. It would be very easy for those students to promote a case for a de facto relationship and, of course, extra cost.

PARA.TAB: Finally, there could be a financial inducement to enter de facto relationships for many young people under the age of 22. This is the most astonishing thing of all. Here are those of the Liberal opposition, white picket fence and all, talking about the 1950s moral strait-jacket—that is the style they are all about—with the unintended consequence of what they are doing with the disallowance being to encourage students to go into de facto relationships.

I am not sure that some of the conservative members of the opposition, particularly those in the so-called Lyons group, I think it is called, or Lyons foundation, would be too pleased to see that this is the consequence of the policy that they are now putting up here. I am sure that we await with interest to hear from people like Mr Miles, Senator Herron, Senator Abetz, and those other conservatives of the Lyons foundation, Lyons group or Lyons committee—whatever it is called—justifying to that constituency, to which they are forever rabble rousing as being the last defenders of civilisation and family structure, that they will be voting shortly to encourage young people to go into de facto relationships. That is the consequence of trying to be a populist in here, jumping up and down without proper thought for the consequences of your position.

I just want to emphasise that, in arguing for a return to the status quo, Senator Hill is arguing for a position which is discriminatory in terms of the act. He would have the government ignore or act counter to the intent of the law. It should be remembered that the Sex Discrimination Act is not an act of this government; it is an act of the parliament. In 1983 members of the Liberal Party were allowed to vote on this legislation according to their consciences.

Senator Hill voted for the legislation. He supported the notion of treating people equally and not discriminating against any person on the basis of marital status. Not only did he vote for it, he took the opportunity to speak in favour of it. He acted on that occasion as a man of principle. But now that he is trapped into being part of the Howard leadership team, he argues for the rejection of the same principle. Further, by arguing that the government should return to the status quo, he argues that this Senate should demand that the government act contrary to the legislation of the parliament.
As I have already said, the opposition would encourage young people under the age of 22 to take up a de facto relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is true; I just want to emphasise the point. This is contrary to the espoused views of those of the opposition. Of course, while they continue to promote that view, they are voting in here to do something quite different.
—It's a good speech, Chris. Did you write it?
—I certainly had deep input, representing the DEET minister.
—You're reading it very well.
—But I do not have to write a speech to realise where a major policy of hypocrisy is being created by the opposition.
—You'd know it when you saw it, wouldn't you!

—Absolutely. I know it when you lot get up into this sort of act—an astonishing performance. I wait to hear the conservative members of the Lyons foundation respond to their constituency as to why they are promoting and encouraging the take-up of de facto relationships amongst young people.

PARA.TAB: I would make one other comment. When Senator Margetts was speaking today in this debate, she wanted the present age of independence for Austudy—being 22, as I understand it—to be dropped to the age of 18. DEET estimates that this would just add another $1 billion to the Austudy bill. I know that Senator Margetts will never be in a position to be part of a government which is responsible for the revenues and expenditure in Australia. But I do think that people should not blithely stand up and say, `Do this,' with the consequence of an added $1 billion of expenditure and with their having no idea of whether it is equitable or fair. It would mean that a lot of high income earners would be able to have their kids on Austudy at the taxpayers' expense. Even some of those in the opposition would see that as being a not particularly equitable outcome.

Also Senator Margetts mentioned the extension of rent assistance to all students. The department advises me that this would add a further $100 million to the outlays. So, again, we just ask that the parliament and the people understand that it is very easy to be a populist, to always stand up and argue that we should spend and spend. But usually the people who put that argument forward really have very few ideas on how we are to raise the revenue, without causing other severe consequences to the rest of the community.

The government is very firm on this issue. We cannot vote against the principle of the Sex Discrimination Act; we believe that to do so is hypocritical. We are surprised, in particular, that the Democrats—who have always supported such issues of non-discrimination—in this case have fallen for the populist three-card trick and are supporting this disallowance. I am not surprised that the Greens are up there being even more populist and demanding expenditures of over an extra $1 billion—which would be the consequence if they were to get their way on Austudy—with no thought to the necessary outlays and taxes.

Finally, just to reiterate: the opposition has jumped in on this issue obviously without looking at all the consequences. Now we have a situation where, firstly, they—particularly Senator Hill—are voting against the principle of the Sex Discrimination Act that Senator Hill himself strongly supported back in the mid-1980s. He is now voting against the principles of that act in order to continue the discriminatory nature of the arrangements of Austudy with which the government does not want to continue.

Finally, and most mockingly of all, opposition senators do not understand the consequences of what they are about. For a party which professes conservative values, a return to the 1950s, the picket fence and the family of mum and dad and the two kids, if this measure is carried, they will actually be encouraging young people to form de facto relationships so they can get the money. It is an extraordinary outcome and it just shows you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that this opposition is utterly bereft of any policy substance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to take part in this debate because of representations which were made to me in Western Australia on the matter. The first question I would ask of the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), or whoever cares to answer is: why did the department advise all the students who were in that category that they would not be able to get Austudy—
—They didn't think you would be so stupid as to knock the regulation off.

—Just a minute. I would like to know why it advised all those students involved who would come under this category that they would be able to get it, until this measure went through both houses of parliament. On ringing the relevant office, my office was told that this measure went through both houses of parliament on 6 December. Whether Senator Schacht thinks that we would have let it through this place or not is irrelevant. We were told that it went through both houses of parliament on 6 December.
—One thing is for certain: they will always know that they should never trust the Senate while you are in it.
—Yes, that is okay. We are here to keep you honest. I want to know why we were told that officially from this office in Canberra without it having gone through the Senate. If you expect—

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Panizza, would you resume your seat for a second. I am a little bit concerned at the way the debate is going. I am very mindful of the point of order that you took during the last speaker's contribution. I think at the moment, by asking questions directly of the minister, you are inviting interjections and, if I do get interjections, I will be forced to rule on them. I ask you to confine yourself to the matter in hand and address your remarks through the chair rather than directly at the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, but can you tell me who else is responsible for answering questions except the minister at the table? I must have missed something. If I ask a question, it is directed at him.
—Not according to standing orders, Senator Panizza. You are not allowed to ask questions of the chair during the debate, either.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Schacht, for the interjection.
—I want an answer sometime to the question of why the office of DEET in Canberra was told—

—On a point of order: Mr Acting Deputy President, I may be able to help you out on that ruling. There is a time when Senator Panizza can ask the minister a question and the minister is obliged to answer it; that is, when this bill is in committee. Now, the minister made—
—Order! Senator McGauran, are you taking exception to the previous ruling, or are you rising on a new point of order?

—I am rising on a new point of order. The point of order is that standing orders do allow the minister to answer questions and Senator Panizza to put questions to the minister, that is, when matters are in committee. This bill is heading into committee. If the minister—
—Order! Senator McGauran, this is a disallowance motion, and it is subject to debate in the chamber. There will be no committee stage, and we are certainly not in committee at the moment.

—Then I invite the minister to, nevertheless, answer Senator Panizza's questions. Senator Panizza is quite entitled to raise questions in the debate and, if the minister seeks to shirk them, he is the one bereft.
—Order! Senator McGauran, please resume your seat.

—On a point of order: I have to say that, in this disallowance motion debate, I am more than happy to answer directly the questions that Senator Panizza puts up. Just for the record, I want to say something about the regulation: a regulation is enforced from the time it is approved by the Governor-General-in-Council until such time as it is disallowed by the Senate. So they were acting absolutely properly.

—Thank you for your assistance, Senator Schacht. I will rule against your point of order, Senator McGauran. This is not the appropriate time to address questions to the minister. In addressing questions directly to the minister during debate, one is inviting interjections, which, of course, is disorderly, and I would not want the Senate to be disorderly. I remind Senator Panizza that there is an estimates committee procedure where questions can be directed not only to the minister at the table but also to senior officers. So I rule against your point of order, Senator McGauran. I call Senator Panizza.
—Thank you very much. By posing those questions, I did not think we would get into this situation this afternoon. Of course, you are allowed to pose questions in debate.
—Rhetorical questions.
—No, you pose questions; whether or not they get answered in time does not matter. I take note of what Senator Schacht said: it is there until—
—Until it is disallowed.

—Until it is disallowed. At the time I questioned that, I had not seen it go through the Senate. It is right—as you have been told obviously—that that was the situation. But having asked the question of the department, I thought I would have been told, `Okay, it hasn't gone through the Senate, but it is a matter of regulations.' That was it. So we have a half truth by omission. That is what happened. I was very interested this morning to hear Senator Neal carry on in the vein that she did on this matter.
—It was a very good speech she made, actually.
—Order!
—Was it? Mr Acting Deputy President, when I took a point of order last time, you advised me to stop interjecting. Could you do the same with him?
—I actually just did that at the time.

—Okay, and I stopped interjecting. I was very amused at the way she carried on regarding the Sex Discrimination Act and these regulations. Was it really meant to take into account these sorts of things in 1984? I do not know. We have progressed a long way down the track, but I did not think we would ever see the day when being married was not regarded as being independent. I speak as a parent of four children who are in that age group.

PARA.TAB: I believe that there is a difference also with de facto relationships. It is very easy to say, as Senator Schacht pointed out, that it encourages students to go into a de facto relationship. But I think there is a difference between a de facto relationship and marriage. Speaking as a parent, if some of my children go into a marriage and some go into a de facto relationship, I honestly consider that the ones in a de facto relationship are still dependent on me. I believe that de facto relationships are far more loose than marriage; I certainly hope that marriage is more secure than a de facto relationship. One of the advisers over there can smile as much as he likes, but I have brought four children up to, hopefully, be good citizens of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: Senator Panizza has made a very serious point towards the advisers box. On many occasions, I have raised the matter about advisers sneering, smiling and pulling faces. Mr Acting Deputy President, the standing orders quite clearly set out your jurisdiction on this matter. I will be going into the chair in a few minutes, and I am just dying to catch someone in those boxes, because I have had trouble with Senator Crowley's advisers on this matter over the last couple of years.
—Order! Senator McGauran, stick to your point of order at the moment.

—The point of order is that standing orders are quite clear about the involvement in the debate by advisers. They will be ejected from the Senate if they involve themselves in the debate. Senator Panizza has made the point—
—Yes, I know, and you have made the point.
—I ask you to discipline the advisers, as the standing orders require.
—On the point of order, I call Senator Schacht.

—This is a most outrageous introduction by Senator McGauran. First of all, he made a fool of himself five minutes ago for not understanding the standing orders when he said that we are going to go into committee stage on a disallowance motion. He made a fool of himself over that, and now he is trying to make himself look serious again by threatening staff who cannot answer for themselves, by saying, `They are sneering and smiling and, when I get into the chair, I'll throw them out.' Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to rule that such intimidation should not be allowed. It is not allowed under the standing orders, and Senator McGauran should be brought to order.

—I take the point of order very seriously. I am aware that there have been previous rulings by presidents, deputy presidents and acting deputy presidents of the chamber about alleged conduct of advisers whilst the Senate is in session. I would think that the proper way to do things would be to draw any alleged inappropriate activity of advisers to the attention of the chair, so the chair at the time might rule on any inappropriate activity.

PARA.TAB: At the particular point in time when Senator Panizza made mention of it, I was, in fact, addressing myself to him rather than to any activity that may or may not be occurring in the advisers box. Because of that, I am unable to make any ruling about any allegations made about any of the advisers currently in the box. But if disorderly conduct does happen, I would invite any honourable senator to bring it to the attention of the chair at the appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a parent I believe there is a difference between children who go into marriage and children who go into de facto relationships, especially the de facto relationship as described by Senator Schacht which we would force them into.
—Oh!

—I consider those who go into de facto relationships still to be dependent. I will bet my bottom dollar that that is what would happen in the breakdown of a de facto relationship, especially the type of relationship that Senator Schacht described where people go into it for the purpose of qualifying for Austudy. I will quote from a letter that I received from a third year medical student from the University of Western Australia. Her letter states:

PARA.TAB: This year the rules for eligibility for Austudy were changed to preclude married students from receiving Austudy as they were considered to be still dependent on their parents for financial support. If you have ever been married, you will understand what a ridiculous rule this is.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been married; I still am married—
A married student is not considered independent until they satisfy another of the independent criteria, none of which is personal or spouse income.

She went on to say that her husband would not satisfy the criteria either. A lot of students caught up by these regulations are married to each other. In this case, the wife is in third year medicine and the husband is doing a postgraduate degree. That means that, under the new regulations, he cannot claim Austudy and she cannot claim Austudy. In fact, this couple got married last week. Her parents live in Queensland and they are relying on them. I suppose if the husband is not getting any money, he is relying on his parents as well. It puts them in very awkward situation. The letter continues:

PARA.TAB: My husband . . . and I do not satisfy any of the other criteria. I am 21 (22 in September) and am studying for a Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery Degree. My husband is 23 (24 in April) completing his Master of Engineering, which he will finish in October.

SPEECH.PARA: She looked into the situation and she says in her letter:

PARA.TAB: I have spoken to people at Austudy who have told me my application will be rejected under the new ruling. I have spoken to the Austudy counsellor at UWA . . . who told me my only option—

SPEECH.PARA: Listen to this; this student is in third year, going into fourth year—
was to quit Medicine for the year and go on the dole while looking for work.
That is the sort of advice you get from Social Security under this government: you have to go on the dole while you are looking for work. She continues:
I have spoken to . . . at the Department of Social Security to see if there were any other benefits I could receive so I didn't have to quit Medicine. She was very sympathetic—

The only extra advice she was offered was to appeal the decision and be used as a test case. Of course, appealing the decision takes a long time. She was told that it takes up to nine months and in that time she would be lucky to find a part-time job. Bearing in mind how little spare time there is available when you are studying medicine, she could score about $70 a week, and that would be the total taxable income. Finally, she said about the abuse of the system:

PARA.TAB: Secondarily, it is offensive to me that the government obviously doesn't consider my marriage to . . . to be legal and honourable. I cannot understand how else they would consider me to be a financial dependent on my parents. I can think no sane person—

SPEECH.PARA: And nor could I—
who would undertake the enormous commitment of marriage for the $120 a week—
That brings me to the point Senator Schacht made that this would force them into de facto relationships. Who would do that for $120 a week? I think the situation is stupid.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at de facto relationships, which Senator Schacht said they would be forced into. When you take on a marriage—and I suppose it is still the case—you take on obligations. I certainly hope that, even in these enlightened days, when you take on the vows of marriage you take on the responsibilities. Those responsibilities could be costly in the breakdown of a marriage.

Even if you go into a de facto relationship to get the $125 a week that Senator Schacht spoke about, don't you think that you take on responsibilities? Do you think that after you finish your course and you are earning $100,000 a year as a medical graduate, you are going to walk away scot-free from a de facto relationship? What a foolish statement for Senator Schacht, and anyone else opposite backing him up, to make. You can smile as much as you like, Senator Neal.

Do you think that anyone would go into a de facto relationship for this reason and then think when they finish university that they walk away and have no obligations? I do not think that you or anyone else in that position would let a de facto husband walk away that easily without demanding half of his salary or half of anything he had.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is extraordinarily sexist!

—It can apply the other way. What husband would let a de facto wife earning $100,000 a year walk away scot-free? Do not think that, if you go into a de facto relationship, it will last. It is not like a one night stand where you get up and walk away. If you go into a de facto relationship, you take on responsibilities. I think it is ridiculous for Senator Schacht to suggest that you go into de facto relationships for that reason. Setting aside what I have said, I believe that Senator Hill has summed it up. This regulation should be defeated. We should give independence to people when they take on the responsibility of marriage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable senators who chose to contribute to this debate. I particularly thank the members of the government for complimenting me on my contribution to the debate on the Sex Discrimination Act some years ago. I appreciated your kind remarks. I remember the speech also and I thought it was quite good, if I might say so myself.
—It's a pity you didn't stick to it.

—I will stick to it. The argument that has been put against our side is really an extraordinary one. I remind the Senate that what we are saying is that the existing situation should continue and the government should treat married students as independent and therefore pay them Austudy appropriately. Somehow or other the government has tried to turn the argument and say that the argument against the regulation is encouraging de facto relationships. I am sorry, but I find that an obscure argument. I do not know that we introduced that argument at all. It seems to be the government that has sought—

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have argued last week before you brought down this regulation that that was the situation. You cannot have it both ways. I can also remember the debate on the Sex Discrimination Act. I can remember the arguments that were put that we need to protect married people, particularly married women, from adverse discrimination, which had been the case so often. That is why that type of discrimination was acted upon through legislative means.

PARA.TAB: It seems to be a somewhat distorted argument to now come in here and say that in some way it is prejudicing married people. We are trying to give them the benefits that they traditionally had under the Austudy regulations because society has treated them as independent, their parents treat them as independent and we think they have the right to regard themselves as independent. So I have not found the government's defence of its position at all convincing. Certainly we stand by the case that we have brought against these regulations. If it means that the government has to take some other action as a result of its unsuccessful attempt to, in effect, discriminate against married students then so be it.

I think the jeering at Senator Panizza's contribution demonstrates a certain prejudice on the other side of the chamber that is unfortunate. Senator Panizza comes here very much driven by a set of traditional values which are still the values of a very sizeable percentage of the Australian community. His attitude to marriage, to married students and to de factos remains a view that is held by a lot of Australians and should be treated with respect rather than with jeers. I am sorry that the government of this country, as represented by the minister and the other few government senators here today, does not see that point. I trust that the numbers have remained as they were this morning and that these regulations will now be defeated.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe there is an agreement between the various parties that we are each going to speak for approximately 10 minutes. I say at the outset that most senators would know that the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill was set up by the Senate to undertake a widespread consultation process with Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to determine their views, particularly on the Senate amendments to the legislation and other matters. This was done based on the background of information provided by the government, which had told Australians and Australian Aboriginals in particular that the so-called Land Fund Bill was the product of the most widespread, extensive and exhaustive consultation in the history of Australia.

PARA.TAB: When we looked at the list of who the government had consulted with, we found that not only had verbal consultation taken place with literally only a dozen or so people, but of the other 100 people on the mailing list, 20-something were churches and mining and pastoral interests. The rest of the Aboriginals who were supposedly consulted were just sent a copy of the bill.

I presume that we will be debating the issues in this report in a fortnight when we come back. I take this opportunity as chairman to say a few thankyous. The Senate will know that the committee was established late last year and, by agreement, was asked to report by 31 January.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the real reason for its establishment?
—Because the Senate did not want to be seen to be delaying the legislation. Senator Kernot should stop interjecting so that the chairman can thank those people who worked hard on the committee.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously Senator Kernot does not want the committee staff or the Hansard people to be thanked during this debate. Her continuing to interject and make cheap, disgusting political points might be a typical reflection of her views on these issues.

PARA.TAB: I will thank the people who assisted us in chronological order. Firstly, I thank Dr Rosemary Laing, who is the Senate Clerk Assistant (Committees). She was given the job in the first instance of trying to get the committee off the ground without any staff. Dr Rosemary Laing and I worked very hard in the first two or three days to put together the information pack, which was most useful for many of the witnesses, staff and senators on the committee in dissecting the complex legislation and the amendments. I thank Dr Rosemary Laing very earnestly for her work.

Again, in chronological order, Sue Morton was very shortly thereafter appointed. I must say that, having working with her over the last couple of months, Sue has made what I have described in the preface to the report as a herculean task seem to go relatively smoothly, if not easily. Again, it is due to Sue's great character and her sense of humour that the committee was able to achieve so much in such a short time.

I also thank Trish Carling, who I see in the gallery today, for the work she did as the senior research officer to the committee. She was of incredible assistance. The job of recording the names and affiliations of the 244-odd witnesses was at times very hard. In the process of the committee—I have sworn to the Hansard people that I would not disclose this too widely; I am now going to break my promise—we introduced a roving microphone, which was used to ensure that anyone in the gathering could have their views heard regardless of whether they put their submission in writing.

As the chairman, I undertook to tell Hansard that I would make sure that no evidence was recorded until we were given the names of the various witnesses and the capacity in which they appeared. In some circumstances, that was quite hard. Trish had to run around and ensure that all of those 244 witnesses had their details recorded. She did that absolutely thoroughly. We went to 11 or 12 locations around Australia and usually spent an entire day at each location. We clearly heard in excess of 20 witnesses at each place. So the committee went through a very physically and mentally gruelling process. It could not have been done without people like Sue and Trish on the ground.

Dr Ian Willis was appointed at very short notice. He was seconded from a posting in the ACT government to act as our principal research officer. Ian's background in Aboriginal affairs research was absolutely essential to the committee's success. Within the short time that we were required to report, it was very helpful to have Ian able to form the framework of the report as we went along. So, when we did get back to Canberra last week, the report writing was not as tough as it could have been.

Sheryln Millikin was based in Canberra as ground control while we moved around Australia. She did a fantastic job of keeping the committee in contact with witnesses who were continuing to contact the office as we moved around Australia from place to place. She did a tremendous job.

I pay particular tribute to the Hansard and Sound and Vision Office people, because they are often not thought of in these matters. In this committee it was very important—I think Senator Chamarette made the point at a press conference this morning—that, regardless of what happens to this bill once this report is tabled, the historical record now shows the views of 244 witnesses across Australia, most of them Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, on land issues. In particular, the issues these amendments looked at are recorded for all time. So it does not really matter what flavour politicians here in the Senate want to put on the evidence; the evidence is there for people to read.

I mention the people from Hansard and Sound and Vision in no order of merit. I will mention Lisa Barrenger first because she had to lug around all the heavy sound and vision equipment. She and and Peter Zuccato are both from the Sound and Vision Office and Lyn Millar, Val Poon, Ros Paterson and Nari Muscat are from Hansard. I have said in the preface to the report that they played a crucial and, without putting too exaggerated a point on it, historic role in recording the views of Aboriginal Australians.

We have limited our time necessarily. As chairman, it is most appropriate that I thank those who took part in the hearings. As I said, I will discuss the policy issues at another time. I also thank the senators who did take part in the hearings, particularly Senator Cooney who came to all the hearings, and my colleagues Senator Ellison and Senator Troeth. Senator Troeth came to every hearing, and Senator Ellison came to all the hearings but one, because he had another hearing that day on another committee. Senator Chamarette came to all the hearings. It was very hard work. No-one who was on that committee could say that it was not extremely rewarding to have the opportunity to speak to so many of our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander brothers and sisters about these issues. It was a very rewarding experience.

One point needs to be made: I hope that the government will take this report genuinely. I can see from Senator Kernot's snide interjections that she will not. I have seen from the minority report some criticisms of the process. Quite frankly, we await what Senator Lees says. I hope that Senator Ellison responds on behalf of the opposition. I have been disgusted by the performance of Senator Lees, particularly, during the past few hours. She has actually misrepresented some facts absolutely and fundamentally. But we can deal with them down the track.

I genuinely call on the government to approach the report positively. The coalition senators and the Greens have compromised where compromise was necessary. We have been prepared to modify and adjust our views and to support those contentions that were supported by the witnesses. I hope that the government will bring the legislation back into this place without delay and allow it to move from the Senate to the House of Representatives, where the government can deal with the issues and at least give some credit to the 244 people who came before us.

As I said, about 10 or so witnesses said, `Let's put the bill through with no amendments.' Of the balance of the witnesses, some, but not very many, supported all of the amendments; we would not expect that. Some supported some of the amendments and some supported only one or two. The reality is that over 200 of the 244 witnesses said that the bill does need some sort of amendment. I ask the government to bring the legislation back and to give the report and the witnesses the cognisance they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the land fund bill majority and minority reports, I take this opportunity to endorse the remarks of Senator Campbell in thanking the staff and Hansard. I think the logistics of organising this committee in January was extremely difficult and I give every praise to the staff involved, Hansard and, of course, the chair and colleagues. We do disagree in our interpretation and, while it was a useful exercise to attend the hearings that I attended, it is always good to hear further views. I feel that my position in relation to the amendments is pretty much as it was at the end of last year.

PARA.TAB: The terms of reference required the committee to inquire into whether the amendments improved the bill and to seek a level of consensus on the amendments among the indigenous people of Australia. The Senate committee found that there were nine groups of amendments which aroused the most comment during the hearings we conducted. It is the conclusion of the minority report, signed by Senator Lees and me, that these groups of amendments should be opposed.

In hearing evidence on these crucial groups of amendments, the committee found that there was no agreement among indigenous people on whether the amendments should be retained or deleted. I suppose we should not really be surprised about this because obviously there is going to be a diversity of opinions in the indigenous community just as there is in the rest of the community. Obviously this is the result of a very considerable variation in the circumstances and needs among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. The essential conclusion of our minority report is that the only way for the land fund legislation to adequately cover this considerable variety is for the ILC to have flexibility.

I hold the view that the coalition and the Greens want to be overprescriptive. I make no comment on their motives in this regard, but they are trying to put everything into the legislation. That will mean there will be less flexibility and it will detract from the opportunity for Aboriginal self-determination and for a flexible approach to what is a very complex issue when you are addressing the extremes of situations that people are in throughout the country. The less prescription and legislative direction in the land fund legislation the more closely we will be able to meet the needs of all indigenous people.

I would argue that the legislation as originally drafted gave much discretion to the indigenous controlled ILC board and anticipated that policy direction would come to the ILC through the regional strategies, drawn up after extensive negotiation and consultation in the regions.The amendments to the bill undermine this important source of self-management for indigenous people. It is the Senate which purports to give policy direction to the ILC on how to handle a number of sensitive issues, but we cannot even predict many of those sensitive issues because they will arise as the legislation is put into place. I believe that if the amendments were agreed to we would have more litigation, more confusion and certainly a great deal of rivalry and conflict between indigenous people.

A lot of focus has been put on the government's consultation. I would like to make just a couple of general points about the development of this bill. First of all, the coalition's feigned indignation about the lack of government consultation would seem to me to be pretty hypocritical because we know that the opposition did not consult on the amendments to the bill that it introduced into the House last year because those amendments were still being drafted and circulated on the day that they were introduced. Clearly, if you want consultation you have to practise what you preach.

Apart from being hypocritical, it would seem that some of the facts are obviously not recognised. The fact is that the government did not merely consult with indigenous people; it negotiated with them. The first real negotiations in regard to indigenous policy development in this country occurred when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) negotiated with Aboriginal people in the development of the native title legislation. It was a real breakthrough in Australia for indigenous people for the first time to be taken seriously in terms of sitting down and negotiating the best outcome in the development of the native title bill. There was a similar process in regard to the land fund.

Of course, I accept there were all those groups who came to us and said, `Oh, we were not consulted.' But let us be realistic. We do not expect anywhere else in the general community for everybody to be consulted. We choose groups that broadly represent ATSIC—obviously, land fund representatives—we choose people who we can talk to who broadly represent the community. I think it is important that we do not impose double standards here.

In the brief time remaining to me I will look at some of the amendments. I would like to address specifically some of the conclusions reached in the majority report. The `most severely dispossessed' amendment was the most roundly trashed of all the coalition-Green amendments. Witnesses at the hearings consistently said, `We are all dispossessed. We do not want degrees of dispossession. We do not want to try to argue, especially as it would result in legalistic argument and potential litigation, about who is more or less dispossessed'. All Australian indigenous peoples have been dispossessed. That is a historic fact. To try to talk about who is more or less disadvantaged will only exacerbate the divisions that already exist.

The coalition and the Greens had to recognise this and a revised wording is proposed in the majority report to incorporate the principle that `those who suffer most disadvantage in access to land receive priority'. This wording might be an acknowledgment of the views expressed, and we have to recognise that, but is access to be defined in a formal institutional sense? If so, the Aboriginal people of New South Wales will go to the bottom of the list because their state has a land rights act and a land acquisition fund. Is that the intention of the coalition and the Greens or is it to be defined in a direct physical sense? If that is the case, those people who retain cultural links through proximity to their country but who do not own their land will be unfairly excluded despite the urgency of the need to re-establish connections.

I make these points not just to be in disagreement but to highlight the complexity of senators making these decisions now when we are preparing the way for a land fund to be presented and put in place so that the flexibility, the whole variety of circumstances that will come forth in the coming years, can be adequately accommodated. If we are overly prescriptive the land fund will not be able to be implemented in a way that genuinely recognises self-determination among indigenous people.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take only a couple of minutes of the Senate's time to briefly indicate the government's reaction to this report. I want to say at the outset that the committee did conduct a gruelling schedule of hearings around the country which did give many people the opportunity to comment on the amendments. The committee did well to produce its report only a few days after it was due. To that extent, we are indebted to members of the committee for the exercise.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, it appears that the disagreements that were all so evident when we were debating the substance of the bill have really, at the end of the day, simply been paraded once again. It is not at all evident, despite all the hard work that has gone into this report, how much really substantial has been accomplished, either in terms of exposing new issues that we had not previously thought of or in terms of bringing about a genuine reconciliation of competing views and attitudes.

Against that background, the government's reaction to all this is essentially this: it still firmly believes that the faults it identified in the legislation—the most important of them I described as the `seven deadly sins'—still remain. Although some effort has been made in the majority report to identify a slightly softened position so far as at least a couple of those amendment areas are concerned, I remain, as presently advised, unpersuaded that that has done enough to lead the government to change its position.

I do not want to take a final view on this issue. The government does not want to do so just yet so far as every single one of these amendments or so far as the drafting implications are concerned. What I do state, however, very firmly for the record is that, in relation to those matters that we identified previously as having either fundamental defects in principle or as, in our judgment, making the bill unworkable, the government is highly unlikely to change its mind. The particular areas that we adopt that attitude in relation to are certainly where there is the reference to those most severely dispossessed. It may be that some improved formula can be found for that, but nonetheless there is still a severe operational difficulty involved, as we see it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee has dumped that.

—I am not talking about the particular language but to the extent that people are still to be prioritised by reference to their access to land or anything else creates a particular problem. That is one of the areas. I mentioned it first because it was first on the list as we reached these issues last time. It still remains a problem for us, as we see it—not so much in principle; it never was a problem in principle. It is less of a problem in principle now with the proposed reworking, but it is certainly a fundamental practical problem, as I am presently advised.

PARA.TAB: The question of grants to individuals involves fundamental questions of principle in so far as to do that would be contrary to indigenous land-holding practices and what we are trying to achieve with the spirit of the bill. The question of the reference to health, housing and so on as things to be taken into account also involves problems of principle for us in so far as the land fund is to meet land needs, as we have constantly argued. We do not see that there is virtue in introducing additional considerations into that calculation of need.

The requirement in the present amendment that the ILC not have to consent to the sale of land is, we think, offensive in principle as it inhibits the capacity of land staying in Aboriginal hands, which is the fundamental purpose of the bill. The question as to the consultation with traditional owners, even if the terminology is changed a bit, still brings about, on the face of it, some fundamental operational difficulties in making the act work effectively in practice.

The requirement for there to be consultation on the regional and national strategies and so on, including with states, creates, as we see it and continue to see it, operational problems. There is also difficulties so far as the separate funds for administrative expenses are concerned, not to mention the $3 million cap. So they are all problems. I do not want to go into the substance in detail—

TALK.START.PARA: —We dumped the $3 million cap too. You obviously have not read the report. Maybe you should go away, read the bloody thing and come back.
—The language is still there in terms of the amount of funds that are required to be produced, and the separation of the $3 million for administrative purposes is still there.
—We do all this work and this guy does not even read the report.
—What I am saying with as much—
—What you say insults the people we spoke to.

—What I said to you at the very outset is that I have not had time, government ministers have not had time—I certainly have not, and I had the carriage of this bill in this place—given other preoccupations to date, to come to grips with the detail of the report, and that is why I am not making a final judgment about each one of these matters, except to say that those issues remain of importance for us. At this stage, as presently advised—I qualified all of my remarks on that basis—I do not see that there will be any fundamental shift in the government's position. So we will continue to have a stand-off in this place. We will have to work our way through that, and you will have to work your way through that.

PARA.TAB: I am fascinated by what you had to say, Senator Campbell, this morning on public radio. I do not know whether what you said represents a personal view or a view of the opposition or what it in fact signifies so far as your attitude to the bill is concerned if it is amended again or comes back to you from the House of Representatives in the original form that we wanted in relation to these particular issues. We will find out, I guess, in due course.

All I am saying is that, on particular substantive issues—and indeed one or two others as well, like the representation of ATSIC commissioners and so on—subject to further consideration of some matters of detail, the government, as presently advised, has not changed its mind as a result of the committee's work. If that all means that the committee's report has been a bit of a waste of time, that is no more than we said was likely to be the case anyway when you embarked upon this particular frolic. So be it and you cannot complain about getting that attitude now.

I do hope—this is the final point I want to make—that we can approach this issue in a way that does focus on the main game, and that is the necessity to get in place as soon as possible a land fund which will genuinely meet the aspirations and needs of the Aboriginal people. That is the political imperative—not any particular partisan posturing or manoeuvring. The imperative is to do a decent job for the Aboriginal people, to follow up and to put in place a corollary to the Mabo principles that we have accepted—the Mabo legislation—which will in fact mean that we can address another dimension of this whole fundamental problem of Aboriginal need. On that basis, I have nothing more to say at this stage, but no doubt I will have plenty more to say at a later stage of these proceedings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a great deal of time is available today to discuss the substantive amendments, so I do not propose to do that. But I would like to comment on several other matters addressed in the report. These two matters are the level of consultation which was embarked on both by us and by the government in its presentation of this legislation and also the role that ATSIC has played in this.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, in our journey around Australia I was amazed at the level of interest in the amendments among the Aboriginal community and the fact that many people made extremely lengthy journeys at very short notice in order to present their views to us. When the other members of the committee and I proceeded to ask witnesses when they first heard of the legislation, it was very illuminating to note that nearly all of them thought we meant the committee consultation. The fact that legislation had preceded this and that notice of that legislation had been available since last May or June was unknown to most of them. It was with some amazement that we proceeded to hear this. By contrast, as Senator Campbell has already well documented in other places, government spokesmen such as Senator Gareth Evans have described the consultation over the bill as `very exhaustive', `extensive consultation in relation to this bill' and `wide-ranging consultation'.

When we got to our meeting at Dubbo, we had considerable difficulty in starting the consultation because of the level of anger in the room due to the fact that nobody had known anything about the bill or the amendments until about two days before. Every person in that room who spoke for a group of people spoke out about the fact that they would need a great deal more time to really find out the views of their tribe, their clan or their family. Page 46 of the report sums this up very well; it even considerably understates it. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Considerable anger was evident throughout the public hearing in Dubbo over the lack of consultation.
Page 47 of the report reads:
. . . the overwhelming majority of witnesses consulted . . . complained that they had heard little or nothing about the Bill.

It took the committee most of the rest of that day to hear the very angry people who had known little or nothing about the legislation. This was a recurring factor throughout our consultations at Brisbane, Cairns, Darwin, Broome, Perth and Kalgoorlie.

PARA.TAB: The government claims that the legislation was widely circulated and that one of the mediums for this was ATSIC. Let me say at the start that I repudiate totally the charge of ATSIC bashing which has been levelled against my coalition colleagues and the majority reporters. That charge is laid on page 24 of the second minority report. The fact that ATSIC was not able to percolate knowledge of the legislation to the grassroots level of the Aboriginal community indicates to me that ATSIC is not being well served by the government and that it should be given more consultative processes or a greater degree of flexibility in the way that it consults with its own people.

It is not the fault of ATSIC personnel that they were not able to consult. In Tasmania, we heard from the ATSIC chief in that state that no consultation whatever had taken place in his organisation throughout Tasmania. You cannot be surprised that there was a considerable level of bewilderment and confusion over what this legislation means. We are not in the process of condemning ATSIC or the personnel involved, but obviously the role that they undertake needs to be looked at in a new light by the government.

There were individuals in ATSIC who appeared to take a reasonably lofty view of their role and the way in which people should have heard about this legislation. I instance the view of Darryl Pearce, the Director of the Northern Land Council, who spoke to us in Darwin. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a whole raft of people had an opportunity to read the bill and to start working out their concerns over the bill—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not ATSIC.

—I am talking about the Aboriginal bureaucracy, if you like, Senator Kernot. I am talking about the level of consultation. Mr Pearce is the Director of the Northern Land Council. What he said does indicate to some extent the point of view of the Aboriginal bureaucracy both in some of the land councils and in ATSIC itself. He goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it our fault that they did not?

It seems to me that, if we are going to go through a proper process of consultation, we are never going to get a bill through. No-one expects us, as is quoted in the minority report, to `consult to within an inch of our lives' or words to that effect. But there still must be a level of consultation at which many more of the Aboriginal people know about this legislation than was evident to us. That is something that certainly struck me to a great extent.

PARA.TAB: I point out that Senator Cooney, for whom I have the greatest respect and who proved to be excellent company on the consultations, did make a few comments in his report that I could only describe as misguided. He instanced the witnesses not being prepared to discuss the legislation with us. How could the witnesses be prepared if they did not have the faintest knowledge of what they were supposed to be talking about? That was because they had not been told anything and they did not know anything about it.
As I said, because ATSIC had been talked to by the government—it was one of the few groups who had—it did have a greater consultation. Page 180 of the report reads:
