SPEECH.PARA: Its evidence appeared to be based on a more measured consideration of and a greater consultation about the legislation than that of any other group.
At the Dubbo hearing, Mr Delaney, the Chairperson of the Sydney Regional Council of ATSIC, referred to the level of consultation. On page 180 of the Hansard, he said:

. . . from my understanding the consultation processes were carried out with the Kimberley Land Council, the Northern Land Council, the Central Land Council and the top end mob—the Cape York Land Council. NSWALC, to an extent, was included. Those were the consultations.

At that rate, it is no wonder that many of the people we spoke to did not have any idea. My whole point is that the consultation was carried out with only the upper echelons of both the land councils and the ATSIC organisation. On page 194 of the report and on page 2 of the minority report, there is a suggestion that the coalition believes that organisations should be unanimous behind every detail of the land fund legislation. As Senator Campbell suggested in public this morning, we do not believe, nor would we ever expect, that there would be unanimity. What we are looking for is a point of view. It is obvious that every Aboriginal person in Australia will not feel the same about this legislation. We were not after unanimity. We were simply after a point of view, and that was certainly provided to us.

PARA.TAB: I do not wish to use the time of the Senate at the moment, but I will certainly be making further comment on the amendments themselves when they are debated in the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point that I am using only five minutes of the Democrats' time. One issue that really does concern me is that of consultation, which was the whole reason for this committee. Consultation really did break down at the very end when the members of the committee were supposedly consulting with each other to determine where we were going on the report. For the first time ever in my five years in this place, not only was the draft report finished before any consultation had taken place with those members who did not support the majority but also the recommendations were included. I found that very difficult, particularly as the meetings were set up at a time when I simply was not able to get there and had no say as to when those meetings were set.

PARA.TAB: I wish to look at the bulk of the problem. If one thing is evident, it is that agreement was not reached on everything. We had views ranging from almost unanimous support for the position the Greens and the Liberal Party had adopted, right through to the point where ATSIC was adopting the recommendations of the government. As we have already heard from Senator Reynolds, ATSIC helped to draw up those recommendations. However, I believe we also have to give considerable weight to the views between these two, from the bulk of the larger organisations which, as you will see in the minority report, we have accepted as representing large numbers of Aboriginal people. While there were groups of people who certainly supported particular amendments, you cannot then extrapolate that to mean that they supported the bulk or all of the amendments, which is the way we have ended up balancing it.

While we did have a few people who were supportive of linking health, housing and education into the land fund, there were others who did not, although they did acknowledge the fact that health, housing and education are critical issues for Aboriginal people. You cannot then extrapolate that principle and say, `Okay, they also support the linking of those issues back into the land fund.'

I had great difficulty with the majority report. It acknowledged the fact that there is a great need in those areas in the community and that they are very important issues, but has tied them back again to land. If there was anything that virtually everybody agreed to, it was that an extra $3 million was required; yet the majority report states, `However, the committee does not recommend pressing the request.' In other words, the majority has decided not to press ahead with the one thing the bulk of Aboriginal people agreed to—that $3 million should go to the land fund as an administrative expense. The one thing that virtually everybody disagreed with—that the states not be involved—has remained in the report. I find that really amazing. I had hoped that, with consultation before that draft report was put together, we could have had a consensus on maybe a few things, but I do not believe the opportunity was really there.

Perhaps the most disappointing thing in all of this is that, after all that consultation, I do not believe either the opposition or the Greens really understand the urgent need for Aboriginal people to be given the opportunity to own land. I know there has been a lot of rhetoric, but we have a situation where, if we go ahead with these amendments, we will set up a land fund with so many strings attached that it will be susceptible not only to misinterpretation but also to endless legal challenge.

It simply is not good enough for the chair of the committee to say, `We're working on a principle here.' The law interprets what we put into words in this place. We cannot say, `On principle, health, housing and education are important,' and then tie these things in legislatively with the purchase of land. We cannot say, as we sometimes did to the witnesses, `It's the principle of greatest dispossession.' If we are going to stick to that and then put it into legislation, we will be setting the legislation up to fail. We are setting it up for ongoing litigation. As soon as land is granted, there will be a huge range of possibilities for those who did not get land to say, `I'm more dispossessed,' or, `I'm greater disadvantaged,' or, `No, it doesn't link that community to any education services; come back again and have a look at us.'

As I said at the press conference, this is really about spirit sickness. It is about the link of the Aboriginal people to the land. We really cannot talk about Aboriginal health and ignore the fact that the primary health problem of Aboriginal people is their need to have access to their traditional lands. Once we have cured that problem, we can start to look at immunisation programs, at various wellness programs and at health programs for women, men and children. But we cannot get into a situation where we tie this land fund up in endless strings and in reams and reams of red tape so that the whole problem of spirit sickness is simply not addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I must address the comments made by Senator Lees in relation to the operation of the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill. I invite Senator Cooney to perhaps address the question of procedural fairness, because I did not hear of any complaint by any other member of this committee about the way things were conducted.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees, I understand your personal circumstances and you have my condolences as to why you did not attend some of the committee hearings. However, it is unfair to attack the committee process of considering the matter whilst hearings were being conducted. That is entirely in order and it is entirely proper. With the strict reporting time limit we had, we had no other choice. I did not hear you complain, when we returned to parliament to draft the report, of not having an opportunity to make an input.

The chairman, Senator Campbell, did a fantastic job. I compliment my colleagues on this committee for the input and work they put into this report over a time which they normally might have spent at home with their families. I did not hear any of the others complain about the process in which this report was put together. The coalition and other participants approached this matter with an open mind and there were no preconceived decisions made.

In fact, the coalition stuck by the principle of the most severely dispossessed but dumped, as Senator Campbell said, the words `most severely dispossessed'. Let me also refer you to the minority report and tell you that there is misleading information in it. On page 195, 21 organisations are listed as supporting the stand by ATSIC. That is a falsity. The Kimberley Aboriginal Association has put out a press release dissociating itself from that report.
Senator Lees interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The association said that the minority report is wrong; that it never did and does not support the ATSIC stand. The Tharpuntoo group in Queensland feels the same.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not refer to Senator Cooney's report as well. Whilst I disagree with Senator Cooney's comments, they were well measured and considered. I say to the members who wrote the minority report that they have it wrong. There were only 19 organisations that supported ATSIC. I have calculated this and you can check it—a total of 84 Aboriginal community based organisations gave evidence and only 19 supported the ATSIC stance in part or in whole. That is less than 25 per cent. That is not what the minority report states. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, the hearings, rather than isolating the evidence of ATSIC, confirmed that the ATSIC position enjoyed strong support for all or part of its position from community based Aboriginal organisations . . .
Less than 25 per cent supported that. That is not strong support.

PARA.TAB: The survey I carried out—excluding the hearings for Darwin, Broome, Perth and Kalgoorlie because I did not have time to complete them—found that 18 groups supported the coalition amendment with regard to providing flexibility on how land is granted, while 11 groups opposed it. I am talking about a majority. What we had during these hearings—and I missed only one day—was overwhelming criticism of the lack of consultation. This is despite the fact that the government said it consulted extensively and exhaustively and that there had been wide ranging consultation. I do not know where the government consulted, but it certainly did not consult with the 244 individuals who gave evidence before the committee. The great majority of them were not consulted, and that is a disgrace.

The opposition would have loved the opportunity to have consulted with the Aboriginal community in relation to its amendments. However, we did not have that opportunity. The bill was forced upon us pre-Christmas. So we took the only avenue available to us: we moved for this committee to travel around the country—some 12,000 kilometres—to consult with various Aboriginal groups and individuals. The committee sent out over 3,000 notices and letters to advertise this.
I want to concentrate on four key amendments. I have mentioned the `most severely dispossessed' amendment. I cite the evidence given by Peter Yu from the Kimberley Land Council:

SPEECH.PARA: The reality [is] that there are varying levels of disadvantage . . . throughout the country.

He conceded that all Aboriginals had been dispossessed but that there were levels or scales of dispossession, of disadvantage. He pointed out that it would be sensible to assist those who were suffering the most disadvantage in terms of access to land. That, I believe, was in support of the coalition's principle of assisting those who were `most severely dispossessed'. We jettisoned those words because they did not meet with favour, and we kept an open mind on that. However, in relation to the question of regional strategies, there was overwhelming support for the government to consult with the grassroots and to devise a national strategy based on regional strategies.

PARA.TAB: There was some confusion about this. The Kullarri Regional Council in Broome, which had received the ATSIC package, was of the opinion that this was a bad amendment. When I questioned Mr Hunter on whether he wanted policy to come from the grassroots, he replied:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes. The national policy should reflect what the people at the grassroots are saying. That is how the government is supposed to be set up. You are supposed to listen.
Ms Sibosado followed that immediately with:
Through the regional strategies, you should set the direction for the national strategy rather than the reverse, because the national strategy would be too rigid . . .

This came from a group who had indicated that they opposed that amendment by the coalition, but when it was explained to them they changed their opinion and supported it. That is what they said, that it must come from the regional strategy, that you must build it up from the grassroots and not from the top down. If this government does not listen to that sort of evidence, then it is missing the boat in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs in this country.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the question of individuals. What we were saying was not that you give land just to individuals but that you have some flexibility so that you can cover this wide diversity that we witnessed over two weeks travelling around the continent; that is, you allow for corporations, trusts, families or individuals. In its report the committee said that it did not envisage that much land would be granted to an individual. Nonetheless, you should have that flexibility. Rosemary O'Grady, who appeared on behalf of the Kamali group, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We disagree with the concept of `corporation' . . . I am a great respecter of the law of corporations, and I believe that corporations are a wonderful invention. However, they are not appropriate for these Aboriginal communities.

We had overwhelming evidence, outstanding evidence, as to the importance of the family unit in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs in their daily life and how they conduct themselves and that a good way to approach the matter was on the basis of the family unit. You cannot do that with a corporation. We are not saying that corporations in themselves are evil but that we should have diversity so that the Indigenous Land Corporation can have the ability to choose how it grants the land so that it can accommodate the wide diversity that we came across.

PARA.TAB: The health and housing amendment was greatly misunderstood in that people thought that money would necessarily be taken from health and housing as a result of having those aspects in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because Meg Lees kept on telling them they would.

—Exactly. I agree that Senator Lees did not put it straight to them, and I think they laboured under the misapprehension that that would be the case. Despite that, I have already mentioned that there was support for that and again in some areas there was not. But the fact is you have to have that diversity so that you can take education, housing and all spiritual and cultural needs into account. It is not a cumulative definition; it is an alternative, and that is what needs to be remembered.

PARA.TAB: This was a very good committee. I applaud the work of the committee secretariat and the work done by my colleagues. I think this will be a landmark for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs in this country for evermore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will start by paying tribute to the secretariat: Sue Morton, Trish Carling and of course Dr Ian Willis, who kept with us around Australia, and Sheryln Millikin, the executive assistant. I pay tribute to Lisa Barrenger and Peter Zuccato from SAVO. I think everybody who came with the committee would agree that they did outstanding work. I also pay tribute to Ms Lyn Millar, Ms Val Poon, Ms Ros Paterson and Ms Nari Muscat whom I think everybody who was on the committee would acknowledge did outstanding work. Certainly, if I can adopt a phrase, they carried out their work above and beyond the call of duty. I also pay tribute to my colleagues on the committee and to Senator Campbell for the way he chaired it.

PARA.TAB: I have been asked about the issue of the witnesses who gave evidence that they had not been properly consulted. Many witnesses said that and many witnesses said that not only had they not been consulted but also, as a result, they had not been able to consult their associates so that they could come back with a combined view. People complained that they did not have sufficient time to comprehend the evidence and then to analyse it. I can only conclude from that that they were then not well equipped to give evidence that could be relied upon. I am not commenting on whether it was fair or not but that was the situation.

However, the overwhelming position with which the committee was faced was that witness after witness gave evidence as well as he or she could, certainly, but on the basis that they did not quite know what they were talking about. The complaint was, `We haven't been consulted and we haven't had a chance to consult with our associates.' If they were able to give cogent and well thought out evidence, of course, they would not have said that because they were all people who, I thought, were of the most reputable kind.

So we have some very outstanding witnesses saying, `I am unable to give evidence in the way I would like because I haven't been consulted. I haven't had a chance to analyse this material. I haven't had a chance to talk to those people to whom I want to talk and, therefore, I can only give you evidence off the top of my head.' Whereas the people who were supporting ATSIC's position said they did not want any more time to consult. They had gone to their associates, they had thought this through and the evidence they were giving was evidence that had been well analysed and well thought out, and came to us as a body of very cogent evidence.
Looking at evidence you cannot say, `There are 100 people here and 90 people support the proposition that we ought to have read—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying ATSIC's evidence was the only decent evidence? That is what you are saying. You think about what you are saying, Barney. You've just insulted a lot of people out there.

—No. You keep misunderstanding. Senator Campbell has raised the issue. I am saying, and Senator Ellison will accept this, that people claimed they had not had a proper chance to consider this bill, they had not been consulted—and that was the evidence again and again; you have to look at the evidence—and the evidence again and again consisted of complaints about not being consulted. The evidence again and again was that they had not had a chance to talk to their associates. If they had not had a chance to do that, how can I rely on their evidence? If their evidence was reliable, if their evidence were cogent, then there would not be a complaint that they had not been consulted.
—Are you saying that every other witness, apart from ATSIC, was not reliable?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —You say it; you say it on the record!

—Order! Senator Campbell! Senator Cooney, would you resume your seat for a moment. Senator Campbell, when you are called to order in future, I would ask you to respect the call of the chair. Senator Cooney, please continue.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think Senator Campbell is raising a fair point and I want to answer it. I am saying that, if a witness comes before the committee and makes a claim that he or she has not had a chance to consider matters because they had not been consulted and they wanted more time for consultation and they said, `We haven't had a chance to speak to our associates', the only conclusion I can come to—and it might be wrong—is that they wanted more time to consult, that they wanted more time to go to their associates. If they wanted more time to consult, if they wanted more time to go to their associates, my conclusion is that their evidence was not as strong or did not have the weight it would have had if they had consulted. I am simply repeating what was said.

PARA.TAB: I thought, in all innocence, that what was happening was that people were complaining about not being consulted. All I am saying is that, if they were complaining about not being consulted, they must have been complaining for a reason—that they had not had time to get their evidence prepared. I should imagine that when Senator Campbell, who is very fair, thinks about that he will see the force of what I am saying. All I am saying is that ATSIC did not make those complaints. ATSIC might be wrong, but it did not make those complaints. It said, `We have had enough time. We have had enough consultation. Here is the evidence.' It seems to me, as a person who came to this area not knowing much about it, that that was the sort of evidence that was quite cogent. That is why I accept it.

The other reason I accept the evidence of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, unless it is proved to be wrong, is that in 1989 we passed a bill in this parliament now called the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989. We made a preamble to that act, which is a bit unusual these days. Amongst those clauses which made up the preamble we said:

AND WHEREAS it is also appropriate to establish structures to represent Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to ensure maximum participation of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders in the formulation and implementation of programs and to provide them with an effective voice within the Australian Government;

SPEECH.PARA: We set up a body that was to represent the Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders on the basis of its being elected. If we want to keep the integrity of the concepts within this act, then we have to take notice of ATSIC. If we find that ATSIC is unsatisfactory, if ATSIC has passed its use-by date, that might be a matter we have to consider. We would go back to the old days of the department of Aboriginal affairs. I say that we should stick with the ATSIC concept until it is shown that something else should be done. If people have a complaint about ATSIC they have the opportunity of voting out the people now in ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: I finish by citing what a great parliamentarian, Sir Winston Churchill, said on 11 November 1947. I see you have some surprise that I should quote such a great man, Mr Acting Deputy President, but nevertheless I shall quote him because this statement applies to ATSIC. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Many forms of government have been tried and will be tried in this world of sin and woe. No one pretends that democracy is perfect or all-wise. Indeed, it has been said that democracy is the worst form of government except all those other forms . . .

ATSIC might have a lot wrong with it, but it is the best thing the Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders have going for them. If we are going to destroy, prejudice or impair it, then we are not doing the right thing by them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the tabling of this report of the Senate select committee today, I understand that Senator Campbell said in his press conference that the opposition will now not vote against this bill, whereas Mrs Gallus has not been quite as overt.
—You have got it wrong again, Cheryl.

—I listened to what you said, Senator Campbell. I think we need to address some of the rhetoric of the majority report, specifically the reasons given for the establishment of this committee. Let us not lose sight of the timing of the establishment of this committee. Some of these points need to be made.

PARA.TAB: This committee was established because at that time, under the leadership of Mr Alexander Downer, the Liberal Party wanted to avoid more than anything in the world taking a final vote on the land fund bill, thereby giving the government the possibility of a double dissolution trigger. Your present leader, Mr Howard, himself said yesterday that the reason the opposition was doing an U-turn, a backflip, on the migration bill was precisely that. That was the case back in December. You needed the extra time to sort out Liberal leadership problems. Clever tactic.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I draw the relevant standing order to your attention again, as I did earlier this afternoon. We are debating the report on the land fund bill. Like all other speakers, she should stay with the subject. If she will not stay with the subject, you should rule her out of order and sit her down.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I am debating the reasons for the establishment of the select committee. I believe it is entirely in order.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: in accordance with the traditions of this chamber, Senator Kernot was well within the bounds of relevance that we have tolerated in many debates—
—That's a joke.
—At times members of the opposition have pulled this stunt about relevance. They should consider the sort of precedent they are attempting to overturn when they do so.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: we did have a debate about the establishment of this committee at the time the committee was established. This matter was properly debated then. Senator Kernot made the snide and cheap political point she is making again now. But I do think it is irrelevant to this debate. We now have a report in front of us of some 200-odd pages. Senator Kernot is not making any attempt to debate the report; she is raising an entirely separate debate which was had in this place some sitting days ago when this select committee was established.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—I will rule on the point of order. I am listening to what Senator Kernot is saying and I take the view at this stage that she is in debate and as such she is allowed to range somewhat beyond the actual topic in hand. But I will continue to listen carefully and I ask her to stick as close as possible to the matter in hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the rationale for this committee's need to go and consult is expressed in the reasons for its establishment, and they are printed here. What I am saying is entirely relevant and, I suggest to you, will continue to be in order for that reason.

PARA.TAB: I think all of the Aboriginal groups whose amendments were sponsored by the members of the coalition and the Greens have a right to feel extremely disappointed at having that attachment to high principle on their behalf now abandoned. We have been chastised in this place before for setting up expectations which will then be dashed. Members of the coalition have done this this time to those Aboriginal people whose cause they champion. I think that is a great pity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—You don't like to hear it, do you?
—You are about as shallow as a birdbath.
—Order! Senator MacGibbon.

—It is quite improper for that senator to reflect on the motives of her colleagues. That is what she is clearly doing when she says that they played on the good feelings—to put it in more polite English than she is using—of Aboriginals with an intention to defraud them, to build them up and then not be able to deliver. I ask you to ask her to obey the standing orders.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I think it is quite appropriate for me to explain—not to reflect on their motives—how Aboriginal people will and do feel used by this process.

—I said in my ruling on an earlier point of order that I would listen carefully to the debate. At this stage, I still consider that Senator Kernot is in argument around a point. I will at this time allow her to continue.
—Could you please tell me how much time I have left.
—By the clock, just over four minutes.
—Thank you. I think we have to ask what we know at the end of the select committee process. We have to say: is there—
—The views of a lot of Aboriginal groups.
—Yes. You have heard the views—
—Who you didn't know before.
—No, I can't agree with you.
—What? You went out and spoke to them?
—Unlike other people in this place—and this is quite relevant to the whole discussion of the native title bill and this report—
—Here comes a spiel on who cares most.

—No, it is not. It is a matter of: if you regularly talk to Aboriginal people and if you think that you are capable of passing on an opinion expressed to you. That is the only point I am making. At the end of this process, at the end of 30 hours of discussion in the Senate—which I think was valuable discussion—at the end of your committee deliberations, we find that Aboriginal people have different views on this land fund, as they put to us when they came and spoke to us, when they rang us and when we had our own private consultations previously. We knew that.
—You want to impose your view.
—I don't. I want us to have a land fund—a land fund which works.
—You want to have it the way you want it; you don't want to give it to them the way they want it.

—I have listened to your views, Senator Campbell. The point I am making to you is: what can you say at the end of the committee process that is genuinely new, that was not canvassed in the debate here, in the committee or with us privately? I think it is very little. I really think you have to go back to the politics of the establishment of this committee.

PARA.TAB: Irrespective of what your views are on how much money should be in the land fund, on what constitutes appropriate consultation and on who does or does not support ATSIC, the reality is that in your attaching to this debate the high principle that you did—Senator Chamarette seemed to be very happy to hear from you the long debates about principle—what we have now are dashed hopes because those people will feel let down by you. That is the whole point I want to make.The good thing is we will get a land fund. That is an important point to make.

There is a lesson in this for the future. It is the same old lesson. The first lesson is that people take the evidence they want to and distort it to support their point of view wherever they can. The second lesson is that people who are expecting those in the opposition to stand up for the principles that they espouse at a certain time should look for those principles two months down the track and wonder if they have the right to expect that support to continue. That is the lesson from this. This is a backdown of gigantic proportions by the members of the Liberal Party. I just wonder if Senator Chamarette, who placed such trust in your approach to consultation and in your words that we see—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be sacked from the reconciliation council.
—In terms of reconciliation, Senator Campbell, what you are doing in publishing this and then moving away from your own amendments will do great harm to reconciliation in this country.

—I feel that time is too valuable to get involved in either political debate or rebuttal, so I would like to use this time to just reflect on some of the aspects of this committee's process and the outcomes.

PARA.TAB: One of the first issues is that a lot has been raised about consultation. I think there is no question that many people felt that the consultation was insufficient; there was a lack of time; and, even if it was consultation, it was not negotiation. We do need to put on the public record that there was a request made in many cases for a moratorium of at least six months for appropriate consultations that would lead to negotiation between Aboriginal groups which had not been consulted by the government in the setting up of the land fund bill.

Senator Kernot asked earlier: what do we know at the end of the process? I think what the committee definitely established is that there is no unanimity, and neither did we expect it. However, a degree of support emerged for various amendments, which established quite clearly that these amendments mirrored concerns in the Aboriginal community across this country which had not been considered and had not been accepted, if it had considered them, by the government. That is a very important acknowledgment to make.

There is only one other aspect of the previous discussion that I want to take up: the controversial term `the most severely dispossessed'. It is quite clear that the committee has taken on board the concerns that were expressed in the various hearings regarding this term. People were distressed at any implication that all Aboriginal people had not been dispossessed by white occupation. There was unanimity about that. They did not want to differentiate degrees of dispossession. But it needs to be made clear that many of those people felt it was imperative that the bill include a principle of allocation of a very scarce resource.

The major point here is that it is not a problem with phrasing. The committee has shown itself quite capable of modifying its stance in relation to the specific words. As Senator Evans said earlier, one of the obstacles of this amendment is that the bill, before amendment, states no mechanism for distribution. There is a preference that no principle of allocation of an extra $20 million or so a year be made in the bill.

This raises the point: if a principle is unstated, there is no mechanism to ensure who gets in first and who is last. A lot of Aboriginal people would prefer some principle to be stated that relates to dispossession from their traditional lands or to their disadvantage in relation to gaining access to lands. It is a legitimate request that needs to be considered by the government.

The second disadvantage of having no principle stated as to the way in which the funds will be allocated is that there is no guarantee within the bill, in the form the government wants it, that acquisition will have any preference over management. So the major concern that underwrites the government's difficulty with this amendment is the fact that, where there is a scarce resource of money available to distribute, some guiding principle should be included. The concern is that it may actually mean that some moneys will have to be given for acquisition of lands rather than the principle that could operate, which is that all could be used for the management of already held indigenous lands.

The Greens (WA) have presented three amendments within the debate which were not supported in the Senate. The committee gave us an opportunity to see whether those concerns—and they are very specific concerns of the Greens—were apparent in the wider community. I do not think there was a single person who gave evidence who did not comment on the inadequacy of the amount. A lot of them were totally surprised to know that $1 billion a year was not being allocated, or they thought that at least at the end of 10 years $1 billion would be given for the fund. Some of them were shocked to learn that the increased allocation amounts to only $24 million a year above that which is already available via the ATSIC acquisition and management funding. The comment was made of how inadequate the amount is. It remains a major concern for the Greens and leads to our great difficulty in supporting the land fund bill.

A second issue mentioned in the committee hearings which was not able to be supported either in the Senate or by the majority or minority reports of the committee was the request by many Aboriginal groups for the capacity to revive native title on any land that was acquired. It is a surprising omission that the government cannot look at that because it actually addresses the concern about disposal. If native title were able to be revived, it would mean that it was inalienable and any problem about it being taken away from Aboriginal people would be totally overruled.

A final point, and one which was raised repeatedly in the hearings, was that Aboriginal people were very concerned that this land fund bill should not be regarded as compensation. Of course if that happened, then those who gain nothing from it may be in jeopardy of really addressing the dispossession that they had suffered.

Basically, following the tabling in the Senate today of the committee's report, the key question still remains of whether the Senate should agree to a land fund which may satisfy the land needs of a small number of people but leave a much larger number with their dispossession unaddressed.

I think the process that the committee went through has been, in the end, disappointing. I might clarify here: it was not the least bit disappointing in relation to the witnesses, who all gave extremely valuable testimony which should be respected and deserves respect—and I hasten to add that, regardless of whether it was given in emotional terms or on a factual basis, it is all worthy of respect; I am not expressing a disappointment with the secretariat, as they did a magnificent job—and I want to thank them for it; it is not a disappointment with Hansard, who also did a wonderful job, neither is it with the sound technicians; and it is not a disappointment with members of the committee who attended the hearings.

But in the end, I do feel disappointed with the stance taken by some members of the committee. The government senators, and Senator Lees from the Democrats, seemed to have taken the role of defending the government bill without amendment. They have, quite rightly, pointed to a lack of unanimity amongst Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders. But unfortunately, they have demonstrated an inflexibility in their approach, despite all the criticisms that were levelled at the bill and the amendments.

It is quite obvious that there are different views across Australia. But if the land fund is worthy of support, it must go to redressing the dispossession of all Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders, not just a select few who may be lucky enough to be targeted by the government bill.

The Greens (WA) believe that the government's bill will in no way go to meeting the land needs of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders. I think the committee itself can feel proud that, for the first time, there is a full record of the views of 244 Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders and the organisations that these people represent. This must be the largest record of the views of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders which has been made—certainly by this parliament. I hope many non-indigenous Australians will read that record which contains the views that were expressed on a political issue which is so dear to the hearts of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders.

What happens now to this bill is in the hands of the government. It would not listen to the Senate. I believe that the amendments have been supported and are worthy of consideration, particularly if it means that the opposition is willing to support the land fund bill—a bill which the government seemed to be so eager to gain support for. But, as we have seen, the government refused to listen to the Senate; will it listen to the views of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders?

Essentially, at the present time the government's bill is in its own hands. If it seeks to persist with saying that it will only have the unamended bill, then it may be that the bill will fall. However, it has the opportunity of addressing not just the views put up by the parliament, which are legitimate views in their own right, but also those of the Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders across the country who have been consulted and to whom this committee has paid the courtesy of giving a hearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Under standing order 191, I make an explanation, as I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Kernot misrepresented something that I said both in my speech and at a press conference this morning, regarding the opposition's position on this bill. It is very important for the record that the Senate understand the opposition's position. That is, the bill comes back into this place next week, I hope—and I have had a private undertaking from the office of Senator Gareth Evans that the bill will come back in here when we resume. I genuinely hope it does. I hope the government will not delay the Senate's consideration of this bill. We will then see what the government wants to do with our amendments and with the recommendations of the report.

PARA.TAB: At that stage the coalition will make a decision as to what happens. We first have to find out whether the bill goes to the House of Representatives, and then how it comes back over here. At that stage all opposition and other senators will have to make a decision as to whether we insist on our amendments. I cannot pre-empt—and I cannot speak for the coalition party room; it is hard to pre-empt that at any stage—what we will do, whether or not we will insist on amendments.

I think it would be fair to say on behalf of my coalition colleagues that that will be determined to some extent on the constructive nature, or otherwise, of the government's view of the recommendations in this report. I guess I have enough lack of cynicism to take Senator Gareth Evans at his word: that he will look at the report; that he will think about it; and that he will take the hand that we have handed out to the government and be constructive about this. If he does not, my level of cynicism about parliament and government will rise slightly higher than it is already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators will recall that the Senate made a large number of amendments to the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992. One particular amendment, based on a recommendation of the Select Committee on Community Standards in June 1992, had imposed a moratorium on the broadcasting of R-rated material on pay television while the Australian Broadcasting Authority undertook a program of research into the attitude of Australians to the prospect of R-rated material on pay TV.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Broadcasting Authority tabled its report on 7 December 1994 and, based on the findings of attitudinal research, it has recommended that R-rated material be approved by parliament for broadcasting on pay TV. On that occasion Senator Tierney, Senator Harradine and I made some comments about the ABA report. I was a little more complimentary than Senator Tierney. Nevertheless, we did have some concerns with some of the contradictory statements that came out of that report: not least, I would argue, because it was not possible on the basis of the way in which the research had been undertaken to clarify precisely what kind of R-rated material the findings were based on.

Some of those results were contradictory. That is the difficulty that we have faced throughout our inquiry. People are unclear about precisely what is R-rated material. Is it material that has a certain degree of sexual innuendo? Is it material that is realistic in the depiction of sexual activity? Is it material that is a little bit violent; perhaps with one shockingly violent scene or continual violence and violent scenes—particularly sexually violent scenes?

The answers to those questions are not readily found. It is not found in the community; it is certainly not found by talking to people at the Office of Film and Literature Classification because such a diversity and range of material is put into this R category. That is very much why the committee made the recommendation that we have. I will take the opportunity to read the recommendation in full:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee, having regard to the following matters:
(i) the community's concerns about the levels of violence in the media, especially depictions of sexual violence, and of realistic and degrading, demeaning or exploitative sexual material;
(ii) the contradictory views expressed about the effects of such depictions on attitudes and anti-social behaviour; and
(iii) the lack of clarity of the R classification which permits an excessively broad range of material to be permitted within its definition;
recommends that R-rated material be not permitted on pay TV.
The committee also recommends:

That the Office of Film and Literature Classification undertake a comprehensive overhaul of the R classification to define with greater precision the criteria to be used in rating violent, sexually violent, realistic and degrading, demeaning or exploitative sexual material, taking into account its intensity and extensiveness, to ensure its appropriateness for viewing in the home environment.
When the Attorney-General has tabled a revised R classification, the Committee will reconsider its recommendation.

The committee's report clearly demonstrates the many complexities of this issue. Unfortunately, an opinion given by the Office of the General Counsel suggested that, under the terms of the act, the two houses have to vote either yes or no on the question of whether R-rated material should be permitted to be broadcast on pay TV.

PARA.TAB: Because of the committee's serious concerns about the suitability of much R-rated material to be broadcast on pay TV, the committee has seen the need to recommend that no R-rated material be permitted. However, we have indicated that, if its primary concerns about the range—the diversity and lack of precision—contained within the current R classification are met, of course, we will be happy to reconsider.

It may seem to many senators listening to this debate, and indeed to some members of the community, that if R-rated material is permitted for sale or hire to adults by all state and territory governments within their jurisdictions—and the Australian Broadcasting Authority found that 82 per cent of respondents to its survey were in favour of adults having the option of watching R-rated programs on pay TV—then what is the problem?

The problem is that, just as respondents indicate a certain view, if you proceed through the report you find alternative and quite contradictory views expressed; for example, women in particular are extremely concerned about sexually violent material. Equally, contradictory views were expressed about whether people believe that viewing extreme material influences their behaviour. While the research is unable to give a definitive opinion on whether or not there is a link, it is equally unable to demonstrate to us that there is not a certain impact on some disturbed and immature personalities.

Therefore, the committee is of the view that there are several problems. The main problem is that, when the officers of the Film Censorship Board assess the appropriateness of a film for classification, they are operating under guidelines which permit them to give the same R classification to depictions of violence, sexual violence and sexual material for cinemas and videos, despite the fact that the age restriction in the case of cinemas is strictly enforced while, in the case of videos, once the material enters the home environment, it is inevitable that minors will gain access.

Senators would be aware that in recent months we invited primary school children to come to the parliament to talk to us about their viewing habits, particularly in relation to a reference we were considering at that time on computer games. We were somewhat alarmed to hear from a number of those primary school children that they were watching R-rated material and, in fact, some have watched X-rated material.

Clearly, these are not issues about which we can make any form of snap decision, saying, `Maybe there aren't any problems.' I think there is enough concern in the community—there is enough violence in the community, particularly sexual violence—for us to take stock and proceed with some caution, and that is what we are doing.

Senators should note that the principle behind the R classification is fundamentally that it is material that is unsuitable for a minor to see. Yet minors can and do gain access to R-rated material on video in the home, and they will have more ready access should R-rated material be permitted on pay TV.

There will be arguments about disabling devices and PINs that make it `impossible' for children or underaged people to gain access to the material. There were all kinds of practical problems that the committee had presented to it from a number of witnesses which suggested that disabling devices, as far as we are aware, are far from foolproof. Because of the nature of the technology, young people are more likely to be au fait and competent in managing the new technology than many parents—myself included.

The committee has undertaken a comprehensive inquiry into the prospect of R-rated material on pay TV. It has taken evidence from a wide range of witnesses. We talked to the industry, of course. We talked to teachers. We talked to parents. We talked to psychologists, academics and a range of other people with a general concern about this issue. We carefully studied the results of attitudinal studies, such as those I have already mentioned conducted by the Australian Broadcasting Authority.

The committee notes that there is considerable disquiet in both the expert community and the general community about the effects or the possible effects on attitudes and behaviours of current levels of violence in the media, especially depictions of sexual violence and exploitative sexual material. The committee is concerned about the long-term effects of such material on society, particularly on our youth.

While there is contradictory evidence about the effects in the short term, there was a commonality of view that constant exposure to such material not only desensitises the individual but leads to a shift towards a less empathetic culture which may be more accepting of violence as a norm. While the media are only contributors to the development of a nation's culture, the media's influence is nonetheless significant. That is why we have recommended that we proceed with some caution and seek greater clarity from the Office of Film and Literature Classification in regard to definitional issues related to R-rated material.

In an interview that I gave this afternoon, after the tabling of this report this morning, a particular questioner from the media asked me, `What's going to happen to the industry? If there isn't R-rated material for pay TV, the industry won't survive, it won't make a profit. What will you do then?' I have to say that my answer was very firm: if the pay TV industry is unable to be economically viable without using violence and sexual violence, I think the industry has to look very closely at its motives and its methods.

There is a wide diversity of material of entertainment and educational value to which we can apply the new pay TV technology. For the time being, we have said, `If the industry is going to fall in a heap just because it cannot use extremes of violence, then, I am sorry; sometimes in society there are more important issues than the profit motive.' I commend the report to the Senate.

In conclusion, I place on record, in my capacity as the chairperson of the committee, my appreciation of the input of my colleagues. The issues we are debating raise very personal and diverse responses. I think it is a tribute to all members of this committee that we have been able to present a unanimous report. On occasions, we wondered whether this would be possible. When we got down to the last few hours and in the final stages and after agreeing to hundreds perhaps thousands of words, we were actually debating whether or not two or three words would be included.

It is a tribute to all members of the committee that we have reached a consensus. This demonstrates that this is not an issue that is dealt with lightly. It is not an issue for partisan positions. It is an issue which we do not have ready answers for. But, ultimately, what we have done in the recommendations we have made is to say to senators that this is an issue of great importance, an issue that has implications for the future, and we should be absolutely sure about the recommendations we make; therefore, a little more time and precision is required from the Office of Film and Literature Classification before we can make a final report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the debate on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards which inquired into R-rated material on pay TV and to support the remarks of Senator Reynolds. What we have been through over the last 2 1/2 years with the production of this report and the consideration of this issue is a very long and, at times, arduous debate. I pay special tribute to the chair of the committee, Senator Margaret Reynolds, for the way she has guided this process over that time. We have been debating two principles in the censorship act. One is that adults should be able to see and hear what they like and the other is that children should be protected. As legislators we have a very awesome responsibility in relation to where we finally draw the line and what we allow into society.

PARA.TAB: I also pay a special tribute to a former member of the committee, my predecessor as deputy chair, Shirley Walters. Since retiring from the Senate she has been following this matter with great interest. She was a major contributor to the debate in the early days. I think it is a great tribute to democracy that across all parties—coalition parties, the Labor Party and the Democrats and independents; Senator Brian Harradine made a major contribution—in the end we could debate this matter for so long and then finally come to a resolution and an agreed set of words and an agreed set of recommendations.

It is something that the public does not often hear about. Politicians are bagged all over the place and people watch question time and make disparaging comments about it. But the report we have before us is a good news report. The press does not very often come in and watch the actual procedures that go into making these reports. It is not something they report on. If everybody is very cooperative members of the press do not tend to say very much about it. They like to report conflict and division. That accounts for a very small amount of the time spent in this place. Most of the time a group of reasonable people sit around in committees trying to work out what is best for the nation. I think the work of this committee is an excellent example of that.

What we have done in our work over time is basically three things. One is that we have monitored the research of the ABA which, as the broadcasting act was set up, was supposed to be a major adviser on this issue. Having had several concerns about this matter, we conducted very wide community consultations and spoke to many experts in this field. Then, as I have already indicated, we carried out a considerable amount of debate in the committee.

The main issue we were concerned with, in terms of what the legislation originally set out to do, was the way the ABA research was conducted. It is regrettable that the ABA did not listen a little more clearly to what the committee was saying because we had major reservations about the ABA's research. I do not want to go into that in great detail at this point because I have put it on the Senate record at other times. Just to summarise basically what was wrong: when you carry out research, particularly surveys in the community, you should in the end be measuring what you think you are measuring.

The major problem with what the ABA was doing with its research was that it was dealing with something that it was very difficult for the public to understand; that is, the nature of R. Senator Reynolds has alluded to some of these problems. The research showed that 30 per cent of people have never seen an R-rated program. It is very difficult to give a judgment on something you have never seen. The other thing that Senator Reynolds mentioned was that a lot of the research was internally contradictory. A majority of people said they wanted R but the report also showed that they did not really want sex and violence, sexual violence in particular. Under R, as it is currently defined, sexual violence is allowed—under certain conditions.

It became very clear to the committee that people, not having seen the movies or the full range of R, not really understanding what is a very complex and murky sort of definition of R, could not come to some sort of reasonable conclusion base. I suppose in a research sense the only way you could have got a result was to sit people down and make them watch a full range of R material and then make a decision. You would have got a correct reflection if you had done that, but in a democracy you cannot sit people down and force them to watch material they do not want to watch. If you let people self-select, you get a biased survey. So the conundrum we were faced with was that the ABA was researching something that could not be researched properly anyway.

The second problem was that the ABA drew incorrect conclusions from that research; and its internal inconsistency is something I have pointed out already. That is why probably the major recommendation in this report is to hold fire on this issue for a while and let the Office of Film and Literature Classification come up with a definition of R that more reflects what happens in R and get a system that is a little more sophisticated to take into account the extensiveness and intensity of the material.

To give an example of two films that showed the range of problems, there is a delightful movie that has an R classification called World According to Garp. It has an R classification but the reasons for the R are reasonably subtle and you would probably be reasonably comfortable with most teenagers and children watching it. On the other hand, the horrific movie Salo that has been banned around the world and has been banned in Australia for 17 years finally slipped through the Film Review Board and is now available with an R classification. Admittedly, it has some restrictions but we are finding increasingly that those restrictions are broken. I am reasonably confident that this material will end up on pay TV some day. What are people to make of it as they both have an R classification?

We had a great problem trying to get expert opinion if we were not satisfied with what the ABA had to say. Most of the research in this area tries to link cause and effect. When you are talking about human behaviour in complex social situations it is extremely difficult for any social scientist to say, `This cause has this effect' and tease it out from all the other causes. That does not mean that the cause and effect are not there but that, with the complexity of the situation and the limited tools of the social scientist and the psychologist, it is difficult to establish it.

We found an increasing amount of anecdotal and disturbing evidence that there were socially and personally undesirable outcomes from people watching this sort of material. The anecdotal material is building at a fairly alarming rate. There is the case in the United Kingdom of the movie Childsplay 3, where some young children murder a younger child. The children in the Bulger case murdered James Bulger in circumstances remarkably parallel with the videotape, and that is just one example.

It is difficult to establish cause and effect but one thing the researchers all agree on is that watching this sort of material can have a reinforcing effect. This is of great concern when it is put into the home environment. If men watch movies involving violent scenes between men and women it is not going to make them into wife bashers. But if they are wife bashers already—and there is a considerable number of those in our community—watching that material will reinforce that sort of behaviour. We have social programs which try to stop events like wife bashing but if the parliament allows this sort of material into the community, it can countermand what we are trying to achieve.

Of great concern to the committee was rapidly evolving technology. This technology may be of some assistance with R and pay TV because there are disabling devices. We were not convinced, having looked at the evidence overseas, that these disabling devices would work sufficiently well. Senator Reynolds has pointed out some of the reasons why a disabling device probably will not work. Parents do not switch it on, children get around the system and the Canadian evidence, in particular, indicates that a large number of children would get access to this sort of material even with that technology. But perhaps the most frightening prospect of the technology is that it is evolving so rapidly that if we set down a legislative regime now, we do not know what the technology is going to be in 10, 15 or 20 years. Shades of it are already appearing. Indeed, some of the products that can rapidly change what we have are already coming onto the market. To give you some examples: the fact that we now have a telephone, a television and a computer as three separate entities will disappear probably in the next five to 10 years. We will have one unit that will do all three things. So television technology, which R and pay would come down to, could be easily merged with computer technology.

With the CD-ROMs now available it would be possible to put material on it that is horrific and very graphic. This graphicness can be added to considerably by the advent of virtual reality. The way it could work is you could plug a headset in, put it on your head and, instead of watching a television screen, the effect of the new technology is that it seems like you are there, just as we are here now looking at others. That will create greater intensity and the possibility of repetitiveness. The effects of this on the social behaviour of young people, given their young and immature minds, could be dramatic. We must have great concern about that. That is the reason we believe that what we do with pay TV perhaps should be more analogous to what we did with computer games.

Video computer games technology will merge with this technology within the next five to 10 years. The Attorneys-General, state and federal, quite wisely decided to stop this material at the MA classification and have no R and X. That is what we are suggesting with this material. Because of rapid social change, because of rapid technological change in this area, bar on pay TV, this legislation should proceed with great caution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As time is very limited, I will cut my speech short. I would like first of all to acknowledge the cooperative work that has been performed in the committee, particularly under the chair of Senator Margaret Reynolds and the deputy chair, John Tierney. I would like to pay tribute to the secretariat and to acknowledge the work that has been done by those persons who have presented evidence and written submissions to the committee.

PARA.TAB: It is very important that we as a chamber, as a Senate, as members of parliament, should get information from the electors—the public—about the issues that we are considering. This is part of our representative functions. I see this committee as part of our representative functions. I include also the people who are in authoritative positions, including the OFLC and the Film and Literature Board of Review. We are grateful to them for always responding to requests that we make.

I do not suggest that we agree with them all the time, and I suppose that is one of the issues at stake in our report. Nevertheless, they are attempting to do a job. I happen to believe that the composition of the OFLC needs a review and consideration in the various boards. But that is a separate issue.

We are bound as a parliament to give serious consideration to the consequences of having another level of readily available R classified material in the home environment. I feel that is a major issue and is reflected in the report. Other speakers have referred to the range of material that is contained in the R classification. The guidelines are repeated on page 67 of our report, which deals with why a film is rated R—18+. It states that material considered likely to be harmful to those under 18 and of possible offence to some sections of the adult community warrants an R classification. So far as language is concerned, there are virtually no restrictions on language in R films. Sexual intercourse or other sexual activity may be realistically implied or simulated. Highly realistic and explicit depictions of violence may be shown but not if unduly detailed, relished or cruel. Depictions of sexual violence are acceptable only to the extent that they are necessary to the narrative and not exploitative. Drug abuse may be depicted but not in an advocacy manner. Extreme horror and special effects usually warrant an R.
Let me go to the question of violence. According to the OFLC, graphic, realistic and bloody violence is allowed, but not if it is

SPEECH.PARA: brought upon to an extent that invites vicarious pleasure from the viewer. That, of course, is to be a subjective judgment by the OFLC. I saw the film Salo. Salo has an R classification. In the part of our report entitled Video and computer games and classification issues which dealt with classification issues, we indicated briefly what Salo was all about.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, we described Salo as depicting sexual degradation and torture by four high-ranking functionaries of a group of young prisoners. They were teenagers of both sexes who were rounded up by the fascist authorities during the closing stages of the Second World War. The degrading and offensive acts range from perverted sexual practices, such as urolagnia and coprophilia, through to brutal violence and murder.

PARA.TAB: I saw that film in a theatre as part of my duties. I must say that I have seen numerous R and X classified films and videos. I looked at that film with one half of my mind on the actual classification guidelines and the other half on the screen. At the same time I was attempting to assess the technical merit of the film. In my view, that film clearly should not have received an R classification. To its credit, the OFLC did not give it an R classification, but the Film and Literature Board of Review did. Therefore, the themes and depictions contained in that film can be included in the R classification.

When we asked a representative of the Film and Literature Board of Review whether that film would get an R classification if were submitted as a video, the response was that it would probably not receive a classification. In other words, it would be refused classification. That is very interesting. Obviously, that presumably meant that the board saw a difference between an R category that could be shown in the cinemas and an R category that could go into the home environment. How this suggestion makes sense under existing laws is yet to be fully tested.

I have also seen other R-rated films, one of which did include sexual violence. To my mind, it was a serious treatment of the particular issue involved. To my mind, it was appropriately classified R. It appears that the word `extent' used by the OFLC to qualify the R category guidelines depends on the particular interpretation the censor places on it on a particular occasion.

What we are saying is that the classification presently encompasses too broad a range. We have said that the OFLC should undertake a comprehensive overhaul of the R classification to define, with greater precision, the criteria to be used in rating violent, sexually violent, realistic and degrading, demeaning or exploitative sexual material, taking into account its intensity and extensiveness, to ensure its appropriateness for viewing in the home environment—bearing in mind that children, as well as persons of disturbed or immature minds, are inevitably going to view the material.

I have referred to violent material and sexually violent material. We also refer to material that is realistic, degrading and demeaning or exploitative sexual material. There is some R classified material which is not physically violent but is demeaning and degrading. For example, a number of the R classified films have the same theme content and intent as the X classification, save only that they have been taken at a different angle.

Some of these films have themes of sexual harassment involving workplace sexual favours. In my view, they are demeaning and degrading. There are also films in the R category which, whilst not physically violent, could be termed `exploitative sexual material'. That material commodifies and objectifies women, mainly. Rather than treating them as free and responsible initiators of human activities, that sort of material, although non-violent, treats women as sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience. Group sex scenes depicting diverse sexual activities are a feature of much of that material.

It might be said by some that this is `spice' material and suitable for going into the home environment. Let me tell the Senate that we received evidence indicating that counsellors and psychologists are concerned that this material is used as a facilitator for the sexual abuse of women and children. That must be of concern to the community. We did have evidence that children of around the age of eight can distinguish, so far as violent material is concerned, between fantasy acting and real life. It just so happens that the exploitative sexual material I am talking about is real life. If somebody in the home environment is attempting to seduce a child victim—and we had evidence that this has occurred—then the child, obviously, in viewing this material, would not be able to make such a distinction because it would be depicting what was actually happening. That is something we should be concerned about.

My time has nearly expired—I have one minute to go—so I will conclude by saying this: the legislation does say that there should be disabling devices if R-rated material is on pay TV. We have dealt with the question of disabling devices in, I think, chapter 5 of this report. As the chairperson has said, nobody is going to suggest that they are absolutely foolproof, but they do assist. I commend parents and others to have disabling devices if they have subscribed to pay TV.

I thank the Senate. I hope that in a cooperative way the OFLC and the Attorney-General will take on board our recommendations so that we can revisit this matter and the parliament can then have a look at the matter.

I then interjected, requesting Senator Coulter to indicate to the Senate and the people of Australia exactly how much natural forest is left in the state of South Australia. He then said:

SPEECH.PARA: You make my point exactly. The other states should have been planting plantations over many decades.

He then praised the softwood plantations in South Australia. It is important for the record to be set straight because basically what Senator Coulter is doing is praising the work of the founders of South Australia, who basically levelled the forests within that state and then replaced them with softwood plantations. As a Tasmanian senator it is somewhat rich having to listen to a lecture from a South Australian senator about world heritage values and environmental values.

PARA.TAB: If we have a look at South Australia and compare its record to my home state of Tasmania we get some very interesting figures. A total of 20.2 per cent of my home state is in world heritage areas. In other words, slightly over one-fifth of my home state is completely locked up and will never be subjected to the chainsaw or the axe. That is 1.37 million hectares out of 6.793 million hectares in Tasmania. That is a very large proportion.

Let us then have a look at South Australia's record. South Australia has a land mass 13 times that of Tasmania—indeed, a land mass of 98.4 million hectares. We then ask: out of that 98.4 million hectares, how much is world heritage listed? Guess what the answer is—only 300 hectares. That is, 0.0003 per cent of South Australia is world heritage listed compared to 20.2 per cent of Tasmania. TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to raise briefly the situation of human rights in Vietnam and the actions of the Australian government in relation to that. The recent imprisonment of leading members of the United Buddhist Church of Vietnam is a major breach of basic human rights by the Vietnamese government. PARA.TAB: The Vietnamese foreign minister, Mr Nguyen Manh Cam, has been in Australia this week. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard letters that have been written to Senator Evans and to the Prime Minister of Vietnam from the head of the United Buddhist Church of Vietnam in Australia, the Very Venerable Thich Phuoc Hue, drawing attention to the recent disgraceful imprisonment of leading Buddhist figures in Vietnam and seeking their release.
