PARA.TAB: There is also growing doubt as to Senator Evans's approach to Foreign Minister Nguyen about a reported proposed Australian delegation to Vietnam later this year. Senator Evans was extremely coy about this in his answer to my question on it in the Senate yesterday. I understand that reports are circulating in Canberra that Senator Evans is not insisting on having a member of the Australian-Vietnamese community in the delegation. Failure to do so would represent a massive sell-out of the large Australian-Vietnamese community.

I find it extraordinary that Senator Evans has so far refused to say what delegation there may be in mind to visit Vietnam. He has refused to confirm whether it would examine the human rights situation in Vietnam. He has refused to give any details about its composition or personnel, including the important question of whether the Australian government would have the final say on its composition.

The economic development that has occurred in Vietnam over the past several years is to be welcomed. However, it ought to be welcomed in the recognition that Vietnam remains one of the world's poorest nations as a result of the economic devastation that has been wreaked on it by the communist regime over the past 20 years. There appears to have been little or no improvement in the human rights situation over the same period. Hundreds of persons remain imprisoned for their political views. The United Buddhist Church of Vietnam continues to be savagely repressed and its leaders regularly imprisoned, many of them—including their patriarch and the head of the church—for many years.

The Australian government has a responsibility, as a free and democratic member of the international community, to do all it can, through whatever peaceful means, to encourage the restoration of freedom, democracy and respect for basic human rights in Vietnam. I and many other Australians are concerned that the Keating government may have decided to take the soft option on this matter. If it does take the soft option and the soft approach, it will do a grave disservice not only to the people of Vietnam but also to the people of Australia, including in particular those proud Australians of Vietnamese origin.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to take a few minutes of the Senate's time to speak about an Australian Industrial Relations Commission decision affecting an important company in Tasmania—Comalco, at Bell Bay. The Industrial Relations Commission seems to have been the subject of a number of controversial decisions in recent months. Australia's industrial relations environment has become a fiasco in which employers are uncertain of their responsibilities and employees are uncertain of their rights. In past times there was a general belief that government had a responsibility to ensure that employers and employees were provided with a framework of legislation within which each group could sensibly go about their work with a reasonable expectation of fairness and justice under the law. It is therefore most regrettable to see that, in December, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission made a decision ruling the staff employment contracts of Comalco Aluminium at Bell Bay invalid. It is particularly regrettable because, without duress, the vast majority of Comalco's work force had voluntarily, and after much negotiation and discussion, chosen to enter into these contracts.

PARA.TAB: The Comalco aluminium smelter at Bell Bay in northern Tasmania was originally established in the 1950s by the Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments combined. Comalco took over the operation in 1961 and expanded the size of the smelter to a peak employee level of nearly 1,300 workers in 1984.

The drive to keep the smelter viable in the face of falling world aluminium prices and in competition with larger, newer and more technologically advanced smelters both in Australia and overseas has seen the work force reduced to a current level of just over 600 people. This has been done by employing more efficient management techniques and better working practices and, where possible, by ensuring that the best possible productivity levels are achieved from the now ageing technology of the 40-year-old plant.

Comalco Aluminium at Bell Bay has been a large employer in northern Tasmania as well as providing many jobs for ancillary and support businesses in the area and throughout the state. It still continues to produce aluminium and provide jobs, even though it is now accepted that its long-term future can only really exist in changed electricity supply situations, with redeveloped plant and changed workplace situations.

With these needs in mind and facing the essential task of maximising productivity within the limited and now ageing technology available, Comalco management has recently set about the job of reforming its work force culture. During 1993 and 1994, Comalco conducted negotiations with its non-staff employees with the aim of bringing all workers on to staff and employed under individual contracts. Following offers to 430 workers to accept staff contracts in mid-1994, 408 accepted the offer. As the contracts were to rely to a considerable extent on an environment of trust between levels of employees, the fact that so many workers accepted this change reflected very well on the industrial relations culture existing at the Bell Bay plant.

For most of the workers who signed the contracts and joined the staff, pay levels rose considerably—in some cases by about $8,000 a year. But the intent of many of the changed conditions related to acceptance of a heightened concept of mutual benefit and responsibility amongst all workers. It should be emphasised that those workers who elected not to take up the offer of staff employment were not disadvantaged and continue to work under their relevant award. The company also accepted that the award served a role as a safety net for those who have accepted staff contracts.

Following the changeover—remembering that this occurred as recently as the middle of last year—a number of trends in productivity and quality control have shown marked improvements. There have been fewer injuries; less sick leave has been taken; there have been better purity levels of metal produced; and there has been a markedly improved attitude reflected through workers' responsibility to their work and their commitment to the wellbeing of the plant. Notwithstanding the increased expenditure flowing from the acceptance of staff contracts, Comalco has been able to claim a decreased cost of production per tonne since the changes were made.

All this would appear to have been a win-win situation seldom seen in industrial relations issues. But not so. Enter the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. In December the commission decided that the company's individual work contracts were invalid. The Industrial Relations Commission decision basically ruled that individual contracts do not fit into the present industrial landscape under present legislation. Thankfully, it is likely that this could well be challenged.

The sooner the Keating government gets its industrial relations act together, the sooner companies like Comalco and its workers will be able to get on with the job of making our economy and our country more competitive in the world market. The longer that industrial relations is based on the priority to protect the union's hold on Australian workers and to protect the jobs of union bosses before the jobs of ordinary Australian working people, the longer Australia will stay uncompetitive and unable to create modern, efficient work practices. The old adversarial approach to industrial relations is no longer appropriate. I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Are the three Defence Trade Commissioners paid by the department; (b) to whom are the Trade Commissioners responsible; and (c) do they report directly to the department as well as to Austrade.
(2) Does Austrade have the power to deny a security clearance even though the department is funding the position.
(3) What security clearance procedures must the Defence Trade Commissioners satisfy before being granted their security clearances, and has it been the same procedures for all three commissioners.

(4) Is the Government planning to review the procedures for the provision of security clearances for personnel engaged in sensitive Commonwealth work, and is the Government, the Minister or the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security concerned that there has been a devolution of authority to issue security clearances from Australian Security Intelligence Organization to Austrade and that this has resulted in the denial of a proper appeal process to persons who are denied security clearances.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) They are employed by Austrade under a joint Austrade and Defence-funded program.
(b) The Senior Trade Commissioner at the relevant post.
(c) No.

(2) Austrade, like other Commonwealth agencies, is responsible for satisfying itself as to the trustworthiness, reliability, loyalty, maturity and character of potential employees; it has the authority to deny a security clearance to an applicant that does not meet these requirements.
(3) I am advised that all three Trade Commissioners were employed in accordance with standard Austrade procedures.

(4) The Government addressed these issues in its response, tabled on 7 December 1994, to a report by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation dated March 1994 and entitled ASIO and Security Assessment: A Review of Security Assessment Procedures. The Government is satisfied that the existing appeal processes for adverse security clearances by agency heads (as distinct from security assessments by ASIO), which are available within Commonwealth agencies (including Austrade) and externally through the Merit Protection and Review Agency or the Ombudsman, are adequate and appropriate. The Security Appeals Tribunal remains the avenue for review of qualified or adverse security assessments by ASIO.

I am advised that ASIO's role has long been confined to issuing security assessments which deal with the question of whether the employment of an applicant might present any risk to security as that term is defined in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979. As explained in the response to (2) above, the employing agency is responsible for satisfying itself as to the trustworthiness, reliability etc of potential employees whose duties may require them to have access to classified material or places. This is the security clearance of which ASIO's security assessments form part. This division of responsibilities and the existing procedures conform with recommendations made in 1977 by Mr Justice Hope in his Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security and re-affirmed by him in his report on the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies.

This question also mentions the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. I am advised that the Inspector-General has no role in relation to these matters. The statutory charter of the Inspector-General expressly precludes him from reviewing ASIO's conduct of security assessments—that is the function of the Security Appeals Tribunal—and limits his jurisdiction to the five intelligence agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 4 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that a Mr Dennis Wholley was deployed by Australia to the Hanoi Embassy.
(2) Is it a fact that he took two suites at the Metropol Hotel while he was in Vietnam.
(3) Is it a fact that the cost to the Australian taxpayer was $US250.00 per suite per night.
(4) Is it a fact that Mr Wholley was resident at the Metropol for 18 months.
(5) If the above facts and figures are not correct, then what is the correct situation.
(6) What was the total amount spent by Mr Wholley on accommodation whilst in Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Mr Wholley took up duty as Trade Commissioner Hanoi in April 1992 and his posting is scheduled to terminate in June 1996. This new position was created coincident with the establishment of an Austrade office within the Embassy structure in Hanoi to capitalise on emerging commercial opportunities as a result of Vietnam's move to a market driven economy.

(2) Mr Wholley moved into the Metropole Hotel on his arrival in Hanoi, then the only hotel of international standard, and occupied a junior suite. From September 1992 when he was joined by his wife, they occupied a complex of two standard connecting rooms, the smallest available in the hotel, with a total area of 72 square metres.
Mr Wholley and his wife moved out of the hotel into a house in early October 1994.
(3) Accommodation costs were as follows:

TAB.TAB: junior suite—$A1,660.00 per week
two adjoining rooms—initially $A2,470.00 per week (increased to $A3,150.00 per week from 1/1/94)
house—$A2,550.00 per week

PARA.TAB: (4) Mr Wholley was in the hotel from April 1992 to September 1994 whilst a search for permanent accommodation was undertaken. The limited availability of suitable housing in Hanoi is well documented. During 1992 and 1993, there were no international standard purpose built apartments or houses available for lease in the city and renovation of older houses was the only viable option for accommodation of an acceptable standard. Two features of the intensive and frustrating ongoing search were the number of houses in poor condition which would have been too costly to renovate and those which, being otherwise suitable, were too costly to lease in the face of serious competition from commercial interests. A lease was signed early in 1994 on a suitable property which, having undergone renovation, has been occupied since October 1994.
(6) Total accommodation costs are as follows:
in hotel 4 April 1992—30 September 1994—$A304,826
in house 1 October 1994—31 December 1994 (present)—$A33,150.

I understand Mr Wholley has performed particularly well in servicing Austrade's clients in difficult circumstances, not the least of which has been the relative discomfort of confined hotel accommodation for him and his wife over an extended period.
